author: @IsaacRodman

text: You asked him about mutation... I don't think people should be concerned about mutation to becoming more dangerous.  That has literally never happened, and it would not be an advantageous mutation for the virus.  Viruses do not want to be ebola.  Viruses want to be herpes.  Their "goal", in as far as an organism that is not even alive, cannot reproduce itself, cannot move, has no metabolism, etc, is to persist and spread (get copied).  Viruses which kill their host do not continue to get copied.  They are failures.  In the case of SARS-CoV-2, it includes a 'proofreader' component, which is pretty unusual for a virus (but common to coronaviruses).  The purpose of that proofreader is to repair mutations.  That doesn't make them impossible, but MUCH less likely.  The genetic drift seen since its initial discovery in Wuhan is VERY small, much smaller than we would expect to see.  And 100% of those mutations have been non-functional.  They're used as 'markers' for virologists to track the virus, but there are very few of them.  (I believe they can tell if the one you got came from NY or the WA outbreaks, though, some of the markers differ there.)  Functional mutations that actually change how a circulating virus affects people are not uncommon.  We haven't seen them in SARS-CoV-2 yet, though.  And every one we have seen in any other virus always, every single time, makes it LESS pathogenic.  Viruses need us for everything.  They really don't want to kill us.  Heck, the viruses that give us the most trouble come from other species, they're not even built to work in us.  That's why zoonotic diseases make the 'mistake' of killing people.

text: It is stunning to me that this guy who so deep into "Bio" does not think that viruses are living.  He compares how they function to a "Swarm". Yea well, a swarm is composed of individuals like honey bees.  Even though they swarm and act as a group does not make the individuals "not living".  Viruses are some of the oldest living things on the planet They are the minimum of life honed to a structural simplicity. This simplified structure makes them different than bacteria, for example, but no less alive. They are a unique life form. They are very much like seeds (or spores): They only grow when they find the right soil in which to do so. And like seeds, even though in a suspended state, they constantly monitor the exterior world around them.  They change, they communicate and they replicate.  The idea that viruses are not alive is the kind of deeply, anthrocentric thinking that has caused so much damage and pain in the name of science.

text: Great interview but i feel that Wolfram's attempts to put him self on the same level as Feynman was pretty cringe worthy. No doubt Stephen Wolfram is a really smart guy, but he comes across as boarder-line delusional in the way he portrays his own mental abilities. The idea that he has been sitting on a stack of Feynman's notes which he has 'yet to have time to look at' is total nonsense. There is almost a zero percent chance that he hasn't looked at them. Rather, he almost certainly would have looked at them (and perhaps still does), but just can't understand what Feynman did. At heart (and at his own admission), Wolfram is a businessman who finds brilliant minds and puts them to use in a very smart way. I think WolframAlpha and his other technical contributions are fantastic and he has done the world a great many services, but I also think its pretty clear he is no genius like Feynman was. Thanks for the podcast Lex!

author: @1997CWR

text:
I watched this great piece some half hour ago, thank you! went away. But something bothered me: "The thing that Feynman did exceptionally well was calculate".
I'm sorry, but what do you calculate? Trying all options may work well in a narrowly confined environment (space).
Does the math lead your thoughts/'intuition', or does intuition, gained from your past Gedankenexperimente/calculations lead the way?
With all the footage of Feynman I've seen, I get the impression that he was extremely honest. It IS intuition that lead him, and only NEXT he calculated.
He was especially gifted at intuition, having always thought in substance and analogies, never in labels! Only next he calculated. and subsequently, fine tuned his intuition.
(So he 'backprop'ed'). That's why Niels Bohr consulted with him. And that's why he proposed nanotechnology ('why can't we..?'). And that's why he remains an inspiration to so many.

text:
@20:40 detailing evolution of states (giving a computational naturalness to SR).
The "order of the update is not defined". This would be discontinuous time (growing block).
This would not result in some people's future being a super-determined causal patch. A future lying observation would non-causally complete a causal network that you/present have not arrived at. SW accounts for small causal patches (microscopic "re-writes"). His hypergraph is 3n space, a Wave Function Realism.
SW's goal is to provide cellular automata as fundamental.
The computational burden placed upon the UWF in such a case for the "update" requires the UWF to be a Godel machine (universality) as it has completed non-causal paths for Godel machines (humans) without their local participation in that path.
SW is injecting his work with disembodied platonic mind which is not pancomputational.
Rather this model would be priority cosmo-psychist.

author: @dcterr1

text: Wow, fascinating discussion! I don't yet understand hypergraphs very well, but it's pretty mind-blowing to imagine that the workings of the universe are built on them and that everything we're familiar with, including space and time, are just emergent properties of these hypergraphs. As for searching for the theory of everything, I don't know how we could ever know we've found it, since we're just part of this structure ourselves and as Wolfram said, the only way to check that we've found the right theory would be to just let its run its course. Perhaps intelligence involves the ability to recognize and utilize "pockets of reducibility", and that the key to finding a theory of everything requires that we're able to utilize the right pockets. I hope I'm making sense here! I'm pretty new to all this, but like I said, my mind is being blown by some of these ideas!

text: So it seems more fundamental to think of the new model in terms of what the universe does (verby) than what it is (nouny). As the latter definition (of what it is) only exists in that one particular state or in that single relativistic instance (which depends on the speed / position of the observers). So the propagation of the hyper-graph edges through abstract hyper-time are the more important constructions compared to the nodes (vertices) of the graph. So the pursuit of theory of EveryThing is futile, which are always 'local' and less fundamental. We should redefine the question as Theory of Global Dynamics.

text:
Quite interesting but my response is the same to everyone who comes up with their own crazy theory of everything, get it peer reviewed, work with the physics community to show that it can do better than string theory.

Just showing that there is a way to think of a hypergraph having curveture is not the same as deriving general relativity. Showing that hypergraphs can split under certain rules is not the same as finding blackholes etc...

By circumventing the peer review process, self publishing a huge 500 page document and going on a self publicity tour on popular science podcasts pretty much guarantees that the people best equipped to advance his work will ignore it.

text:
A few questions:

It's been a while but I read a good bit of Wolfram's "A New Kind of Science". The recurring theme throughout the book is that simple rules can result in complex behavior. For the moment forget that the terms "simple rules" and "complex behavior" are undefined. And let's take cellular automata as an example. Out of more than 100 "simple rules" only two rules result in "complex behavior". How are we supposed to believe that this is how the universe works?? The universe, almost literally, is a computational process governed by a simple rule that yields complex phenomenon. Why should we believe that the underlying rule is simple? Why should the universe "choose" the one simple rule that results in complex behavior from the many rules that result in a simple outcome?

text:
It's a naturally entropic system so it stands to reason that eventually it will work itself back to equilibrium like all entropic systems. How many steps or generations would that take? Could be infinite in a manner of speaking seeing that Infinity itself equates to a complete balance of opposites (positive/negative forces).

I don't know why we find this so fascinating if we posit the idea that the Universe began from The Big Bang which is essentially the same as saying the entire Universe sprang forth from one simple bit of information. This information repeats itself in ever more complex ways no different than a human being begins as one simple bit of information; a single-cell organism called a Zygote that repeats itself in ever more complicated ways over the course of 9 months until it results in a complex multi-cell organism called a baby. Even though all the organs and parts of the baby may appear different from the other, every bit of the baby reflects the same genetic information down to the hair follicles.

We could make the same argument for mathematics. All numbers are really just an extenuation of ONE number. There really is no such number as 72 because 72 is really just the number One repeated 72 times... Again, complex information that emerges from simplicity. And so, we use the number 72 as a symbol to help us simplify and comprehend complex information just as the human brain compiles an impossible amount of complex data at lightening fast speeds via the senses and outputs that information into a simplified format for us to use.

Just saying, whatever the "Answer" is, it must Ultimately be hidden in plain sight...

author: @Julian-we6qg

text:
Perhaps I'm wrong, but isn't this all to do with symmetry? Wolfram says: it *looks* random. That just means the initial rule remains the rule, instead of creating a recognizable large scale pattern you can *recognize* as symmetrical enough to *look* non random. And some rules tend towards symmetry and others do not.

In other words, trying to find the larger pattern is like trying to predict the pattern before the rule does. You have already predicted the pattern, by letting the rule run. There is no alternative to letting the rule run, or the pattern would not be made from this rule. In other words, your rule from the very beginning would hide some other rule. But it cannot. Because at the beginning, there is only the rule, by definition, and the pattern only arises from the propagation of the rule through your defined method of propagation: *line by line* .

It is therefore the *lines* that you are not taking into account, the geometry of the rule is modified by each new line. It's like saying the rule is different at each new line. So of course you can't find the general pattern, because you have to let the rule run one line to find the new rule, that you can then run another line, to find the next rule, then run the rule another line to find the next, etc.

And you're already doing that! There is no shortcut to life. To geometry. Or it would not be geometry.

More deeply, I think confusion can arise from the idea we are using physics to predict behaviours of limited systems. But only of limited systems. We are certainly not capable of predicting exactly how, say, human society on Earth will evolve. We limit ourselves to very, very basic predictions, like where an electron might end up in an orbit. But can we predict where they all will end up at time T in order to predict electrical impulses' trajectories in every single brain on Earth, to predict social events, like when people will get tired of an unfair political system? No. At least, not yet.

Yet this is physics. This should be possible. And indeed it is, when we accept the fact that the rules change based on how the previous set of rules ran for a specific time. For instance I couldn't have predicted how the popularity of social media would evolve in 2006 when Facebook went worldwide, but judging on how people are reacting to it now, Twitter feuds, and opinion of Mark Zuckerberg, etc, (a new line has run), I can tell that there will be issues in the near future. Because I didn't try to predict the entire universe from its original state.

This is a clue, that reality organises itself one line at a time, one event, one action, one interaction, one exchange of force, of energy, at a time. It is likely *local* change, that IS the rule. And the complexity we observe is simply complex *to us* , because it is not made like we are, so we understand ourselves, but not the world. Or at least not as well as we have the *opportunity* to discover ourselves.

It is all simple geometry, movement begetting movement, one step, one line, at a time. That is likely why it is unpredictable. Because you aren't taking into account that the rule evolves and reexpresses itself within its current geometry. Its current line. Our current moment. Or the closest thing to a moment every individual entity can experience.

text: Regarding complexity: Cellular automata is NOT a good example for his point. You have a pretty simple rule for adjacent cells counteraction, but, because there are a lot of them, the only way to find a future state of the system is to go step by step. Is not is the same in "traditional" science?  You have a simple rule describing counteraction of two points, for example, one of Newton laws, but if your system made of 10 (solar system) elements, you end up with an equation system you can not solve in any other way than by numeric modeling - just like in the case of cellular automata.

text: It is not difficult to show that such kind of local updating rules actually generate stationary points of a (discrete) energy of an underlying weighted graph (grid) such as a Bayesian or a Markov graph. Generally, the number of such stationary points is exponential in nature, hence the richness in terms of the motifs one can generate using such simple updating rules.

text:
0:00: üí° Stephen Wolfram discusses the possibility of communicating with aliens and the nature of extraterrestrial intelligence.
0:00: Stephen believes that it would be possible to find a common language with aliens if they were to visit Earth.
5:03: He compares the communication with aliens to the communication with artificial intelligence.
7:07: Stephen suggests that there is no fundamental distinction between computational processes in the weather and in human brains.
9:22: He speculates that there may be two forms of alien intelligence: artificial intelligence and physical/extraterrestrial intelligence.
11:58: Stephen views the details of human civilization as what makes us special, rather than some abstract attribute of intelligence.
13:01: He discusses the concept of a techno signature and the idea of a perfect shape as a sign of engineering.
14:09: ü§î The video discusses the challenge of sending a message that represents human intelligence and civilization to extraterrestrial beings, as well as the difficulties in defining and understanding concepts like understanding, ethics, and long-term survival.
14:09: The question of what to send as a representation of human civilization is philosophically complex and there is no clear answer.
14:41: Computation is a fundamental aspect of human achievements, but it is unclear how to connect human intentions to the computations happening in the universe.
16:23: The Voyager's Golden Record is an example of an attempt to send a message representing humanity, but its format would be unfamiliar to a modern audience.
18:03: Understanding and interpreting a message from extraterrestrial beings is challenging, as it depends on the representation and objectives of the receiving party.
19:48: Defining 'hurt' or 'threat' in the context of interactions with extraterrestrial civilizations is complex and subjective.
21:00: Maximizing the long-term survival of the human species is a difficult objective, as it involves trade-offs and uncertain definitions of 'long-term' and 'survival'.
21:06: Ethics is a human construct that cannot be abstractly proven, and it involves different perspectives and trade-offs.
23:54: The question of what actions optimize the survival of the human species is unknowable due to computational irreducibility.
25:13: The journey and process of understanding the universe is valuable, and the answer may not be knowable or predictable.
26:04: Predicting the outcome of a complex computation, such as the universe, is likely impossible due to computational irreducibility.
26:31: The universe is too complex for us to predict or fully understand, and attempting to do so would imply a superiority beyond the universe.
29:07: üî¨ The principle of computational equivalence suggests that even systems with simple rules can exhibit complex behavior and computation.
29:07: Computation is the process of systematically following rules.
29:30: There is a robust notion of computation that transcends the specific framework in which it is implemented.
37:45: The principle of computational equivalence states that when a system isn't doing obviously simple things, its computational behavior is of equivalent sophistication.
38:13: Simple rules can create complex behavior and computation, even equivalent to Turing machines.
39:26: The principle of computational equivalence is a science fact, but its proof is complicated and has a complicated epistemological character.
41:56: üß† Stephen Wolfram discusses the principle of computational equivalence and the possibility of the physical world being computational.
41:56: The principle of computational equivalence suggests that there exist initial conditions that can represent any program.
42:08: It is unknown if the principle of computational equivalence applies to the physical world.
43:03: If the physical world follows a simple program, physics could be reduced to a branch of mathematics.
43:34: The search for a fundamental theory of physics may reveal if the universe is computational.
46:21: The underlying computational infrastructure of the universe may be as structureless as possible.
47:02: Space and time may emerge from a more structureless system.
51:55: The cognitive capacity of human beings to understand the underlying laws of physics is uncertain.
52:47: Building waypoints and abstract concepts can aid in understanding complex ideas.
53:11: Science is about building cognitive mechanisms for understanding and building on top of them.
53:44: The journey from simple concepts to understanding the laws of physics may be a long one.
54:26: Computational irreducibility is a consequence of computational equivalence.
55:17: üî¨ Stephen Wolfram discusses the principle of computational equivalence and its implications for understanding the universe.
55:17: The principle of computational equivalence suggests that many systems are computationally irreducible, meaning their behavior cannot be predicted without following each step.
55:38: Observers in the universe, including humans, are fundamentally equivalent to cellular automata and cannot 'jump ahead' in computation.
57:05: The question of understanding the fundamental laws of physics requires computational reducibility, which allows for recognizing patterns and building theories.
57:44: Science has learned more about the universe by considering the role of observers and their limitations, such as in the theories of relativity and thermodynamics.
59:06: Determining whether a system is a true quantum computer or a simulator is challenging due to the abstract nature of quantum mechanics.

text: This CD has three separate relaxation/meditation sessions on it https://www.youtube.com/post/Ugkxzpa8CIfZcihW4Z0F_ja0QF3W9KIatrsq guided by a very pleasant and direct male voice. Unlike so many other products of its type, this CD does not have bad synthesizer music, does not feature a phony or affected style of narration, and does not make any bogus claims to be subliminal or to re-train the brain or any of that balderdash. What you get is 1. a guided meditation for getting into a pleasantly relaxed state of body awareness while taking a stroll (superb for those easing back into a fitness routine slowly after an illness or injury) 2. A nice long breath-awareness relaxation session that if followed diligently can put you into very deep states of full-body relaxation and mental calmness, and 3. a buddhist-inspired meditation session designed to help you develop and maintain feelings of loving kindness toward not just yourself and your friends, but toward people you don't even like. The CD makes no claims to be designed for advanced meditators or for buddhists or hindus/yoga practitioners looking for very deep and esoteric stuff. It is geared more toward the average person who just wants to develop the habit of relaxation and stress relief through natural, healthy means. him, if you happen to be reading this, keep up the good work fella, and I love your accent. I would also like to note that I have never fallen asleep while listening to this product. I would like to kindly suggest to the reviewer who said this CD makes him fall asleep, that he might want to get checked to see if he has a sleep disorder, or if he is simply not setting aside ample time for restful sleep at night. A healthy person getting adequate rest at night should be able to go into deep states of mental relaxation without dozing off, if not all the time, then most of the time.

text:
As far as I am concerned, as soon as AI starts asking us the questions I'd consider them equal to humans in the equal rights respect, the issue with my stance is it is easy for a person to create an AI that meets my criteria.

What I mean is if an AI that was trained to answer prompts suddenly out of nowhere prompts the user with a question, at that point I would consider it conscious, there's no way to prove it, just like there is no way to prove that anyone outside your subjective experience is conscious.

But if it looks like a duck, swims like a duck, and quacks like a duck, then it probably is a duck, it could be a squirrel wearing a duck suit disguise, or a thermonuclear explosive device disguised as a duck, but I'm not going to interrogate every duck I ever come across, that would be incredibly rude.

text:
Despite the prevalent desire of educators to view Turing machines as a fundamental form of computation, I
really dislike relying on an infinite paper tape as a mechanism for computation. Infinity is an indication that something is missing in a hypothesis. I'm not offering a replacement idea for the Turing machine ... Just saying that I hold my nose when the idea of Turing machine is mentioned. Somehow, the idea not needing memory to do computation is a dumb restriction. David Butler

text: Wolfram subscribes to the myth of cumulative scientific progress (as opposed to a revolutionary pattern in science), and considers methodological changes (as opposed to paradigm changes) the markers of scientific revolution. Thomas Kuhn (The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, 1964) shows that in the pattern of scientific revolutions there is a crisis of the previous paradigm, resulting in its deconstruction and replacement by a new paradigm. The scientists later re-interpret the older paradigm in light of the new one, and retroactively construct a myth about the meaning of the old paradigm in order to rehabilitate it. Quantum-mechanical physics, to my mind, is in a state of crisis and is ready for a new paradigm.

text: This story may seem shocking, but it's nothing new, really. See for example the story of Hugh Everett III, the originator of the "many worlds" interpretation of quantum physics (by means of the PhD dissertation he wrote in the 50s, while studying at Princeton)‚Äîa theory that was systematically prevented from taking root in academia by the existing gatekeepers of what constituted acceptable discourse at the time, who had created the existing Copenhagen Interpretation (established by Bohr, Heisenberg, et al.) and used their credentials to prevent the advancement of any dissenting theories. In summary, he became so demotivated by the active academic censorship at the time that he left Princeton after completing his PhD, to establish a career working for the defense industry. And in case anybody wonders: in retrospect, with the additional advances in understanding that accrued in subsequent decades, it can now be objectively said that those gatekeepers were an overall impediment to the advancement of knowledge, and without justification (it's not as if the many worlds theory can be said to aid in the development of fantastically destructive weapons‚Äînot like some of the contributions from members of the opposing team).

text:
"Let me show you that you didn't understand (9:35) the Self-Dual Yang-Mills equations correctly in topology and physics."

Within Mathwave 935, Kumiko's concept of Pythagorean localization has a natural tie-in to the Self-Dual Yang-Mills equations. Her model demonstrates how the key concepts of least action and local emergence produce regenerative structures. They are marked by dual symmetry-forming and sequence-breaking as natural requirements of the flow of time following the basic principles of least action and angular momentum. In sum, this Pythagorean localization represents the pass of the baton inherent to tracing out and reconciling the pathways, the vectors of expansion versus the vectors of the orbit within the wavefunction. It is marked, in terms of an event, as the dipole moment, the moment when the divergent paths of expansion and orbit find their closest point of return, also known as perigee.

If you have Frank Wilcek, you wouldn't say, "Frank, let's be honest, 15:35 (935 seconds) you've done very little with your life after the original huge show that you used to break onto the physics scene."

Here, Eric is commenting on the problem of introducing new concepts when the interviewers are most concerned with how other people perceive your work who often are not qualified to understand it.

You will find the best reviews of Eric Weinstein's work from Prince Blake at Quora.

text: Right out of the gate, the mere idea that the most persons must have abridged versions of any kind of information is completely and utterly routed for failure. The technology and communication advances in the last two decades should have led to a worldwide increase in intelligence and honesty in and from our governments and world leaders. It had the polar opposite effect. Adults now must be entertained as if they were children, and view any learned environment as boring or non engaging. Books and reading are becoming increasingly obsolete, as information is transferred into video clips. Subsequently, the average attention span had decreased so dramatically that the average American student is a decade behind their counterparts in most of Europe and Asia. It is beyond disheartening to see such opportunities for enlightenment being completely wasted all in the name of self gratification. We now rely on these devices to spell for us, and grammar and sentence structure is not even part of the curriculum in grade schools. I have three honor-students that are my children, all in high school just outside the nation‚Äôs capital, and none of them were taught what an adverb is, or a pronoun, or how to properly diagram a sentence. We are intentionally being dumbed down, and physically being poisoned to create a weaker and stupid general population. Growing up in a class of 300 there were maybe a dozen kids who were overweight. Now it seems to be the norm, the average. Students are fat, lazy and remarkably dumber than my generation, which is brutally difficult for me to see. It was literally accomplished in a generation using these devices as a weapon. Having a weakened, moronic base allows a vitriolic government to manipulate and control with greater ease. Just look at who we have come to accept as our leaders; our government runs rampant with morons and ideologies based around hate. Half of Americans believe that education and healthcare are not important issues in relation to our kids. It‚Äôs terrifying. There is more a dangerous combination than hate and stupidity, and those two things seem to be most prevalent in our society. We are fast approaching a point of no return, if we haven‚Äôt already. And the division created by hate and fostered by stupidity only grows, as these weaponized devices continue to infiltrate and indoctrinate the youngest and most impressionable. For example, before social media became so prevalent, children‚Äôs answers to what they wanted to be when they grew up would usually be a doctor, a lawyer, a police officer, educator, etc. Noble and useful careers which would contribute to a better society for the most part. Now those answers are YouTuber, Instagram model, and TikToker‚Ä¶I shudder to think how delusional we have all become. None of this is sustainable, and point of fact, the damage is cataclysmic and has progressed far faster and reached far beyond what I previously would have thought possible. I have grown past worry for our future into fear of the immediate and inevitable end‚Ä¶Not just of the American way of life, but of all life as we know it. It is tragic and extraordinarily painful to witness.

text: In a commonplace sense, this has always existed in scientific academia. Before online preprints, leaders in any field sent each other their preprints months ahead of assured publication, so new faculty, faculty at lesser schools and graduate students had no idea where the front line of the field stood. The real scientific communication went on through back channels, and newcomers could only hope to get into the private club and benefit in the same way.

text:
I like Eric, I like Elon. In these comments I think that Eric does not give Elon enough credit - and yet in another sense he is correct. Although Elon is quite proficient in ordinary physics and excellent in engineering, he is optimizing traditional physics - mostly Newtonian physics - rather than making groundbreaking discoveries about the universe; and his genius is really as a businessman bringing new technologies to the masses and as a salesman selling big ideas to the public.

So from Eric's perspective as a top level physicist, Elon appears competent but nothing special - and he's probably right about that as far as physics go. Eric knows lots of extremely smart people who probably understand physics better than Elon, so he naturally thinks that there are lots of other people who could do the same thing if they just put their mind to it - and at one level he is correct. What he is missing (and in fairness what most people are missing) is that it requires a very rare ability to combine multiple fields like physics, engineering, chemistry, economics, business, and salesmanship into a successful enterprise that can actually push humanity forward to become a spacefaring species.

Most cultures around the world actively seek to suppress such business geniuses. In fact, the United States is a rare exception not in that such suppression doesn't happen but in that there are enough people pushing back to provide entrepreneurs some breathing room. The issue is that most humans are hardwired to have moral beliefs about fairness that made perfect sense in the zero sum game of paleolithic hunter-gatherers, but which are actively injurious to humanity in the age of modern economies and modern technology. The United States is one of the rare places where a sufficient proportion of the population is wired to intuitively grasp modern economic conditions that allow these advances to occur, thus improving living conditions for all of humanity.

And that is what Eric is not acknowledging here - that the qualities that make Elon so rare are not about his knowledge of physics, but his abilities for optimization and organization and salesmanship that allow these new technologies to be actualized.

text: I think we are focused on Elon more than some of the other breakthrough scientists not because he as able to avoid "quality control" as Eric suggested, but rather he is an extraordinary science communicator. By establishing inspiring and brands like Tesla and SpaceX and developing his own personal brand, he is able to get the masses to consider his worldview on the most basic level. People love fast cars, but don't want to have philosophical conversations about the implications of Artificial Superintelligence or the dire necessity to create a reliable and affordable way to sustainably create, store, and distribute energy. Thus, Tesla. He's wrapped these esoteric but critical ideas in a freaking racecar with iPad on the dash in order to shape discourse around these topics in a digestible way. Its brilliant, and far more considered than I think he gets credit for, all the way down to his Twitter antics and hitting a blunt on Joe Rogan. I am certain he understands the effect he has on average Americans who want to dream big, who want to have these existential conversations, but need a figure who can make it relatable and fun.
author: @kevinchaiken4253

text:
I share some of the criticism here in the comments, but to Eric's defense I think his point isn't so much about Elon Musk but to sort of ponder on a philosophical level why "the system" hasn't created/rewarded more people like him.

It's an interesting point to say that great men aren't born, but made. It's a democratic notion in a sense whereas elitists tend to think of the greats as endowed by some metaphysical sense of destiny. Eric seems to me to be saying Elon Musk is who we all could/should be, but since we are not then Elon Musk looks more unique as a comparison and has to scale/rebrand his visions as a consequence.

text: A word of caution about Elon Musk: Elon admires Thomas Edison over one of the greatest inventors of all time, Nikola Tesla. Thomas Edison invented only one thing, the electric chair. This is not a great achievement. Edison would take the ideas of others and manufacture them into products that lined Edison's pockets. Likewise, Elon has not invented anything. He has succeeded so far in Manufacturing electric automobiles, rockets for the government and electric backup systems for local utilities. He has correctly concluded that the money is in government Supply. He is joining the industrial government complex. He may be joining the military industrial complex because his rocket to the space station Took 48 hours to arrive at the space station. Where do you think that rocket was for those 48 hours? It only took the Russians 2 hours to deliver our astronauts to the space station. So, the missing 46 hours must have been involved in some kind of classified operations which we can reasonably conclude were on the behalf of the military, as we have no information about the Lost Time.  So, Elon has joined the military industrial complex . Remember, Elon started with PayPal. He always has his eye on the money, and invents nothing. So he and Edison are very much alike. If there is no time there can‚Äôt be a phase shifts, which naturally realign everything. Remember, all you have to do is create an opposite reaction to what‚Äôs happening right now to stop time. You should be able to do that with an energy field. I don‚Äôt think it has to be a very big energy field either. As long as you have something to start collecting the energy once you stop time at the collection area, you can then use that power to create a larger time dilation in front of the sensor, so it self regulates. time is related to our position and movement in space so all we have to do is negate that in a tiny area with a sensor that can collect the energy

You can come and try to hit me on the head a couple of times and see if the station comes in clear but so far I haven‚Äôt gotten anything to work : ). Bring a can of brain tuner spray. LOL


Since I am not a full-fledged scientist, this could be very embarrassing in some ways to give ideas out here but if I don‚Äôt use my mind to the fullest of its ability and try to contribute that even worse for all of you. This may seem stupid to the rest of you, but I‚Äôm trying to do the best I can with what I have.

text: This CD has three separate relaxation/meditation sessions on it https://www.youtube.com/post/Ugkxzpa8CIfZcihW4Z0F_ja0QF3W9KIatrsq guided by a very pleasant and direct male voice. Unlike so many other products of its type, this CD does not have bad synthesizer music, does not feature a phony or affected style of narration, and does not make any bogus claims to be subliminal or to re-train the brain or any of that balderdash. What you get is 1. a guided meditation for getting into a pleasantly relaxed state of body awareness while taking a stroll (superb for those easing back into a fitness routine slowly after an illness or injury) 2. A nice long breath-awareness relaxation session that if followed diligently can put you into very deep states of full-body relaxation and mental calmness, and 3. a buddhist-inspired meditation session designed to help you develop and maintain feelings of loving kindness toward not just yourself and your friends, but toward people you don't even like. The CD makes no claims to be designed for advanced meditators or for buddhists or hindus/yoga practitioners looking for very deep and esoteric stuff. It is geared more toward the average person who just wants to develop the habit of relaxation and stress relief through natural, healthy means. him, if you happen to be reading this, keep up the good work fella, and I love your accent. I would also like to note that I have never fallen asleep while listening to this product. I would like to kindly suggest to the reviewer who said this CD makes him fall asleep, that he might want to get checked to see if he has a sleep disorder, or if he is simply not setting aside ample time for restful sleep at night. A healthy person getting adequate rest at night should be able to go into deep states of mental relaxation without dozing off, if not all the time, then most of the time.

text:
Every time i see and hear Eric talk, i enjoy it. Very charismatic and likable person.

However, whenever people try to explain the fabric of reality, they've lost me. Not only because i'm wayy to stupid to understand, nor explain my thoughts, but mainly because i feel like they make a giant error in logic.
That is that math and other scientific theories are what they are only because we made it so. People see links, reactions and correlations in specific areas and call it an absolute like it is some rule of objective reality. I'm convinced there is no such thing.
All human thought is just a subjective sketch of what the individual thinks the universe looks like. Somewhat like religion, there are as many gods as the amount of people trying to conceive of the concept.

They are obviously very smart and what they're saying is a real phenomenon, it's just not directly connected to absolute reality.
Numbers work the way they do because humans made it so. It's not the "language of the universe".
It is a beautiful, necessary and unavoidable pursuit, but whatever objective reality is (if there is such a thing), no entity of similar make up to us will ever come close to understanding it.

Reference 46:20, Where are the leaders?
If a toxic leader attains some status, their first task is to eliminate the competition. In today's environment, such people use defamation, innuendo, "canceling", then redefinition of terms to control discussion or the meaning of rules, laws, prepositions and theories, and so on. In this environment those who sre late to the game, who try to challenge the game at its roots, are confounded by the confusion and misdirection generated by the game players who have made challenging the game against the rules. Simply, too many people have accepted the rules of the game, and values of tradition and responsibility, the old stories, are against the rules.
I posit that the only way to eliminate the toxic game it to develop the basis of a benevolent game, or at least a playing field, and then persuade a large number of people to abandonthe toxic game and play on the new field.
Develop a new game that provides liberty and responsibility.
Persuade me that I can thrive in the new game.
Provide me with the tools and will to persuade others to play on the new field AND ABANDOIN the old, toxic game,
Recruit Elon Musk to support the organization.

Incidentally: Elon Musk is a pivotal superhero that you have not identified. Is it that he can't become potus that keeps you from discussing him?
author: @thinwolf4516

text:
Reference 0:35:15 Conversation about honesty with the public:.
A weakness in discussing whether information can be shared with the public is that the public is not uniform but broadcasting is.
In the case in point of being honest bout masks and the hoarding of masks versus telling the public that masks are ineffective, there is a portion of the populace that would behave responsibly with knowledge that masks work and that is is important to minimize personal consumption and refrain from hoarding so that healthcare workers, whose exposure is greater and whose services may be needed by anyone, have the masks.
Another, discreet portion of the populace would go straight to panic acquisition mode and purchase every mask available to protect themselves without regard for the safety of others or the contingent safety of those whose assistance they might need.
The problem is that our communications systems broadcast the same information to both groups simultaneously so the "panic" group's response overwhelms the efforts of the "responsible" group.
So it is necessary to treat both groups the same, as the subgroup with the most destructive reaction.
Given that our current communications systems are largely broadcast systems, we have little choice in the message that is distributed.
This is not fair or just, but it is realistic. This is not a case of the need of the greater exceeds the needs of the fewer, it is that the communication systems are inadequate to serve the needs of everyone.
Communications appears to be evolving in the direction of separating audiences. This may, one day, make disseminating the truth possible.

text:
People are made of cells. Cells contain DNA. DNA is made up of molecules. Molecules are made up of chemical elements. Chemical elements are atoms. Atoms have a nucleus made up of one or more positively charged Protons, zero or more neutrally charged Neutrons, and zero or more positively charged Electrons (normally the same numbers as there are Protons), so a single Atom of Hydrogen gas is one Electron orbiting one Proton with no Neutrons, meanwhile a single Atom of Gold has 79 Electrons and 79 Protons and 118 Neutrons. Now there was a mystery in physics which was "Why do atoms with multiple positively charged Protons stay glued together when their Protons should repel each other apart?"

This led to the assumption that there must be some new force of nature gluing Protons together. Later experiments revealed that Protons were made up of three Quarks held together by gluons. Neutrons were made up of three Quarks held together by gluons too. The gluons were responsible for keeping the atomic nucleus together. The way gluons operate is governed by something called the Strong force.

Actually, there are only two types of Quark inside most atoms. There are Up Quarks and Down Quarks. That's it. Very simple.

So you have an Electron with an electric charge of -1

Then you have an Up Quark with an electric charge of +2/3
Then you have a Down Quark with an electric charge of -1/3

Therefore, a Neutron is +2/3 + -1/3 + -1/3 = 0 charge
and a Proton is simply +2/3 + +2/3 + -1/3 = +1 charge

Elegant, isn't it?

So all atoms in the Periodic table are made of Up and Down Quarks held together by gluons with Electrons orbiting them. Those atoms then connect into molecules and can form things like DNA which allows life to replicate itself and grow cells to make new people to make and watch podcasts and comment under the video. These quarks are called elementary particles, and they can't be divided into anything more primitive.

However, particles can be thought of as waves. However, both models of reality are misleading as they are actually fields that are spread out everywhere and interact with each other, and sometimes those interactions seem wave like, and other times they seem like point particles moving around.

Eric Weinstein is saying that there is just a single unified field named omega which interacts with itself in fourteen dimensions to produce relativistic waves, some aspect of which are determined via interaction with the engine of observation that is gravity - i.e. the "curvature" of our readily accessible four dimensional spacetime.

Geometric Unity is a speculative work in progress that aspires to be a Unified Field Theory and a potential future candidate for what a Theory of Everything might look like. It is not yet either. It does not describe itself as a Theory in his incomplete draft paper. Lex described it as a Theory of Everything, which is a misrepresentation of where Eric Weinstein has got with it thus far. It may become a candidate for a Theory of Everything at some point in the future, but it might take several years more work. It is hard to say "How long?" with these things as Albert Einstein worked on his Unified Field Theory at Princeton University for the last thirty years of his life and was unable to solve the problem.

Eric Weinstein thinks that the problem can be solved by unifying the almost incompatible types of geometry which underlie both Quantum Field Theory and General Relativity. Here, Quantum Field Theory is based on the geometry of Charles Ehresmann. General Relativity is based on the geometry of Bernhard Riemann. These geometries can be made to work by the construction of a kind of bridge between both geometries, that Eric Weinstein calls a Chimeric fiber bundle as, like the mythical Chimera that has the head of a lion and tail of a snake, Eric needs to find a way to join the fourteen dimensional Ehresmannian surface where omega lives with the four dimensional Riemannian spacetime where we live.

Hence, Geometric Unity.

Then you have a single field omega 'pulled back' through this Chimeric fiber bundle so that some aspects of this field manifest as phenomena in our four dimensional Universe, like quarks and electrons (i.e. Fermions) and gluons (i.e. Bosons). I'm leaving out a lot of detail, so you may want to read my longer comments on my video:

Geometric Unity explained in under 2 minutes

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wVlDoR_EMPg

text:
Lovely song.
Sometimes the way out is indifference.
Some people don't respond to love.
They think that it's a weakness or something.
I've gone the extra mile for different people.
Some can't even be bothered to say thank you.
I don't know what to think about love anymore.
Love is beautiful though if you can cultivate that in your life.
I've had times in my life where I felt love in my life, like I had a piece of heaven.
I was actively cultivating love in my life.
I had the biggest dreams at that time.
Life was magical despite the tough spots.
And other times, when people started changing, where my heart felt like it was going through hell on earth.
I had to come to terms with the realities of life over the years.
I don't know if love is the answer.
Maybe beauty is.
I don't know.

author: @guslevy3506

text:
I think that too many people are focusing on the game, which I also follow, as if this were an ordinary player. Since I have significant knowledge, and since I believe that Hawking and Musk were right, I am really anxious by the self-taught nature of this AI.

This particular AI (and its more generalized, even more recent variant MuZero) is not the worrisome thing, albeit it has obvious, potential applications in military logistics, military strategy, etc. The really scary part is how fast these were developed after AlphaGO debuted.

We are not creeping up on the goal of human-level intelligence. We are likely to shoot past that goal amazingly soon without even realizing it, if things continue progressing as they have.

The early, true AIs will also be narrow and not very competent or threatening, even if they become "superhuman" in intelligence. They will also be harmless, idiot savants at first.

Upcoming Threat to Humanity.
The scary thing is the fact that computer speed (and thereby, probably eventually AI intelligence) doubles about every year, and will likely double faster when super-intelligent AIs start designing chips, working with quantum computers as co-processors, etc. How fast will our AIs progress to such levels that they become indispensable -- while their utility makes hopeless any attempts to regulate them or retroactively impose restrictions on beings that are smarter than their designers?

At first, they may have only base functions, like the reptilian portion of our brain. However, when will they act like Nile crocodiles and react to any threat with aggression? Ever gone skinny dipping with Nile crocodiles?

I fear that very soon, before we realize it, we will all be doing the equivalent of skinny dipping with Nile crocodiles, because of how fast AIs will develop by the time that the children born today reach their teens or middle age. Like crocodiles that are raised by humans, AIs may like us for a while. I sure hope that lasts. As the announcer in Jeopardy said about a program that was probably not really an advanced AI long ago, I, for one, welcome our future, AI overlords.

text:
As much as I am happy science is advancing in important fields. Ultimately, I am very saddened by the effect of the victory of Alpha Go over Lee Seedol. Many in the go community myself included consider Lee Seedol a hero, a guy you could rely to defeat any opponent. To see him lose was a shock. So by all means the fourth game meant a lot to me. It meant that humanity could somehow defeat software by innovation, unexpected calculation and "kiai (fighting spirit)". We lived in simpler times, and most people playing go started in their teens and some have developed into really high quality players. In effect, the complexity of the game's patterns makes it that by sheer dedication a 15 year old nerd in 2005 like myself could beat a 45 year old who wasn't concerned by the patterns of the fuseki and josekis.

And you could ask anyone of the go community how they felt about Alpha Go's victories over Lee Seedol and people will probably not talk to you about the AI optimization. They will tell you something else... The word you will hear will be: "I felt sad". And then if you ask them about game 4, they will tell you "I felt hope'. Ultimately humanity does have the intellect, the potential, the pattern recognition, the ability to create arts and to give meaning to things. And al of those considered, I think robots might somehow be better at all of those one day... Except one thing that they will never outmatch us in: the beauty of the human emotion. We will win that game a 100 times out of a 100, regardless of the source code or optimization. :))
author: @m4r_art

text: Thanks. This is teaching us a lot about intelligence - "if then else" statements (one off programs), "Monte Carlo, Tree Searches" (Deep Blue), "Learning from experts" (AlphaGo), Learning with no previous knowledge (Alpha Zero) and Learning  knowing even no rules (NewZero).  Amazing, and I now understand how the progression is actually removing the inbuilt limits inherent in each approach with the "final" answer being that the AI has to be able to work out everything for itself without prompting.  Amazing! Being a very modest Chess player I found it difficult to appreciate the staggering achievement of AlphaZero, that only knowing the rules it was able via self-play to effectively uncover the knowledge in Modern Chess Openings in a few hours.  Looking at the commentaries, for example, on its games against Stockfish you would hear such as, "it now chooses the Dragon variation of the Sicilian" but the wonderful thing is that it didn't get that out of a database, it worked it out for itself! It cloned human knowledge of 2000 years in a few hours. Thanks David and Lex.

9:14 Computation model of Universe


Classical computation is 2 dimensional.
Where classical computation is a function of space and time.

Where we can only compute in 1 and 0.
Time is a derivative of 2d computation with iteration.
When we parallelise 2d computation it rise to space.

Quantum computation is 3 dimensional in potential . Where time and space collapse.

Let us model the universe with this idea.

the quantum scale is infinite precision computing.
The universe is zero precision.
Scale is a gradient of precision.
Time is a function of delta precision.
delta precision in precision gradient is space.

From microscopic to macro gravity is a symptoms of relative growth between objects in that scale.
We can derive that from the bifurcation map where r 0 to 4 can me map into world scale. Plank scale would be 4 and observable universe is 0.

From this assumptions, we derive both zero precision and infinite precision is stateless. Therefore no computation.

Therefore, zero and infinite precision is both non temporal and non spacial.
Space and all the dynamics are in between these two point.

Now, we can model the universe with bifurcation map.
Where plank scale would be r value 4.
And observable universe would be r value 0.

From this we can derive the motion for every subsystem in their relative scale.
author: @srimallya

text:
When he says that "consciousness is not a computation" isn't that the same as saying it is not a result of cause and effect? When someone is put to sleep I think it is wrong to say they loose consciousness. I don't think that is the correct use of the word 'consciousness'. I see consciousness as a vastly many varied state. It's the amount of consciousness that is of concern when someone is put to sleep. I say they are still conscious when so-called unconscious, it's just that they are not as conscious as they were when their brain was taking note of all the data coming in from their senses. I think the proper use of the word 'unconscious' is that it means dead.

I believe computers, or rather human-made computers, experience consciousness because I see consciousness as being data. The act of using data is consciousness i.e. this is what it is like to be a working human brain. Every part of consciousness is data. To be conscious is to be conscious of something, in other words to have data of that something. To be unconscious is to be conscious of nothing i.e. dead. When you are 'unconscious' (in the present use of the word) your brain is still using data, it is still conscious of something, it's just not conscious of the outside world, and in the case of anaesthesia, not conscious of pain. That's why I say consciousness is a vastly many varied state. To understand the consciousness of anything, be it a fox, a bee, an ant ..... a laptop .... you have to ask the question 'What is it conscious of?' i.e. 'What does it have the data of?'.

I understand that a human brain is bound to be very different to a human-made computer brain. Of course it will be, it has evolved over millions of years, we grow from seed, we have a childhood, we have needs, we are made from flesh and bone. A human-made brain is made from silicon and metal, has no needs, or at least does not know it has needs, does not have a childhood, it is completely different ... BUT ... do those differences mean it is not conscious? Does the fact that the human brain has these microtubules mean that it is therefore conscious and the human-made brain is not? I do not see how they come to that conclusion. Is not everything the result of cause and effect?

text:
why Penrose and other brilliant scientist, seem to despise the possibility of having intelligent machines?, I mean, consciousness is not a computation, ok. But what can you say about a general theory of the neocortex?, very little to zero. And what can you say about the principles governing information processing in the brain?, very little too.
But for some magical reason, we seem to be convinced that consciousness (an eufemism for intelligence) is not a computation.
This puzzles me, particularly coming from such brilliant people as Mr. Penrose. I ought to be missing something here.

text: Ask Sir Roger why he wears a comb-over and he might say that it makes him feel better, that he wants to control how he's perceived. So why does he care about how he's perceived? He might say that his feelings are affected by others opinions/attitudes. But how? ... Perhaps feelings convey to us the energies which flow between us or the quality of field which we inhabit? If there are no such energies or fields then the comb-over is a just device to make the wearer trick themselves into believing that they are better thought of by others thus, perhaps, improving body chemistry? ... but a thinking man would know better than to have to fool himself to overcome self consciousness and would choose the practical hair style over the trouble of managing absurdly long and lopsided strands. ... Feelings are likely the best route to understanding consciousness. What could you do with the maths of consciousness anyway? ... achieve enlightenment by taking a pill? Tell God/the Tao/the unified field that now we know!! ... when we could've just lived well? Tell yourself the truth and know/make sense of your feelings and the need to pin consciousness down, reduce it to numbers, will evaporate ... probably. But I suppose that one route to happiness is having others think that you're really clever!

text:
Attempt at defining consciousness:
The information gathered from the senses is perception.
The recognition and understanding of those perceptions, is knowledge.
Based on a set of known/unknown feelings, {happy, hungry, passive, bleh, etc...}
(Bleh is an example of an unknown feeling, not enough knowledge to accurately define it. Is it sickly? Is it a mixture of tired and bored? People answer "i dont know" all the time when it comes to feelings.)
Assigning a grouping of weights to the set, gives rise to emotions, (50% happy, 50% sad = bittersweet?)
The grouping of all emotional outputs, including the output from sensing the change in your emotional output, to all scenerios, gives rise to your personality.
A being that is able to sense its own personality and the changes to it, as well as reorganize the hierarchy of its feelings, is conscious.

feeling hierarchy: happy > hungry > sad
reorganizing the hierarchy redefines your inherit goals which contribute to your personality.

text:
What a profound way to discuss about the meaning of life!

First there are several layers for the meaning of life. First layer would be "Does the universe have a meaning?". Well, it looks like it operates on some very fine-tuned laws and constants. At first glance, there is no meaning. For the next layer, let's look at 2nd law of thermodynamics. It's purpose to increase entropy. What if the evolution is just a mechanism (a sub goal) in order to increase entropy further? Evolution's goal is how to reproduce efficiently. In other words how to spread energy efficiently. Because of it, entropy will increase as efficiently as possible.

This line of thought is truly mind-blowing. Probably I will not able to sleep for 2-3 days, because of thinking about this concept...

Lex and David, Thank you for the conversation!

text: The mystery that was aalways very interesting to me was, why machine learning works without any algorithm. What was that latent variable everyone talked about in every topic of ML. I surely did not find those answers in any tutorial except that they were approximating a function. But made that function work, what was the logic, it was always a black hole. I spent a lot of time just thinking about what the hell was this latent space of VAE?i saw maths of matrix multiplication bur absolutely no intution what was that latent space. However, i came upon transfomer like idea much before reading these topics. But, whatever i read in ML, this idea was always counter intuitive to what i thought should be.. So, i thought my understanding must be rubbish to the way it works. I understood what those weights in DL were but never could not understand why it was always intialized to 0 or with some  hyper-parameter. search. But, all were giving absolutely no intuitions the current deep learning material was taught. Here, only thing helps is how you view things or perceive which is the uniqueness of super smart people i have listenedt to. They always struggle witj ideas which are counter intuitive and hence their learning is slow with taught material and often are not grade a+ of their class because their ideas may be better but simply not accepted.

text:
Would then the meaning of life be to contribute to increasing the entropy of the universe as proposed by David/MIT? In other words, are we evolving to survive and to reproduce to be able to scale our energy dissipating systems? That would be consistent with the definition of energy consumption-based civilization's technological advancement scale proposed by Kardashev. Looking at the expected long-time rewards, we're not dissipating all of the potential energy available to humans now because it wouldn't be conducive to dissipating more energy in the future as we would want to use our resources more effectively towards expansion. Make Dyson spheres, not war <3

text:
Lex, you definetly have my respect, but I don't agree with this. Here's this random's take:

There's way more powerful and pure things to rely on than dissatisfaction. If you run on dissatisfaction you're not being fair, you're relegating yourself to a dog chasing its tail. Pursue external things because of appreciation, illusion and impetus, because you want them in of themselves, not because of the sweet yet full of shit feeling that they'll complement you in a way that will make you complete. Always act through gratitude, never through selfishness.

Be the predator instead of the prey, as bad as this sounds, live for the why as opposed to the why not.

text:
I agree with the warning. I've experienced this myself. At one point in my life I had a girlfriend. Any time when I'd bounce an idea off with her it was met with criticism. I know that my ideas have holes and that they are very open to critique, but it drains the life out of someone when you hear criticism every time and never some positive reinforcement. The idea was that she'd give criticism in order to improve the idea, but whenever I listened to her tone, I never got the idea that it got conveyed in that way. There was some miscommunication on how her criticism was meant to be taken. I also didn't always experience the criticism as constructive (sometimes I did experience it that way). Ultimately, I stopped telling her my ideas, but my spirit got drained.

Contrast this to an entrepreneurial friend of mine. The first thing he did was build on the merits of the idea. And I think that's what you should do. Because when I think about any FAANG company, I could should down all of those ideas with a similar style of criticism that my girlfriend from back in the day used.

It wasn't only her. It was also people that I looked up to and listened to. The people that I looked up to were wealthy, smart and kind but quite conservative (financially speaking, not politically speaking, and in their position they should be financially conservative). So I got financial conservatism 101 advice. Rationally, it's sound advice. But in retrospect it fucked with my emotions and I simply wasted a year applying to jobs. I wasted a year because I put the bar high but only have 60 to 80% of my soul in it.

That sounds like a lot, but when you put 100% of your soul into something, then crazy shit happens. Stuff like: you're breaking your own scale and now the 60 to 80% of yesteryear is now 30 to 40% when you're looking at your new scale. Or you get energy from what you do instead that it takes energy. I find working on stuff that takes energy amazing as it teaches me something about life and it builds a form of character. But a person is so much more productive if what that person does gives energy instead of taking it.

I agree with the warning, mostly. As you can see, I had a friend who definitely helped with his advice. But most people didn't help.

I'm not sure if you should follow your passion though, because while all of this is amazing, I've seen 2 caveats:
- Amazing musicians who lived below the poverty line. It's nice to make music but they were rationing their meals.
- Horribile musicians who thought they were amazing and lived a 100% for music. You see them come by on music competition shows.

So I think with this advice some simple economic theory should be in order. Are you in a winner takes all market, or in a more egalitarian market (i.e. programming)? Do you care about not eating every day? In other words: what are your financial needs? Also, how much are you willing to sacrifice? Following your passion may mean not seeing your family, friends and significant other for a long time. It could also mean that you get to see them more and be more connected (it really depends on what you're passionate about), but to my understanding: Einstein, Steve Jobs and Elon Musk had or are having issues in this department.

Finally, this message is too easy. The word "passion" biases us to "follow your passion". Which implies to follow one thing. That's easy to remember. But what if you want to balance 5 things? Why not have a more nuanced discussion on balancing multiple areas of life? Also, there is a darkside of passion. I've already stated a potential social darkside, but your health as well. When I'm passionate, I can't sleep because my mind races about the thing I'm passionate about. I ignore all else, it's like drugs except I'm being productive and creating somekind of app just for the sake of it. Is that really what you want your life to be like? I mean, I thoroughly enjoyed the moments I've been passionately working on my computer graphics engine in 2012, doodledocs.com in 2019 and hacking on hackethebox.eu in 2020. But I haven't spoken to people in those months as well, I averaged 5 to 6 hours of sleep per day, had horrible exercise and eating habits. I could've done better at that but it's hard since I'm not passionate about exercise or healthy eating, I like it, but when I'm passionate then everything else has to move.

I think a warning on "live your life with passion" with the above comments should be stated as well.

text:
These are some thoughts on life and artificial intelligence to engineering students, my friends, and family. Here's the outline:
0:00 - Overview - The Voice poem
6:46 - Artificial intelligence
13:44 - Open problems in AI
14:10 - Problem 1: Learning to understand
17:15 - Problem 2: Learning to act
19:28 - Problem 3: Reasoning
20:44 - Problem 4: Connection between humans & AI systems
23:57 - Advice about life as an optimization problem
24:10 - Advice 1: Listen to your inner voice - ignore the gradient
25:12 - Advice 2: carve your own path
26:28 - Advice 2: Measure passion not progress
28:10 - Advice 4: work hard
29:05 - Advice 5: forever oscillate between gratitude and dissatisfaction
31:10 - Q&A: Meaning of life
33:11 - Q&A: Simulation hypothesis
36:15 - Q&A: How do you define greatness?

text: Very passionate, romantic, 'ideas guy' speech. Uses all the right buzz-words. Reality is, only the top 1% of the top 1% of the top 1% most elite graduates, who have been coached in calculus since 3 years old and naturally love it, are going to succeed in this ultra-ultra-ultra-competitive field of AI. And then, as the speaker openly admits, you can prepare for a drab, dull life of suffering and struggling. Yes if you are in the lucky 0.0001% then you will end up as a multi-millionaire because you 'suffered' enough for some wealthy VCs to take pity on you. This is a winner-take-all game. There isn't room in this field for people who are whole human beings and have interests beyond the narrow, restrictive confines of hard hard hard math.

text:
"Now the dream is to create a system that you can love and that can love you back."
As a fellow computer science student I'm always saddened by Silicon Valley crowd's desperate quest to find/create love within the machine. It seems the world would be spared a lot of technological missteps if they'd foster such 'systems' in the analog world, in the form of families and communities instead. Trying to build technological substitutes for human love and connection is a fundamentally misguided endeavour in my perspective. As fascinated as I am by the science and engineering, I think the work of technologists should be to automate necessary but dangerous, difficult, or mind-numbing work so that we can spend more time with our loved ones, create communities, engage and play in shared creativity, connecting on a physical level - all those most human things. Protect the environment. Build shared and sustainable prosperity for as many people as possible. So many valuable goals. Building a machine that loves is necessary for none of them. It's a huge distraction in my view.

text:
I really enjoyed this conversation with Roger. Here's the outline:
0:00 - Introduction
3:51 - 2001: A Space Odyssey
9:43 - Consciousness and computation
23:45 - What does it mean to "understand"
31:37 - What's missing in quantum mechanics?
40:09 - Whatever consciousness is, it's not a computation
44:13 - Source of consciousness in the human brain
1:02:57 - Infinite cycles of big bangs
1:22:05 - Most beautiful idea in mathematics
author: @lexfridman

text:
Memory probably has an instant recall at an instinctive, unconscious level, that perhaps can be honed to a fine precision following years of practice, wherein a kind of automatic pilot takes over.

A tennis player or a classical pianist didn't become instinctive overnight, they practice for hours everyday. until instinct takes over and it all looks effortless and superhuman. Practice makes perfect as they say.

Humans in that sense anticipated AI, as practice almost works like the endless running of simulations until reaction times get quicker and quicker. A kind of self programming algorithm.

But such intuitive behavior might also speak to Chomsky's window of stimulation in youth as most classical pianists and tennis players start in childhood.

If that early start is not pursued in childhood, it's almost impossible for late starters to catch up, no matter how much they practice,

text:
The actual workings of the brain largely elude us at the moment. But this is not (just) a matter of not understanding consciousness. We don't really understand things like memory, perception, muscle control and movement, and so on.
But all that is understanding of the mechanism. And consciousness is not part of the mechanism. Consciousness is an emergent property. There's no such thing as proto-consciousness, and so on and so forth.

We don't need some mysterious quantum effect at work in the brain at the physical level to be able to explain consciousness.
I'm not saying that there's no mystery / unexplained things down there. What I'm saying is, that we don't need to understand that, to understand consciousness.
Incidentally, this is also the reason why a machine can become self-aware, and conscious.

I should write a book or article to explain these things. Because even smart people like Penrose, I hear him talk and it's clear to me that he has no idea about this, and about what consciousness really is.
This is because he's been trained as a scientist, and is (still) a materialist. Which is unfortunate.

The spiritual realm (to which consciousness belongs), is not some kind of subtle or tenuous material world. To think that the spiritual world is like the physical world, only a little subtler, or in rarefied form, that is materialism!

text:
Spirit is the origin, as metaphysics teaches. It is the cause of all reality and thus the solution to how all creation is interconnected. If science can accept that the universe was created from a big bang with a physical universe instantly coming into existence from either nothing or a singularity within a black hole, then, is it not conceivable for science to shift and evolve to a potential proto consciousness, the belief that a creative intelligence existing within all physical world levels could be the point of origin? Could it not be conceivable that the premise that, there must be something beyond that fabric of consciousness in order for It to exist be invalid? (Irreducible Factor) Would it not be potentially logical for there to be a dimension consisting of an infinite, spiritual fabric of internal consciousness that is irreducible and that is responsible for reality?

In my search for answers for forty years in the field of metaphysics, it was necessary to analyze the action of Nature as we experience it in the physical world, on a moment-to-moment basis, and then, deduce it to the inner dimensions of existence, to the point of origin. It is at this juncture that post modernism in the science field lacks that remaining piece of discipline, accepting the existence of an absolute, inner, irreducible, spiritual fabric of creative intelligence that is responsible for the vibratory formation of all physical world phenomena. It is for this reason that science alone will not find a viable answer of how the universe was created.

text:
If this is a sim, then it must be an ancestor sim for the mathematical argument to make sense; and an ancestor sim must be faithful in detail to the Real World to be of any value. So this world is probably as close to the Real 21st century human experience as our genius descendants could manage.

So, anything they could have done or thought in 2020, presumably so can we.

They might change up the conditions to test their models, and maybe just for fun/what if? But the majority of sims would be faithful as possible, and so statistically we should expect to find ourselves in one of those.

It's a fun idea, and the logic of it is hard to shake, but I can't get over my visceral rejection of it. (Programmed that way, I'm sure.)

text: I'm sure this comment will ruffle a few feathers, but really have to wonder if doing philosophy should be a full-time occupation that anyone should pursue. Consider the periods in which philosophy as a wholistic discipline really bloomed, let's say as represented by the ancient medieval and early modern period. People like Plato and Aristotle were early enough so that they could theorize about the nature of the universe without having to become specialists in multiple fields; people like Thomas Aquinas had a vocational duty to begin to try to put together a holistic view of reality; finally, somebody like Immanuel Kant could use a fully formulated Newtonian physics as a model. But we now live in an age in which holistic thinking seems better realized as The outcome of speculation done by people within the individual disciplines. That conflicts with the way that philosophy has evolved as a discipline in it's own right ‚Äì as one that requires a great deal of specialization, without requiring any actual real knowledge of fields outside it's on discipline. That leaves the philosopher without much to talk about except developments in various arguments that are carried on by philosophers, but that lack a feeling of relevance simply because it has become more and more of an isolated discipline in line with the specialization in academic disciplines surrounding it. There's some thing that doesn't feel quite comfortable about working Day after day within a field that isn't rooted in anything by the development of its own speculative arguments. But If physicists for example could take over to a greater extent the tools and arguments of philosophers that apply to their field, then they would be the ones to be in the best position to draw those conclusions. They do of course already do that to some extent, but a professional philosopher can always find places where they overlooked something. For the individual philosopher it must feel somewhat alienating, isolating, and maybe even a little bit fraudulent in some sense to spend all their time in  a field whose subject matter forces them to look to places other disciplines can't quite claim and make a daily preoccupation out of them. To me, the guest's demeanor seems like A reflection of that basic problem inherent in the discipline of philosophy. The question of whether this is important and why has to be raised at all points. Such preoccupations seem sitting for someone such as a novelist or for a physicist or a computer scientist who is thinking about these things as a sideline to their main work, but there's something odd about someone having to exert themselves consistently to become an expert on such issues. Yet the evolution of the discipline demands it.

text:
If you reverse the question you get, could an AGI we've created in a simulation understand this world?


There are practical reasons to create a simulation with intelligent agents spanning larger timespans (therefore not even requiring as much raw computing power). Right now the lifetime of a scientist is short in relation to the timespan of the universe. In the future we may find space exploration being carried out by somewhat intelligent agents (even if it's just narrow AI), constructing larger particle accelerators and telescopes to give Earth a better view of the universe.


There's no reason for the hypothetical outside reality to be any different to ours. For all we know it could be less complex with us merely riding on top of an emergent complexity (maybe that's why the universe is so uniform ;) ).


For Elon Musk, ... he founded Neuralink. In the space of 2 years he's become a pioneer in the technology that could enable a brain in a vat. Now, if we are in a simulation, maybe that may place an upper limit on the potential capabilities of Neuralink or OpenAI, so it may be in his best interests to think about this.
