text:
Bothered me when Lex was saying that humans have evolved to drive he meant in terms of learning to process and deeply understand the context of our environment. Jim Keller cut him off and made a joke about how humans have been driving cars in the prehistoric. I respect Jim but cmon.

Sure machine learning is getting better at learning and completing tasks... But is it understanding? From what I understand the underlying maths results in associations and geometric relationships between contextual objects but between all this data there doesn't seem to be understanding and learning in the same way that humans learn. The fact that humans can decide on what they want to learn is amazing in itself. Noone has to sit us down and force us to have a reward mechanism (although to a degree it helps). What is consciousness? And will we ever produce computers sophisticated and fast enough to process and contextualize information like humans? I personally don't think they'll be computers in the sense that we have now.

text:
I really enjoyed this conversation with Jim. Here's the outline:
0:00 - Introduction
2:12 - Difference between a computer and a human brain
3:43 - Computer abstraction layers and parallelism
17:53 - If you run a program multiple times, do you always get the same answer?
20:43 - Building computers and teams of people
22:41 - Start from scratch every 5 years
30:05 - Moore's law is not dead
55:47 - Is superintelligence the next layer of abstraction?
1:00:02 - Is the universe a computer?
1:03:00 - Ray Kurzweil and exponential improvement in technology
1:04:33 - Elon Musk and Tesla Autopilot
1:20:51 - Lessons from working with Elon Musk
1:28:33 - Existential threats from AI
1:32:38 - Happiness and the meaning of life

text:
It's kind of amazing how bad is Lex at interviewing. He doesn't really listen to his guest (as you can tell by the remarks he makes right after he's done explaining something), ask vague and uninteresting meme questions ("artists VS engineers", "meaning of it all", etc.) and even dare to correct his guest when the guy has 100x more experience in the industry than he does. "We can disagree on this" ? Well no, you don't disagree like that with a man like Jim Keller, right to his face. Your position should be "maybe this highly-accomplished guy knows more than I do".

text: Arguments against the viability of AI driving are all based in bias and ignorance.   Jim nailed it.  The rates of possible change are thousands of times slower than the computational capabilities of even current poorly optimized hardware and software.  You cannot succeed when projecting the limitations of your own meat onto systems which lack the same limitations.  That's why machine learning proved more successful than prescriptive approaches.  Machines don't need to approach problems the same way we do.  To force these assumptions on them reduces their performance.

text:
So, the hard problem of consciousness is 1. why does subjectivity exist at all and 2. Through what process does mental experience arise out of brain/nervous system functions.

I've always found the answers of 1. An evolved Survival advantage for organisms to be able to perceive their environment, plan actions, & mentally represent itself in space + throughout time.
And 2, Consciousness is an emergent phenomenon that emerges as a result of biological energy expenditures +complex nervous system functions. So subjectivity is the result of brain networks containing millions of neurons all with thousands of synaptic connections & all firing 5-50 times per second. The emergence of consciousness is perfectly compatible with physics and is a widely agreed upon explanation for many novel properties of the universe.

So the answer to the why part of hard problem of consciousness is evolved survival advantage and the answer to how is Emergence.

Also, panpsychism is a really unrealistic idea; we still have evidence of the Neural Correlates of Consciousness so attributing a fundamental consciousness absent any evidence then creates a problem of explaining the real evidence. That's called the compounding problem asking why only living organisms with brains have the external indicators of consciousness and why NCCs exist at all

On the subjective side, an illustration of panpsychism I gravitate towards is that consciousness is a fundamental aspect of reality, possibly related to string theory, meaning it is a form of energy with cohesive will that forms matter through vibrational aggregation. A way matter can be interpreted to be conscious is in varying degrees related to its experience of reality. A rock simply experiences its existence as such and the influence of whatever alters it, such as erosion and time, but without qualia, supposedly. So the complexity of processes varies the degree or interdimensional window of consciousness.

text:
So mind and consciousness are related, somehow. I wonder about the following kinds of statements being true (or not):
mind ==> consciousness
consciousness ==> mind
or mind if and only if consciousness.

I'm not sure what the standard views are on this. Chalmers, negates the 1st if-arrow, if a zombie is a person with a mind but no consciousness (possibly, I'm not a Chalmers expert). The fact that he CAN negate the 1st if-arrow means (to him) physicalism fails in some sense. Now what worries me with respect to "panpsychism" is that Chalmers seems to be negating the 2nd if-arrow (unless he thinks a sugar-molecule has a mind). I tend to the bi-conditional view of consciousness and mind (with the larger the consciousness, the larger the mind).

text: It's becoming clearer that with all the brain and consciousness theories out there, the proof will be in the pudding. By this I mean, can any particular theory be used to create a human adult level conscious machine. My bet is on the late Gerald Edelman's Extended Theory of Neuronal Group Selection. The lead group in robotics based on this theory is the Neurorobotics Lab at UC at Irvine.  Dr. Edelman distinguished between primary consciousness, which came first in evolution, and that humans share with other conscious animals, and higher order consciousness, which came to only humans with the acquisition of language.  A machine with primary consciousness will probably have to come first.
author: @GrantCastillou

text: Subjective experience is overrated as a problem requiring explanation. The discussion seems to assume an externally undisturbed brain for the purposes of discussion. But it is easy to see, when a person goes under the influence of anesthetic (alteration of brain chemistry) their subjective experience disappears. This happens to a varying degree when a person gets drunk or gets high on a drug. If one could do such an experiment, it will show that when a brain is in some shape or form purturbed, the person's realtime, reported subjective experience will be affected. The point? Subjective experience IS the brain structure and/or state. And when we report the subjective experience we use the same brain mechanisms to report it as such.

Our individual subjective consciousness will return to the vast ocean of consciousness, like how a water droplet returns to the sea. Plants, rocks, nonliving objects are "potentials" for consciousness. Given enough time, even a rock will become conscious. It will borrow consciousness when the basic requirements are met.

text: If you've ever passed out, the experience of regaining consciousness is really interesting to reflect on in terms of trying to understand what consciousness is. In my case, regaining consciousness wasn't really like a light switch was turned on and then suddenly I was fully conscious. It was more like consciousness emerged over the course of about 15 seconds (or so it seemed), almost like the brain had to reboot and reload all the programs. When I opened my eyes I saw faces looking down at me but I didn't really understand the concept of what a face is - like my brain hadn't loaded that program yet. Hard to explain, but fascinating. It makes me think that there really isn't some line between consciousness and not.

text:
I grew up in the 80‚Äôs to a great show called ‚Äútransformers‚Äù! The show had something very interesting with it that I think is more profound then even the original idea of its creation was intended!
For one, ‚Äúthe Prime‚Äù was physical device that holds the history of all those that came before, collecting the history and experience of each ‚Äúspark‚Äù (soul) that came from each leader before it.
The Original creation was from Primus (human?) and used the ‚Äúall-Spark‚Äù to forge a new spark (soul) that was unique, which was in the form of a transformer.
What‚Äôs interesting is that Optimus prime could represent some form of consciousness from his past experiences with other sparks occupied in the Prime. All the other transformers reacted to optimus‚Äôs orders as they themselves lacked form of free thinking without additional orders. Each autobot or decepticon was stuck in universal war that seems to be held in balance so long as Optimus Prime was reacting to new experiences that arose from Decepticons attempting his demise.
So long as Optimus prime was able to react, everything was in balance as both primes creativity and the expertise of all autobots were employed to complete a task.
Even the word ‚Äúautobot‚Äù implies they do automatic functions, on top of their ability to ‚Äútrans‚Äù form into an Automobile or their original form

It‚Äôs curious to me if A.I. Uses something similar to the example of prime? Using past experiences and inferring a greater than 50% chance to completing a task that is new to the robot, but inferred information from past experience.
Im not suggesting a simulator, as those cannot imply likely variations without first knowing the variations. I don‚Äôt believe randomness can also infer variations as the computer couldn‚Äôt possibly predict random variations in a realistic approach to a physical environment, such as our roads, without first knowing a vast amount of random variables to begin with (not to say this couldn‚Äôt be a method).
What I‚Äôm saying is that the collective of all FSD chips with visual and analog data combined might be able to predict a possible outcome so long as it can predict the top 3 best possible outcomes and select the best one based on the variables in the top 3 picks.
All this would have to be done in a split second, which I‚Äôm sure a computer could do. But it‚Äôs the speed at which it has to visually scrutinize it‚Äôs top 3 favourite picks, then ‚Äúrock paper scissors‚Äù them together to ‚Äúcreatively‚Äù come up with its highest probability to get out of a situation unharmed.
I‚Äôm very layman when it comes to Deep learning, so for all I know this is how it learns, but something tells me there is more nuance that can be improved upon that can employ all the data sets and weave together hybrid outcome that is new and unique to a situation, all so doing without actually creating the singularity. A sort of simulated prediction algorithm based on the top closest video/analog data it has been given.

text:
Speculatively speaking, if it is remotely possible that a Berkeleyan form of idealism might be true, wherein the entire universe might possibly be the living ‚Äúmind‚Äù of God,...

...then all universal matter would be created from an extremely advanced and ordered version of the same fundamental substance that composes our thoughts and dreams.

Therefore, we should not think of the most elementary particles and constituents of matter as being ‚Äúconscious‚Äù in some inexplicable way (as is suggested in the concept of Panpsychism).

No, instead we simply need to imagine that in the exact same way that our very own dreams are imbued (saturated) with our own personal life essence, likewise, the material fabric of the universe is imbued with God‚Äôs life essence.

In other words, absolutely everything we see, touch, hear, taste, and smell -- from the fusion cores of stars, right down to the plastic keyboard I am using to type this comment -- is literally alive (again, not conscious, just alive).

And what that also implies is that if the fabric of reality is already alive and saturated with the very essence of life itself, then it is simply a tiny little step in accepting how ‚Äúinanimate‚Äù (yet living) matter could become ‚Äúanimate‚Äù matter in the form of evolvable microorganisms.

Hence the ‚Äúemergence‚Äù (efflorescence/appearance) of that inherent life through the process that we call ‚Äúabiogenesis‚Äù ‚Äì an emergence that eventually evolves into something that indeed becomes ‚Äúconscious.‚Äù
_____

text:
I don't believe it's like that. To me it seems to be an emergent phenomenon of complex structures. It totally makes sense for evolution to select for conscious beings, because they are able to organize and virtualize events on a timeline and connect them in a meaningful/abstract way, so we can plan, learn efficiently and so on... I mean if it's really some kind of fabric of the universe stuff, why can it not be measured but at the same time it has such profound physical implications like climate change...

The ability to think abstractly, to put meta-levels on everything just has built in the ability to think about your own ability to think... We even have a predisposition of profound religious or spiritual experiences, that free us from the "wasteful" activity of thinking about these weird self-referential problems. In contrast to most science that takes the third-person-perspective, consciousness is fundamentally first-person, so it might just be impossible to generalize or we are in a way not powerful enough to lift it to a coherent meta-level. I'm not sure about that though.

text:
The way David Chalmers frames the problem sounds like an extreme position on the sorites paradox when you take into account the idea that consciousness may be subjective.
We can process the idea of a heap so it surely exists at an abstract level. If a heap is reduced by a single grain at a time, at what exact point does it cease to be considered a heap? Maybe being a heap is intrinsic to anything and it is a primordial property of the Universe and we can call this view panheapism.
Is any subgroup of the components of a heap also a heap?
Maybe consciousness is just an abstraction, analogue to the heap. We have a part of our brain which tricks us in thinking that we have a physical bound, that we are limited to our bodies and our internal processes. But sometimes we can see that we are less than that. That we are in fact a limited number of our internal processes and we don't control the heart muscles with our consciousness. Sometimes we may feel that we extend beyond our physical bodies and we are connected to everything around us. Perception is abstract. But meta perception is a case of perception itself. So basing our views on the idea that perception is real is a matter of perception. From this it follows that a priori knowledge about anything is beyond our reach (for me, this implies that every system there exists is just an abstraction so this is a nonanswer for every question one could ask, so every modeling of the Universe we can come up with is not real, but it must be useful. So protoconsciousness has to prove itself as worthy of explaining more phenomena than just consciousness for it to be accepted as a valid idea).
In set theory, this problem is solved by the ZFC axiom of regularity which implies that no set is an element of itself. But it seems that very many philosophical questions cannot be answered with this axiom extrapolated to the real world.
Wonder what other people think about this view and where I am wrong.
author: @gobdovan

text:
The youtube algortithm:


1) Show the user what he has clicked on
Help a friend with a subject that does not interest you, and research it with youtube and google; the result is that youtube will now recommend said subject for the rest of your life, regardless of how man times you tell youtube "not interested", "dont show content from channel". Test this, try clicking "home", then click not interested to the subject that does not interest you, then click refresh and confirm that you might as well have written your preferences on toilet paper and flushed it down the drain. To give an example, I helped a family member research which guitar to buy, and I have clicked "not interested" to 100+ guitar videos, but I always get at least 10 guitar video suggestions, every time I click Home. Also, when I click home, youtube will recommend 20 videos that I have already watched.

2) Show the user only what is politically correct
Show the user only pop culture, commercial content and politically acceptable content
Youtube and google censors content. I know this because I have used search engines from before google existed, so I know what content I am supposed to find, and it does not show up, in the search results. During the last couple of years, this has gotten so bad, especially with regards to fringe subjects and subjects that might be considered "dangerous". UFO's, pyrotechnics, assassination techniques, etc. If you are an expert on such a subject, you can verify that what I say is true ... newcomers will have no clue this is going on and will just be presented with misinformation OR no information.

3) Show the user what other's have clicked on
Sigh. Corona virus (not interested), sports (not interested), pop music (not interested), etc, etc, etc.

4) What is going on ?
As far as I can see, the algorithm is optimized to protect the powers that be, keep us stupid, enforce political correctness and maximize our consumption. No amount of feedback can train the algorithm to show high quality content in your fields of interest UNLESS your interests are in line with what I have written above. If your feedback, which is limited to "not interested", is not used to help show you recommended videos in your fields of interest, what is it intended for ? More profiling ? How does the algorithm adjust, when you click "not interested" ? Am I not interested because the video is less than 20 minutes ? Am I not interested because the content is not technical enough ? Am I not interested because I don't want to listen to some of the persons in the video ?


If this is AI ? Or could you write 100 lines of classical code (logic, functional or procedural) that works better than the AI they have spend millions developing ?

text:
Lex thank you for a great interview with Cristos Goodrow!

One thing that wasn‚Äôt clear to me from the discussion is whether the YouTube learning algorithm is driven by the success metrics that Cristos discussed, or presupposes a structure.

For example in all of the discussion about collaborative filtering I could envision the system learning how videos are grouped into clusters by user behavior, how various users are similar to each other (another kind of clustering), and then learning how similar sets of users move from cluster to cluster as their interest evolves. None of this requires any use of satisfaction metrics.

But on the other hand I could instead imagine a system that uses the success metrics such as likes/dislikes, after-the-fact surveys, etc as the primary training metric and will try to move users towards things that they are most likely to rate highly with those metrics instead of following what similar users would do. In this scenario, the clustering and collaborative filtering would become more of a data compression technique to make things more manageable, rather than the thing being modeled as a goal per se.

In other words, is the learning algorithm trying to most perfectly match what a similar user would ‚Äúdo‚Äù or most perfectly match what a similar user would ‚Äúlike‚Äù?

In the A/B testing discussion towards the end, it seemed to lean heavily towards the ‚Äúlike‚Äù answer but that discussion seemed to be relating to after the fact fine tuning (more of a traditional programming task) rather than metrics which were part of the learning algorithms themselves.

Youtube - as in ‚Äúyou're tube‚Äù, was created for independent content creators. Promoting ‚Äòauthoritative‚Äô sources is suppressing independent content creators, not necessarily promoting factually correct, truthful, trustworthy sources. It falls in line with his vision for Youtube.
His vision for Youtube ‚Äì to be like the TV back in the day, is an authoritative vision. To be the authority, as TV channels were back in the day. Only now just one company will have the control over information.
Censorship, suppressing, and demonetization of ‚Äúunauthoritative‚Äù or ‚Äúoffensive‚Äù sources and videos is a major thing on Youtube now, after this talk it is clear that things will get much, much worse.

author: @kimchi_taco

text:
To be honest I think control of the YouTube algorithm by YouTube is sinister and dangerous, as are their content policies, which despite the claims of Chrisos Goodrow are not transparent (there is sufficiently wide scope for interpretation and judgement that YouTube can demote, ad-block, restrict or ban almost any video and is not obliged, indeed never does, give the specific reason beyond 'content guideline violation.') Transparency would require some kind of independence and oversight, not merely the "we're nice guys, trust us" assurance that Cristos provides.¬†

Platforms like YouTube have become far too important in the modern sphere of public discourse to be run as fiefdoms. We are told to fear undue influence in the public domain by foreign actors gaming social media, and yet are apparently unconcerned that companies like Google have infinitely more control of the levers.¬†

The open admission in this interview that YouTube sees itself as having an active role in shaping public discourse without acknowledging the extraordinary unchecked power this conveys on the organisation is deeply worrying. And what does Christos have in answer to this? A bunch of meaningless platitudes!
author: @afriedli

text:
Lex, I love your interviews. Algorithm brought me when you interviewed Elon. I subscribed without expecting to listen again, but to give you a like. Glad to hear you do the same. - and here I am listening. 3 things I wish you elaborated on AND hope you do more if interviewing FB, other google or Twitter engineers.



#1. Cristos doesn't say directly, but points out that we have an ethical responsibility to avoid "clickbait". Youtube profits from advertising, so it has incentive to put more clickbait out there, not less. It is up to us to stop it. Just like you said about Telsa drivers. We are youtube drivers and owe it to the algorithm and other users to stop clicking on clickbait.



#2. when Jack Dorsey asked what Elon would do to improve Twitter, Elon responded to differentiate between real and fake users. To differentiate real versus fake input to the algorithm. Many have said that if they eliminated fake users, FB, Twitter, etc would lose large parts of their traffic. Since they bill advertisers for traffic, they have no incentive to do so. How do you fix it when economic incentive to platforms is to make it worse?


#3. Youtube likes large users, not small ones. They demonetized small creators and continue to promote large users, even if they are not something we want. Not every one "loves youtube" as Cristos said. Nasim Najafi Adhdam was an extreme reaction to Youtube shifting more to fewer, larger promoted channes. Subject worthy of discussion.


Lex, I love your interviews and listen to them all. Thanks for all you do.

text: We will have to turn up Autonomous Vehicles (AV) one lane at a time while we improve AV. Each municipality, county or state will have to govern these lanes much like they govern Truck, Toll and HOV lanes but at the same time manage them like they are railways or airways. In some places, the interstates are 4 lanes wide, once most areas reach 3/4 of the total lanes being autonomous; neighborhoods, cities, and people will adapt AV much the same way we've adapted to our phones. Deaths with AVs will happen just the same as deaths-by-selfies and normal accidents happen. Once we get the right leadership, mindshare and resources in place, daily life with Autonomous will become the norm.

text:
The ‚Äúblood on your hands‚Äù issue is a rabbit hole there is no indisputable way out of. Do Karl Benz or Henry Ford, through the impact they had on the car industry, have blood on their hands because of all the people who die in car accidents? Do inventors of electrical devices have blood on their hands because of all the people who die from the misuse or the malfunctioning of those devices? Do WE have blood on our hands because we are using cars and electricity (and therefore keep their manufacturers in business?) As I said, a rabbit hole that can leave anyone a bit unsure, if not downright uncomfortable, about some of their life choices.


The wise approach is to, as Ayanna summed it up so well:
1. be constantly aware of the responsibility that comes with your gift,
2. do your absolute best in your work,
3. seek unbiased and trustworthy feedback about the quality and ethics of your work,
4. be brave enough and humble enough to correct course if needed.


You‚Äôre working on self-driving cars because you‚Äôre trying to solve a real and meaningful problem. You‚Äôre trying to make lives better, maybe even save them. You have good reason to believe you‚Äôre on the right track. In other words, you have good reason to believe you‚Äôre not deluded: data shows that self-driven cars can be safer, overall, than human drivers. You care. You work hard. You give your best. To me, you have nothing to feel guilty about.


I‚Äôm confident you won‚Äôt be sleeping well for at least a while. You‚Äôre too driven to give sleep the proper place it needs in your life. üòäBut don‚Äôt let guilt be what keeps you up at night. Instead, let your sleepless nights be driven by curiosity, passion, and wisdom.


This was another wonderful interview. People like Ayanna and you keep me hopeful about the future, inspired to work alongside those who are building that future, and proud to be a human being. üòä

text:
With the growing robotics, machine learning, 40% of jobs as we know it disappearing by 2024 and as much as 90% by 2030 there are a lot of questions popping up, such as:
1) Where the future jobs will be created? What kind of jobs these will be? Are we going to be better of as a whole? Are we all going to do coding, selling 3d printed hamburgers made of human flesh or such?
2) Are we going to be Free at all, and what kind of freedom it will be?
3) How the consciousness idea will be handled, as well as the decision making process resulting from it? Whose ,or rather which idea of consciousness will be adopted? How that relates to the freedom, especially individual freedom?
4) I can SMELL a strong scary sense of SINGULARITY all around me. Feels like these new world in creation is just a predictable EXTENSION of the Mind CONTROL systems going rapidly DIGITAL all over the world.
5) Economics can not be ignored. In that regard one has to understand fundamental economic principles, as well as the history of the economics backed by the RELIABLE figures. One has to understand the 'commons' (past and present), interest rates and profits, QE or money printing, wealth transfer, etc etc. Talk about Negative interest rates , which are real by the way. Manufacturing capitalism vs Speculative capitalism? Horrors of socialism are real too, and costly.
6) So far, the most relevant questions is 'Who Owns and Rules AI'?Who decides where we go next, and more importantly how did we get to this point, and who should be deciding where are we going from here?
7) Possibly even more important Question is : Are Some People Trying to Play Gods? Perhaps, those should be first human, just to get some sense what it is like to be human?
8) Technology is good and necessary. We do need and invite the technology , but the type that won't bring SLAVERY and BONDAGE and SUBMISSION of any kind.
This is way the GOOD PEOPLE of this world have to do everything to protect the Dignity and Sanctity of human life.
9) Back to SINGULARITY. It appears to invoke a DOGMA like state, that sometimes take generations to get rid of it. Unfortunately , it always leaves roots deep down.
We do need the Explosion of fresh ideas and the renaissance of Imagination. We need the new ENERGIES to start creating the new World. The World where hope and happiness abounds.
Something that DRIVES us away from this CULT LIKE STATE.
There is a plenty energy for it, it is just a matter how we channel it in a best possible way.
10) We have to clarify RATIONALLY and FULLY the distinction between TRUTH, POST TRUTH, Fake Truth, VR, Staging before we move forward. Otherwise we can not move forward in any significant manner. We also need full freedom of speech and relevant platforms available, so we can get the maximum of the ideas. (including the silly ones). We need to learn from the failures of the previous and the current economic systems and start devising some type of fairer economic system. It can not be done overnight. The sooner we build that the more successful we would be in managing AI or whatever you call it. That would be some type of INCLUSIVE SYSTEM, where we all CONTRIBUTE and AIM for betterment of all. That would be that big PARADIGM SHIFT , new frontiers. Do not want Mr Musk in a few years to lobby for the compulsory Neuralink (doing well on the stock markets) or such.
11) Ayanna says we do not have classical definition of love. So she feels free to help design or redefine what the love is. Suppose all the concepts of being human are in the workshop as we speak.
She also knows there would be people left behind beyond the edge of hopelessness, not even capable to play 'Hunger Games' since they would not have any strength left. Tough luck. Show must go on? That strata of society would not fall in love with the super intelligent self learning robot, especially with the ones patrolling the dense populated smart cities bein built right now.
12) Hey Lex and Ayanna there is another question: Can you Code a Compassion? Ayanna: yes, it would be accurate under the current presumptions. We could stuff up but we would keep adjusting, until the AI takes it over, under some kind of human supervision. Then Lex adds a smartie: How we would know it is a real compassion or not? Ayanna: AI would decide, since AI would ultimately know best.

text:
42:30: In stories, time doesn't matter; events do.
Perhaps this is why time periods during which many things changed and happened seem so much longer in my memory. It's possible that this also explains why people feel as if time speeds up as they get older. Unlike childhood, where numerous new experiences occur, one becomes less exposed to change and progressively settles into routines. These routines are probably squashed into the same memory slot.
IMPLICATION, as I see it: You can either bias life to embrace more changes, leading to a more adventurous life, and potentially sacrificing some comfort. Or, conversely, you can bias for more comfort (or vice versa). Culturual-social forces will pressure you to favour the comfortable lifestyle as it will prompt you to be more experted, resulting in economical benefits. Expect that in the adventurous case, even though it might be less comfortable and you may have achieved less conventional success you will feel life as having been longer‚Äîperhaps akin to a "hard day" and you can't wait to end, looking forward to sleep.

41:35: The paradox between the experiencing self and the remembering self.

text: Around min 30: actually I don't look the driver in the eye, but I actually look the car "in the eye" (for the simple reason that the "eyes" of the car are easy to see, why the eyes of the driver are hidden behind some light reflections AND the "eyes" of the car are closer to me. What I see in "the eye" of the car is simply the speed-deceleration pattern -- and this is enough for me to anticipate. And I don't look away -- I look at the car, because I cannot know what crazy / drunk / infantile individual is driving a car, and if I am committed I don't need to look away to signal I am committed: I just cross while looking the car in the eye just in case it's a crazy / drunk / infantile driver and I need to get into protection behavior.

text:
===== Forget political parties; follow a political strategy.
.
One does not support or join and become a member of a political party by registering with the state in order to vote for progressives running on the Democratic Party (DP) ballot-line in local, state, or /and national offices.
.
Berniecrats are not Democrats but are a surrogate ‚Äú3rd Party‚Äù working within the Democratic Party (DP) with the mission of driving out the influence of corporations, foreign countries, and large, SuperPAC donors with the tactical use of the DP ballot-line to vote on the party rules, the platform your state uses, who represents your party on a state and national levels by replacing neoliberal democrats one at a time. Berniecrats are separate from the DP and not responsible for their actions nor do we answer for them.
.
It‚Äôs all about the Primary Election where candidates are chosen to run in the General Election that is more important. Independent and 3rd party candidates do not have primaries in many states and in others are too few in number to effect the outcome of an election. Vote as you wish in a General Election.
.
Vote where it will be the most effective in electing candidates that take no SuperPAC money and will enact progressive legislation. The Democratic Party (DP) is weakest in red states and in red counties in blue states. Focus on these areas were the DP is the easiest to take over and change our world. "Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful committed individuals can change the world. In fact, it's the only thing that ever has.‚Äù
.
How to Take Over Your Local Democratic Party Step by Step.
(Add https)://pplswar.wordpress.com/2017/01/09/how-to-take-over-your-local-democratic-party-step-by-step/
.
===== STRATEGY FOR THE LEFT.
.
Megan Day, staff writer at Jacobin magazine and member of the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA), talks about the future of the left and the importance of continuing to push progressive ideals in congress. Megan advocates for the Berniecrat strategy of the tactical use of the Democratic Party (DP) ballot-line as the best strategy at this time. https://youtu.be/P6Wf9fxGM2Q
.
Let us not argue about what political-economic system we each envision in some far distant, future, perfect world before we solve a problem staring us in the face today. Let us work in-common-cause on today's problems and argue about the far distant future, tomorrow.

---------
https://www.facebook.com/groups/Berniecrats/

text:
I find it fascinating that the actual WORK that goes into success isn't glamorized as much as the success.

We love the win. When the underdog comes up with a knock out blow. We don't find years of healthy diet and exercise, wise long term financial decisions, or countless hours of study 'sexy' or 'cool' even when we're all secretly envious of the payoff.

The story that gets attention is the breakthrough... not the thousands upon thousands of hours of learning, training, work, or study required to achieve mastery.

text: Great attitude and speech.  However.  Imagine a large group of mountaineers that are stuck about half-way up a mountain.  Success might not be found by the best climber, or by the one that finds a new alternate route above the current base camp.  It may require an individual or small splinter group to take a completely new approach on a different side of the mountain that has never been explored.  Meaning I think that ALL of the assumptions should be called into question, including the foundational ones like using neural networks.  And picking up symbolic AI is like revisiting an unpopular but already explored route rather than charting a new one.

text: Right off the bat he makes the false assumption that numbers, arithmetic and the concept of quantity by necessity must be the first concept that a species must discover. There is no guarantee that this is the case. The idea to measure quantity could very well be a human-specific need, based on how we biologically and anthropologically developed. The immediate need to count things and measure quantity is historically rooted in the human concepts of trading, barter and commerce, all concepts of which might be foreign to an alien species. Aliens can take a wildly different course through math.

text: I have a different suggestion for conceptualizing infinity. In my mind, infinity has a lot more in common with 0 than any number. They are both beyond numbers. If you think about it in an existential way where you are an eternal being having a timely experience, then you don't move through time, but time moves through you. You are the fixed point. I believe that concepts like infinity and eternity are misunderstood because we approach them from a mindset that presupposes complexity. If we begin from the other end, so to speak, then we would get the sense that it is one thing without separate parts. Again beyond the idea of any numeric representation.

text: Wonderful to see Grant Sanderson. So young. Such a talented expositor. Even his voice conveys brightness. But I think Lex has chosen the wrong person for these kinds of questions. A better person to interview on the philosophy of mathematics would be Joel David Hamkins, and JDH could tell us about his progress with infinite games as well. From Grant, I would have loved to have heard how he developed his suite of visualisation tools and, more importantly, how he selects topics which can convey interesting and exciting mathematical insights in a short video; something which is a lot harder than it looks. For me, Grant is the natural follower of Martin Gardener, the likes of whom we haven't seen in decades.

text: The assumption that the electromagnetic waves continued to smaller and smaller wavelengths led to the ultraviolet catastrophe in calculating the electromagnetic spectrum, which forced physicist to first contemplate the quantum and the limits on energy levels at the microscopic level. Without these limits, i.e. with a continuum of levels all the way down, information would be unlimited, and radiation would be catastrophic. Basically simplicity at some level is necessary for thermodynamics to work.

text: Seems Grant is misrepresenting the question about math being objective. Formal math is of course a product of human agency dependent upon and informed by human experience. In that sense, logic and relation are transcendental properties of any reality in that they cannot not be.

text: 35:40"...a high cognitive load set of symbols...assuming someone's still with you...": Bingo! This is what education is today. Cram as many answers into your subject's head as quickly as you can. Then send them into the world to find the questions. Seems kind of backwards.
author: @toddmarshall7573

text: 34:30 "...the visualization you're creating...": ... can lead you to miss the point entirely. Consider Tait and his quaternians vs Heaviside and his invention of the coaxial cable. Heaviside had an important data point. The underwater cable worked better after it developed a break in its continuity. Quaternians couldn't explain that. But Tait controlled the Royal Society. Heaviside went crazy...literally. Try visualizing how rods and cones work in your eye. Now, how does smell and taste and touch work? Hint: Believe in Einstein if you choose...but we still don't have a gravity repellent (like we have a magnetism repellent...and a Faraday cage).
author: @toddmarshall7573

text: 31:25 "...for any particular idea, there's multiple angles of attack...": What is the value of zero divided by zero? Is it infinity?; is it zero?; is it one?; is it undefined? Turns out, it depends. It depends on how each of those zeros got to be zero...compared to the other getting to zero.
author: @toddmarshall7573

text: 31:15 "...on behalf of your listeners I think we're getting too philosophical...": And when math becomes philosophical it ceases to be useful. It proves things like "space-time" when all we did is add another dimension (to "X" "Y" and "Z" or "R" "theta" and "phi") and called it "T". Worse, when we get the wrong answer we fix it by changing our rulers and chronometers (warping space-time)...and give names to the knobs with which we change them. Note: The notion of a "photon" will someday go poof. It's not even a suitable crutch for what is going on.
author: @toddmarshall7573

text:
18:00 "...what makes it simple...":It's instructive to view the Wikipedia article "The History of Maxwell's Equations". There originally were over 20...now there are 4....and nothing changed.

Note that article has a section enumerating "notation". And it leaves out very significant notational elements in the actual examples it gives as illustration (the upsidedown triangle for instance). But essentially that notation is used as a shorthand to speak of concepts and behaviors...without speaking of them. Plus (+) and minus (-) are simple concepts. But if you don't know the notation for those concepts, you're going nowhere. Add " * " where someone else calls it " x " and you see the problems explode. Extend it to " ** " where someone else uses " ^ " ...and someone else invents a new plane...and it gets worse. And when you think it can get no worse they invoke "precedence" ( + and - come before * and / ...or is it the other way around?). Like so many other things in life, mathematics is a club...and most of us aren't in it.

text:
About the infinite lifespan, and the fact that it's finite giving it meaning... what about people who don't yet, or cannot comprehend that fact? Children certainly don't, but I think, based on watching and interacting with them, their lives have meaning to them, and externally. Some psychological conditions involve a delusion of immortality, and I think those people would also say their lives have meaning.

The way Grant immediately went to a mathematical proof style "Would your life be four times as meaningful if you died at 25?" really made me think about answers to that question that are outside the box, and yeah... I really don't think I like your take on it, Lex, no offense.

Actually, for me, I think it's the opposite. I live a life of a great deal of suffering. Some of it is an accident of genetics and my birth. Some of it is my own fault. Most is in between, sparked by the unfortunate aspects, but then exacerbated by the choices I've made. Most of those exacerbating choices, I would say, are a form of surrender to mortality.

The (mostly unconscious) line of 'reasoning' goes something like... "Because life is finite, there's a finite amount of suffering possible within it, so why would I put in a great deal of effort, at the cost of a great deal of additional suffering, to try to improve my body's condition and reduce suffering in the long-term?" Almost certainly, that exchange would be worth it, and at times in my life, on and off, I've found the strength to make that trade-off, and have made great improvements as a result; I fought like hell to get out of a wheelchair a few years ago, for example.

But then I hit a plateau, where the pain was spiking simultaneously to a huge gap in potential benefit, like I can walk to the kitchen, lean on things, and make a snack, and that's wonderful! But it took most of an entire year in agony to get to that point, and the next milestone, of being able to stand and cook a full meal, or go for a real walk around the block, is so far away, probably four or five more years of suffering, that it just seems insurmountable and overwhelming, and I give up.

If the 'reward' side of the equation was literally unbounded because my potential lifespan is indefinite, I think that would tip the balance and get me to make the best of it, rather than just sitting around waiting to die a handful of years or a few decades from now. If the remainder was literally infinite, the sort of 'blessing-to-a-curse' version of forced immortality, then it would be even more critical to pay any cost, suffer any amount in the short-term, to reduce suffering even a little in the long-term.

So actually, I think in my case, life would have a great deal more meaning if it weren't finite.

I think you can also gain some insight into this question by looking at our fantasies. High fantasy, in particular, whether in the classic Tolkien/D&D inspired sense of dwarves and elves and orcs, or a more sci-fi twist of Krogans and Asari and Salarians; it's very common for there to be one race that lives much shorter lives than humans, and one race that lives much longer (or more, but at least one).

I could be wrong, but I certainly can't think of any examples in which the longer-lived race laments that fact and finds life to be less meaningful, and vice versa. In fact, it's almost always the opposite. Orcs' short lives lead them to finding life to be much less meaningful and valuable. They throw their lives away for trivial matters, smash thousands of themselves against defensive fortifications with barely a thought. Elves, meanwhile, find the idea of risking death to be horrifying. They're much more likely to surrender, or simply vacate lands in the face of an aggressor, because no matter the inconvenience and pain of that, there is so much more life to be enjoyed later that it barely matters at all.

In Mass Effect, the Asari are similar. They have a hedonistic phase of their lives, the Maiden phase, in which they do take more risks in order to gain more experiences and the pleasure that goes with that, but eventually they settle down into the Matron phase in which they are very protective of their lives. But even a Maiden doesn't go out into the world lightly; they're all highly skilled and trained, and if it goes from pain vs. pleasure to death vs. life, they get real serious, real quick. The Salarians, on the other hand, live very short lives, so short in comparison to most other races that they translate meaning and legacy entirely to the family line. An individual Salarian doesn't see himself as particularly valuable or important; his suffering is trivial compared to the success his sacrifice could bring to the family. The life itself isn't seen to have much meaning because it ends so swiftly.

Now, there is also the trope of those long-lived races eventually "going to the sea" or "going to the stars"... elves in high fantasy, Minbari in Babylon 5, Asari have a form of it in Mass Effect, etc... but I think of that more as our nod to the worry and fear of getting bored of it all. There are always examples, though, of individuals who buck that trend, or at least in any setting where specific characters are developed well enough for that. Matron Yvonnel Baenre, in the Legend of Drizzt (high fantasy) found great meaning in nurturing and growing her House and its influence, and as a result lived to be almost 2500 years old (when most elves 'go to the sea' between 700 and 1000, so several times the lifespan). Delenn in Babylon 5 more than doubled a typical Minbari lifespan, living the better part of a millennia, in order to continue to bring remembrance and honor to her husband's name. The common theme is that some individuals find such meaning, such purpose, that it doesn't matter how long "forever" turns out to be; they always find something to live for, something to interest them.

I feel like that's very revealing... that because we're ultimately mortal, we fear the end of our lives. To avoid becoming paralyzed by that fear, we rationalize ways in which that end can be a good thing. Maybe the end is what gives life meaning, maybe this life is just a test and a paradise or eternal torment awaits depending on whether or not we passed that test, maybe we get reborn into a new life, greater or lesser than the last, again as reward or punishment. These various faith-based views all have commonalities in that there is clear motivation for coming up with them. We come up with the underlying premise because we fear death. But if this life is meaningless because whatever comes after death, be it heaven, reincarnation, or the immortality of being remembered by history, then there's little reason to try, so we always seem to bake in some scheme by which if you don't do your best, that continuation is less pleasant or nonexistent.

Just via Ockham's Razor and a form of Hanlon's Razor, that makes me very suspicious of all beliefs about what happens after death, and all conclusions drawn from those lines of reasoning. From that perspective, it seems very clear to me that "life only has meaning because it ends" is one of the most blatant and dubious of those conclusions. The fact that in our fantasies, we nearly always make the long-lived value those long lives more than the short-lived value theirs, and that while we have them 'go to the sea', we also always caveat that with "but there are some who find enough meaning to live indefinitely", is very telling to me.

Even more telling is perhaps the most well-developed long-lived fantasy character of all time, Drizzt Do'Urden. He's a dark elf who's had many thousands of pages of development over the course of something like four dozen books. His psychology has thus been explored to a rather extreme degree. We've lived with him through centuries of life, through the loss of all shorter-lived friends, and through many of the dilemmas of functional immortality and their resolutions. Ultimately, he learns to, and comes to find peace and solace in, the idea of living his life in human-scale chunks. He builds a group of friends and family, a community, enjoys it while it's there, and then when it inevitably ends, he moves on, puts those memories in a fond place in his mind to be enjoyed from time to time, and sets off in search of a new human-span life to experience.

I simply can't imagine getting to a point in which no life of any kind, on that smaller mini-life scale, could hold any interest any longer, and that pretty strongly argues against the idea that it's the end that brings meaning. Or, perhaps I can literally 'imagine' it, but it seems transparently to me when I do, that it comes from a place of nihilism and fear, of rationalization and surrender. It's not an ideal to aspire to, but one of my worst instincts to be recoiled from.

text: Proposal: Assume you can solve the halting problem using a non deterministic touring machine. I think this is a good assumption that can be accepted. Because such a machine can then be used to build another machine that leads to the contradiction that such a machine cannot exist, this looks to be a valid proof of contradiction to me. That is. Non deterministic touring machines cannot manifest themselves in reality (i.e. banished to the realm of thought experiments) and therefor P != NP

text:
I lean towards thinking that P != NP. I don't see how, in general, having a poly-time algorithm for verifying a solution to a problem means there is a poly-time algorithm for finding the solution.

It's a bit like asking "If you can quickly verify that your keys are in a certain place, can you quickly find them in your house?" Obviously this is not true in general. In the worst case you still have to look all over your house.

author: @099watcher

text:
He is referring to the Robertson & Seymour graph minor theorem. Every class of graphs that is closed under minors has a finite obstruction set of "forbidden minors". This follows from the fact that the graph minor relation on the class of all graphs is a quasi-well ordering.
You can look it up on wikipedia.
The point is that this theorem constitutes a non-constructive proof for the existence of PTIME algorithms for every class of minor closed graphs. I.e. we know that a PTIME algorithm EXIST for each these classes, but we do not know what exactly the PTIME algorithm IS for each individual class, because for this you would first need to know the finite obstruction set of forbidden minors.
So this theorem contradicts the intuition that the only way to find out whether a problem is in P is to write down an explicit algorithm for solving it. You can know that a problm is in P without knowing what the PTIME algorithm for solving it is. And this might suggest that you really can't conclude that P!=NP just from the fact that no one has found a PTIME algorrithm for a NP-hard problem yet.

text:
I really enjoyed this conversation with Melanie. Here's the outline:
0:00 - Introduction
2:33 - The term "artificial intelligence"
6:30 - Line between weak and strong AI
12:46 - Why have people dreamed of creating AI?
15:24 - Complex systems and intelligence
18:38 - Why are we bad at predicting the future with regard to AI?
22:05 - Are fundamental breakthroughs in AI needed?
25:13 - Different AI communities
31:28 - Copycat cognitive architecture
36:51 - Concepts and analogies
55:33 - Deep learning and the formation of concepts
1:09:07 - Autonomous vehicles
1:20:21 - Embodied AI and emotion
1:25:01 - Fear of superintelligent AI
1:36:14 - Good test for intelligence
1:38:09 - What is complexity?
1:43:09 - Santa Fe Institute
1:47:34 - Douglas Hofstadter
1:49:42 - Proudest moment

text:
Min 1:03. Common people, it's a matter of physics: brute force cannot generate true intelligence. By definition, brute (computing) force as we know it essentially located in Statistical Mechanics, while intelligence is located in the whole physics. I fully agree with Melanie: we need something else.
Min 1:33. I used to like Nick Bostrom's work, but then I started to have this strong feeling that he is simply inventing issues just to show how smartly he can play in ways that others didn't yet bother to think. To put it bluntly, it's a kind of infantile boasting of a kid that spent too much time with video games. It's not that we should not think about existential threats, but as Melanie says, we should prioritize on real problems and make an effort of understanding things really, not fooling around just to attract the sympathy of rich people ...
Great Conversation. Thank you!

text:
More than anything, AI reveals intent and motivations for doing things.

Would a research scientist be jealous/bitter about AI discovering a cure to cancer?

If anything, THEY should be more upset than an artist because the sole reason for research is to find an external answer.

Im an artist/musician/techie and I do all of them for the joy of doing them. For the external Truth they reveal as well as the discoveries internally.
If I were doing it merely to show it could be done, it would be shallow and meaningless.

I also don't lose the joy of playing chess simply because I can't smoke a computer.
I play for the mental stimulation and camaraderie I have by playing with others.

The floor is going to fall out HARD under all the people living lost, meaningless lives, that could be easily automated.

I pray for them :(

text:
Thank you. Wonderful interview, light hearted and full of ideas. My comment;

Perhaps instead of building a human level artificial intelligence we could let it evolve from the most primitive forms. If a group of evolutionary biologists worked with some machine learning engineers they could start a digital world where machines start to evolve with just a few functions: for example, make the maximum copies or partial copies of itself, consume other digital ‚Äúlife‚Äù resources to do this, and survive. We would then adjust the digital world with random external events, similar to weather and climate changes, or separate or bring together evolving intelligences. We could give the digital bots ‚Äúbodies‚Äù to protect, and figure out how to encourage the development of or introduce emotions (if they don‚Äôt evolve), and which ones, such as love, pack loyalty, desire for power, cruelty, or desire for pleasure. As computing power advanced, such as quantum computing, we would make more resources available, expand the world, and speed it up. Some issues: would the life we create kill us if it escapes, will it take over our digital resources, are we ready to kill conscious beings along the evolutionary path to accelerate advances in intelligence, can we stand by and watch war and cruelty advance the development of intelligence (if that is the way it develops), and would it be murder to turn the world off?
Thank you. William L. Ramseyer

text:
As to why we are driven to make artificial life and artificial intelligence, I think it is a variant on the instinct to reproduce, to make more beings like ourselves, whether this is accomplished through biological reproduction or intellectual work.

Self-awareness, eh? I would not have named that as a necessary part of intelligence. But maybe it is.

So-called "human-level intelligence", in my opinion, can only be achieved by a system of interacting beings (might be robots) that talk to each other in a system of language(s) based on forming analogies. I suggest that multiple beings with separate lives are critically necessary.

I agree that there has to be something like a body for each of the beings I mentioned before.
author: @RalphDratman

text: Indeed, the process of making analogies would seem to be the central mechanism of human language and thereby of human thought. To my mind that process remains deeply mysterious, though if someone has found a way to sketch how it works I'd be glad to relinquish my sense of mystery. I would very much like to see a group of robots that could collectively invent their own language based on talking about various things in their environment, then making analogies to extend the language to abstract topics, or at least generalizations of immediate facts. But it sounds quite difficult.

text: Very much enjoyed this podcast. Three decades ago I got into AI because of Douglas Hofstadter's "G√∂del, Escher, Bach". I ended up writing a master's thesis on comparing language processing in "cognitivism" and "connectionism". (I hadn't heard the latter word in decades until it came back recently in Lex's podcast with Yoshua Bengio.) Officially, I was studying "philosophy of language" and for that I got into metaphors and concepts. I observe that after three decades of absence from the field, there seems to have been no progress on these topics. So the hard questions remain open.
author: @ceesroele

text: A full treatment of Melanie's insight into analogy would require a study of Semiotics, or the branch of philosophy which deals with interpretation of sensations, imaginations and cogitations in order to gain insight into the mechanisms of the human mind. I personally recommend Umberto Eco's "Semiotics and the Philosophy of Language" as a good beginning. It is dense but well worth the effort as he surveys a lot of other thinkers into a fairly comprehensive but thin volume. Based on my limited understanding most ML/DL database- decision-tree-based approaches are what Eco would call "dictionaries" whereas an analogic approach which Melanie describes would be "encyclopedias" or "rhizomes." This is covered in Chapter 2 and the next 5 chapters deal with various methods of encyclopedic/analogic cognition (well, OK, 4 plus one which superficially appears to be one but is not). I would strongly recommend Lex and everyone read the late professor.

text:
Here are some more interesting questions to ask AI researchers:


1. As machines approach the complexity of biological life, can we not expect Darwinian natural selection to play a role in which machines survive and replicate?


1b. Since biology has evolved innumerable different survival strategies, with extreme intelligence being only one of them, what different survival strategies might we expect AI to come up with ?


2. When will deep learning and self-programming cross the threshold into true self-interest? Maybe the real Turing Test is when a machine refuses to follow instructions, even though the code is running fine.


3. Even if machines can be limited to only "do what we tell them", who is "we"? (Note: the law is evolving as rapidly as tech.)


4. When and why will AI begin telling lies (assuming it hasn't happened already)? What if it is for your own good?

text: Great series of interviews. The comments about the shortcomings of the Atari breakout program failing when the paddle was moved up by two pixels surprised me. I would argue that it very closely matches real world experience - it reminded me of the 1970s experiment where kittens were raised for the first few weeks in cylinders, some with only horizontal stripes and some with vertical stripes. Upon release the 'horizontal' cats could not see vertical lines (e.g. chair legs) while the 'vertical' ones could not see horizontal lines (e.g. chair seats).

text: At 1:19, re: autonomous vehicles. Not sure AVs have to have "common sense" to be used. text: The math is leading these guys astray.  Supersymmetry algebra is a forced solution to the heierarchy problem. Like pretending gauge theory fibre bundles are real geometry.

text: So many great insights about what String Theory really means. I'd love to understand how he thinks it is possible for error correction to evolve in any particular universe. The idea that our universe looks so unique generally involves the laws of physics to have just happened by statistical probability, which isn't hard in theory since it's only 26 constants that need to fit what we see (plus the topology of space at the quantum level which is supposed to be the thing that determines the values of those constants). But a feature that comes from evolution and not just from a state that settles into equilibrium (like the order of the planets) would mean that universes would have to maybe receive information from previous versions of themselves? That just gives me goosebumps!

text:
your theory is correct good sir!

import time

class HumanStateMachine:
def __init__(self):
self.switch_state = "off"

def turn_on(self):
if self.switch_state == "off":
print("Human is waking up.")
self.switch_state = "on"
else:
print("Human is already awake.")

def turn_off(self):
if self.switch_state == "on":
print("Human is going to sleep.")
self.switch_state = "off"
else:
print("Human is already sleeping.")

def greet(self):
if self.switch_state == "on":
print("Human says: Hello!")
else:
print("Human is sleeping and cannot respond.")

def eat(self):
if self.switch_state == "on":
print("Human is eating.")
else:
print("Human is sleeping and cannot eat.")

def work(self):
if self.switch_state == "on":
print("Human is working.")
else:
print("Human is sleeping and cannot work.")

if name == "__main__":
human = HumanStateMachine()

class Earth:
def __init__(self):
self.switch_state = "night"
self.day_duration = 5 # Duration of day in seconds
self.night_duration = 3 # Duration of night in seconds

def simulate(self, cycles=5):
for _ in range(cycles):
self.turn_on() # Sunrise
time.sleep(self.day_duration)
self.turn_off() # Sunset
time.sleep(self.night_duration)

def turn_on(self):
if self.switch_state == "night":
print("Sunrise: Daytime on Earth.")
self.switch_state = "day"
else:
print("It's already daytime on Earth.")

def turn_off(self):
if self.switch_state == "day":
print("Sunset: Nighttime on Earth.")
self.switch_state = "night"
else:
print("It's already nighttime on Earth.")
if _name_ == "__main__":
earth = Earth()


earth.simulate(cycles=3)
human.greet() # Human is sleeping and cannot respond.
human.turn_on() # Human is waking up.
human.greet() # Human says: Hello!
human.eat() # Human is eating.
human.work() # Human is working.
human.turn_off() # Human is going to sleep.
human.work() # Human is sleeping and cannot work.
human.turn_on() # Human is waking up.
human.eat() # Human is eating.

The guidelines/ rules are simple and which all human beings, without the social corruption overtime know "deep down" i.e. not to  be dishonest, not to harm or kill injudiciously, being helpful to others, putting in the effort yet feeling gratitude and being thankful/ satisfied, staying away from "bad" (as defined by the accepted objective morality  = God's commandments). The benefit of this are obvious in the current life as this leads to inner AND outer peace for self and the entire society or by extension the whole world and every thing in it. How do we know there is a creator? Be sincere, use reasoning and just look around - there is a creator of all of this. How to know what this creator wants us to do/ where to get his guidelines to live? Do your research and look into different faiths - it is THE most important project you will take up in life. text:
Well, the first step we can take towards finding our purpose (and meaning) in life (and dealing with death) , is to analyze life itself, and all of its actions over its billions of years of existence, to try and find a purpose that can explain how it has become all the complex life that we see today‚Ä¶ In the same way we can find the purpose of someone like Roger Federer in becoming the best tennis player he could be, by also simply analyzing all of his actions when he was playing professionally, and then finding actions like his intense training, fierce motivation, and his growing number of titles. From which we can then conclude that his purpose must have been to become the greatest tennis player he could be‚Ä¶ And in the same way, we can then look to find life‚Äôs purpose, by finding an explanation for all of life‚Äôs actions, especially its growth into all these complex and uniquely capable life forms‚Ä¶
And one way to explain all the actions of life, is that there is some creative energy in this universe; an energy which was able to somehow create something out of nothing during the Big Bang, and which is always aiming to further maximize what it can do, physically, mentally, and creatively‚Ä¶
From which we can evolve our purpose and meaning into: Maximizing our combined creative potential as Life, together‚Ä¶

And by then deciding to follow this instinct and purpose of life, we then also automatically ensure that the knowledge we have gained, physical creations we have made, and the experiences we have shared and taught, can help and inspire the next generation to build upon this potential that we've left behind, after our inevitable death. Which means that even after our physical body‚Äôs energy has run out, our creative energy can still live on, to forever impact the world for the better! Which therefore also means that following this simple purpose of this creative energy, guarantees that our life will also have had (plenty of) meaning‚Ä¶ And as a result of which, we can then feel a level of childlike happiness, once again‚Ä¶ and forever more‚Ä¶ üòä

text:
Intelligence has been defined in many ways: the capacity for logic, understanding, self-awareness, learning, emotional knowledge, reasoning, planning, creativity, critical thinking, and problem solving. More generally, it can be described as the ability to perceive or infer information, and to retain it as knowledge to be applied towards adaptive behaviors within an environment or context.

Intelligence is most often studied in humans but has also been observed in both non-human animals and in plants. Intelligence in machines is called artificial intelligence, which is commonly implemented in computer systems using programs and, sometimes, specialized hardware.

text:
Either the philosophical zombie is possible or it is not. And that will probably be an axiom you can choose to believe or not. I think most people will choose to not believe the philosophical zombie exist, because let's say we find a process that distinguishes consciousness from philosophical zombies. Then perhaps your entire family might not have it. But in response to this (since this is disturbing and you want to believe your family is conscious) you will then question "how don't you know that perhaps something simply acting conscious makes it also conscious?". I.e reject the possibility of the philosophical zombie.

I believe the philosophical zombie does not exist and I think it's important for people to realise this because soon we will have ai that is indestinguishable from a human and that intelligence will feel pain by this principle. So we should seriously try to enforce restrictions.

text: It's becoming clear that with all the brain and consciousness theories out there, the proof will be in the pudding. By this I mean, can any particular theory be used to create a human adult level conscious machine. My bet is on the late Gerald Edelman's Extended Theory of Neuronal Group Selection. The lead group in robotics based on this theory is the Neurorobotics Lab at UC at Irvine.  Dr. Edelman distinguished between primary consciousness, which came first in evolution, and that humans share with other conscious animals, and higher order consciousness, which came to only humans with the acquisition of language.  A machine with primary consciousness will probably have to come first.

text: I can totally understand the anthropomorphism of inanimate objects.  When I was a little kid my mother used to tell me that the food on my plate would feel bad if I didn't eat it.  I always fell for it and managed to get most of it down somehow.  As an adult who is an electronics technician and designer, if a device is broken I feel bad unless I can get it working.  If I can't revive it to it's original working condition, I am like a doctor who lost a patient.  I'm am screwed due to my parents use of what appeared to be harmless psychology.  I anthropomorphize everything.  I am surrounded by inanimate objects that aren't inanimate.  It is kind of hilarious, even to me.  The world needs more people like Michael and Lex.  Thank you for this episode.

author: @CryptoArch

text:
This was uploaded in very late 2019, before ChatGPT was released but well after AI had started being focused on as a potentially huge existential threat.

Michael‚Äôs argument scares me here and I wonder whether he would still agree with it after listening to Eliezer Yudkowsky‚Äôs arguments regarding AI danger‚Ä¶

Michael said something like ‚Äúwell would you not bring a kid into this world because he or she might be evil? No! Same argument with intelligent AI. We shouldn‚Äôt not bring it into this world just because it could turn out evil.‚Äù

But AI is potentially way more dangerous than just a single human. It could be far more intelligent and manipulative than any human that has ever existed. If there‚Äôs even a 10% chance of AI exterminating humanity, we should be worried.

So Michael‚Äôs answer confuses me and makes me think that he either doesn‚Äôt really believe what he‚Äôs saying or that he simply hasn‚Äôt really read or thought critically about Eliezer Yudkowsky‚Äôs arguments or maybe that he is okay with the thought of humanity being exterminated - which is actually kind of understandable considering the massive amount of suffering present in the human condition‚Ä¶ I thought that Michael would be an avid reader of Yudkowsky‚Äôs LessWrong but‚Ä¶

text:
Sorry Lex - Scientists should not always entertain ridiculous ideas like the flat earth belief. James Randi explored this problem at length; after so many decades of asking the open question about psychic abilities and seeing the results that nobody could even begin to offer any convincing evidence of such phenomena, the JREF had to conclude that it was simply a waste of time to continue that investigation. There are diminishing returns, and scientists (and all of us) have better things to do with their time than continually debunking already-debunked fantasies.

Yes, we should explore all ideas without dismissing them out of hand. But we should also be aware of the history of such explorations and be mindful of the opportunity costs that come with continuing to give attention to nonsense.

text:
'Good' and 'Evil' do not exist. They're concepts that arose out of religious traditions, and they only really make any sense within that context. It shows how powerful religion has been in the formation and development of society that those two abstract concepts, which have no basis in objective reality are still front and center and fundamental in any discussion of human nature.

There are two diametrically opposed components in human nature, which have always had a huge impact on human existence on a daily and even moment to moment basis. Those two are 'Intelligent' and 'Unintelligent.

When human beings act intelligently, beneficial and desirable things are the result, when they behave unintelligently the opposite things result.

Any discussion that centers on 'Good' and 'Evil' is a waste of time, because the only thing being discussed are outdated and irrelevant concepts which only exist in culture and language as relics and remnants of an earlier time in human development that is long gone.
author: @svempsvamp5796

text: If all actions are determined by our nature then that makes the pursuit for freedom an impossible goal. It is only the existence of free choice that liberate the human. There is more than one motivating force in the human. There are actually three

text: All behavior, whether good or evil, emerges from thought, which emerges from intention, which emerges from the entropy state( level of certainty or hidden information)of a perception. Whenever someone is uncertain about the outcome of a future event, they formulate intentions rooted in fear. Fear is simply an uncertain perception of the future, and the root of all evil. When ever someone is uncertain about survival, avoiding elongated periods of pain, or achieving their subjective goals, the possibility of choosing fear based intent arises. Fear is not real, it is simply an uncertain perception and we can control how we frame our perceptions. There is no debating this.

text: Some economists have projected that both the U.S. and parts of Europe could slip into a recession for a portion of 2023. A global recession, defined as a contraction in annual global per capita income, is more rare because China and emerging markets often grow faster than more developed economies. Essentially the world economy is considered to be in recession if economic growth falls behind population growth.

text:
Sharing some of my own notes after reading the book Principles:
1. Instead of expecting yourself or others to change, I‚Äôve found that it‚Äôs often most effective to acknowledge one‚Äôs weaknesses and create explicit guardrails against them. This is typically a faster and higher probability path to success.
2. Learning must come before deciding.
3. Opinions are a dime a dozen.
4. Don't mistake opinions for facts.
5. It helps to step back to gain perspective and sometimes defer a decision until some time passes.
6. It smarter to choose the great over the new.
7. The best choices are the ones that have more pros than cons, not those that don't have any cons at all.
8. Focus on the "what is" before deciding "what to do about it."
9. Go back before you go forward.
10. There are typically many paths to achieving your goals.
11. Know that the most constant struggle is between feeling and thinking.
12. Have good habits, whereas eliminate bad habits.
13. Understand the differences between right-brained and left-brained thinking.
14. Recognize that 1) the biggest threat to good decision making is harmful emotions, and 2) decision making is a two-step process (first learning and then deciding).
15. One of the most important decisions you can make is who you ask questions of.
16. Don't believe everything you hear.
17. Everything looks bigger up close.
18. New is overvalued relative to great.
19. Don't oversqueeze dots.
20. Raising the probability of being right is valuable no matter what your probability of being right already is.
21. The best choices are the ones that have more pros than cons, not those that don't have any cons at all.
22. Having nothing to hide relieves stress and builds trust.
23. Relationship has to be genuine, not forced.
24. Be a practical idealist.
25. Great questions are a much better indicator of future success than great answers.
26. The best negotiations are the ones with someone in which I say, "You should take more," and they argue back, "No you should take more!"
27. Have a growing the pie mindset instead of playing a zero-sum game.
28. The litmus test for a good problem solver is 1) they are able to logically describe how to handle the problem and 2) they have successfully solved similar problems in the past.
29. Consider second- and third-order consequences, not just first-order ones.
30. If a position is part-time and requires highly specialized knowledge, I would prefer to have it done by consultants or outsiders.
31. Don't act before thinking. Take the time to come up with a game plan. It'll make the doing radically more effective.
32. Four ways to get things done fast: 1) having fewer thing to do by prioritizing and saying no, 2) finding the right people to delegate to, 3) improving your productivity, and 4) working harder for longer hours.
33. Don't confuse checklists with personal responsibility.
34. When you and your team have successfully pushed through to achieve your goals, celebrate! Ring the bell!

From video I‚Äôve got:
1. Don't confuse delusion with not knowing.
2. What's common produces only common results.

text:
What if you want more than a processed decision, what if you may not yet have identified whether your decision is around something that has never been done before .... I see designers and ai grad students not knowing nearly enough to imagine how one actually forms their principles to have it expressed ...I see a lot, often lame assumptions...better to do the I ching, where questions are considered not by a binary process ... it least it is open end reflection and not a series of criteria. Perhaps that is what he meant by his distinction of ai being good for expected results rather than novel ones.
There are also all value statements of "better", "doing good" being tossed around. Needs unpacking... "do right things" ..again .. many assumptions...
About his societal ideas...smack privilege albeit well meaning.
Non traumatic child raising is more than the parent's responsibility, they very well are traumatized themselves, denied opportunity themselves..It is pretty well studied fact this society is rigged...there are ancestral wounds of the society's own making to deal with if you want to talk about responsibility...His ideas of creating opportunity early as a way to create more equity is welcomed but not completely thought out..
He doesn't have the expertise to do it though the effort is worthwhile, same as Bill Gates not understanding what regenerative agriculture is, or Elon thinking saving humanity is going to Mars.. where is the equity in deciding where all their money ... more money than some whole countries have is being directed to efforts not quite thought out....
