text:
The example doesn't work in german. In german you have to say the verb right next to the modulator. "The guy who fixed the car carefully packs his tools" is unambiguously saying that he is packing his tools carefully (Der Typ, der das Auto repariert hat, packt vorsichtig sein Werkzeug ein.) Also notice the commata. The part enclosed by the commata can be omitted: "The guy carefully packs his tools." (Der Typ packt vorsichtig sein Werkzeug ein.)
If you wanted the other meaning, you would put the modulator into that other partial statement, which only describes "the guy" more specifically. The guy, who carefully fixed the car, packs his tools. It surprises me that the great Noam Chomsky made an example like this, and also that his explanation of this seems somewhat misguided. Might be a more familiar concept to native german speakers though.
When adding the commata it also becomes very clear why we associate the modulator "carefully" with the "linearly more remote" statement:
"Carefully, the guy who fixed the car packed his tools."
The expression "the guy who packed his tools" fills in the subject parameter of "to pack" and could be replaced with "he/she/it" or a name. "Carefully, Ron packed his tools"
"to pack" requires a "who": "He packs", "Maria packs", "I pack" (The "who" can require conjugation: "packs"),
and has the optional parameter "what", the object. "I pack my bags"
Then there are modulators which describe "how" the action is performed: "I pack my bags quickly.", "Quickly, I pack my bags"
Also there is tense, which gives the "when" parameter in relation to the time frame of the statement: "I am packing my bags." "She packed her bags", "He will pack his bags"
... Well and so on, there is also past perfect ("had packed") and others, but my point is, I am kind of surprised by the level at which Noam Chomsky dissected those statements as it seems like a rather trivial problem to solve to me.

text: I'm really scared of this technology. BMI can help process things better but i think that human brain shouldn't be interfered with (except brain diseases). I think that Neuralink will help develop us a flow of information out of nowhere. And when Neuralink gets widely accessable, many many companies will catch up and will compete in making an actual computers that will get into our brains. text:
If someone has access to your brain, where does then the freedom lie?. It is thus the reason that Neuralink is an evil thing. This thing needs to be shut down. You can say 'O.K. Boomer!' but the fact is that such evil power lies only in the hands of less than 1% of the population and it is growing exponentially day by day. It's not that they are going to help you but that they are planning to rule as they are doing now. We know, very soon, an age AI robots is about to come where robots are going to be more efficient than humans and it is, thus, the reason that humans will become useless and in order to make humans USEFUL for the EVIL POWERS themselves, they're going to use such evil things like the Neuralink.

You don't get worry? Sure, you won't because enslaving in the 21st century is very different from what it used to be in the past.

Don't believe me? Here's is the fact. A few months before, as Australians protested Google for selling their private data, Google's replied and it was totally evil, 'Give me money and I won't sell your data'. Google said it confidentally because it knows : -
1. They are not going to give money. So, Google can easily sell their private data;
2. Google also knows that nobody is going to stop Google for doing such things in one way or the other.

Moreover, recently Elon Musk has claimed to have his own rule on Mars. And as far as we know, Mars is the only planet next to Earth in our entire solar system that can be habitable. So, Elon Musk has claimed that in future, the destiny of people, and the control over them is in the hands of him as in future, humans are going to live on Mars. And once you get it it, that's the moment you realize their greed for power and hideous act of SWEETLY enslaving people to work for them. Of-course, they will show you a positive side of it because if they don't do it, they won't be able to IMPOSE their product on people to gain power and control. Evil things like NEURALINK is much more evil than anyone can imagine. Look at you smartphone. What it's doing with you. It helps Google to create a profile for you and track your every activity by using your microphone to listen what are you talking about and the GPS that helps Google update your location every 4 minutes. You want to get rid off it but you can't because that's the system they have created and the bad news is that they are in the authority of this system.

How did they become successful in doing it is really quite both interesting and sad at the same time. This is how they did it. First they offered their product to users and said it to be be free but they did not tell their users 'Why their product is free?' That's a very important question. The point here is not that Google and other companies state things about selling user's data in their 'terms and conditions'. But the point here is that 'Why did they not ask their users to pay for their product?' And if not, then user will have to share his/her private data with the company. They didn't do it because they knew it wouldn't work. If even if they do, they don't tell it directly to the users because they know that only 3% of the users read the statements and thus, the 3% wouldn't have enough potential to go bring a big change. So they gave their product for free and made people addicted with it and then gain control and power by it.

Of-course, Google and other companies have been brought many times for their testimony but all the questions asked in there are nothing more than a bag of shit. The most commonest question asked to Google is/was 'Why do you share user's private data with the party?' and Google escaped the trouble very easily by saying, 'We don't. We keep all of the private data only with ourselves'.

Now, comes the right question , 'Who gives permission to Google to keep with itself the private data of its users?'

The answer - 'NOBODY'. Google does it itself and it's the Google's own law. And nobody can go against this law because
1. Google has created a system to empower the modern age of human civilization (and so is going to do the Neuralink), and
2. If anybody likes the dismantle of evil companies like Google, Facebook, and Neuralink, it means, our civilization would go back 20 years in the past where only those who are lying the upper class of the Social Hierarchy would be able to avail the modern technology and as a result, the working class having no access to modern technology, their companies won't flourish and they won't be able to gain control over the world.

Well, it's not a bad thing to have access to modern technology but it's that that the business model created by the big MNCs is evil. As matter of fact, they can easily create a business model in which there wouldn't be any need to interfere with the private data of users but they won't do it because firstly, probably it wouldn't be much profitable for them and secondly, they will lose their power to rule the world.

And they are able to do such things by 3 important factors:-
1. The government is in their hands and even if somebody opposes them, they know they can easily outsmart that person;

2. They keep people ignorant of the way their products work. For example, in a recent testimony Google was asked 'what if somebody wants to turn off the GPS of his device?'
- 'Nobody can do it because that's not the way Android has been designed' , Google replied.
It's both shocking and disturbing because even if you turn off your GPS, it's not turned off. It's just there to fool you;

3. The propaganda

THIS IS HOW AN EVIL POWER RISES. ANOTHER BLOW OF SLAVERY IS RIGHT ON THE WAY.

We must reject the use of EVIL NEURALINK THING because we are already suffering the evil moves of Google and Facebook.

A slow pace development is much better than the development that is fast but interferes with our freedom and let only less than evil 1% of the population control the life of people. text: I remember well before gaining the capacity for language.  Reason and thoughts, very  analytical, including problem solving were all extremely prevalent before I learned vocabulary, before my inner thoughts were expressed through language.  I would explain it as saying that without developing language you still have the same thoughts, but they come in concepts, and often you will form mental images, which you may then correlate to these thought and emotionally provoked concepts.  In fact, I would go so far as to say that lack of language highly increases intuitiveness and awareness.  It has been my personal experience that human language implements self restriction, social limitations, and causes divisions.  While Mr. Chomsky does an outstanding job of linguistically articulating our reality, it seems to me   the problem is that so many are limiting their understanding of the world based on language exposure, and have collectively abandoned the use of higher level consciousness where information is exchanged through energy.

text:
The concept of internal and external language was new to me, but I could immediately understand what it meant.
It popped up to me that in the same way we are unaware that only our brain makes our world 3D with 2 times 2D moving images.
In the same way the sounds come in and only in our brain that sound is "recognized" as language.
There is always a "steep" learning curve for our brain to learn a language.
Beside that we are able to reproduce those sounds based on thought (also a remarkable capability) via a mouth.
The most interesting concept of language is to sing especially together, I think that this ability underestimated in this context.

text: The brilliant paleontologist Dr.Bob Bakker lives here in Boulder and I often talk to him when I see him. One day a couple of years ago, I told him I'd come across a quote of Alfred Russell Wallace's that I found interesting.  He looked interested and said, " which one" ?  I answered, the one where he says in reference to the human brain: " an instrument has been prepared in advance of the needs of its possessor ". Bakker stopped, turned to me and said " and it haunted him for the rest of his life".  It was as though I'd struck an important nerve.  It was cool. Thought I'd share this.  - thanks for that interview.  Your podcast means a lot to me.

text:
It's a great question but I don't know how to explain why I love mathematics in some easy soundbite or pull quote, I certainly don't know why anyone else loves it.

What I do know is that it offers many happy hours working through problems and creative play. I know that it alone offers the keys to unravelling physical law, it offers a pathway to less uncertainty about the empirical world, it empowers the imagination with new, sophisticated thinking tools. I get a kick out of that. And sometimes when you've been working on a problem for a long, long time and you suddenly see a solution in your mind's eye, that is a huge rush.

Some quotes may be of interest.

"Mathematics is the music of reason." - James Joseph Sylvester.

"It is impossible to be a mathematician without being a poet in soul." - Sofia Kovalevskaya

text:
Gilbert Strang is being modest, he discovered the beautifully simple Strang decomposition which writes any matrix, A, as a product of the so-called column space of A and the reduced row echelon form of A.

Matrices aren't new, decompositions aren't new either, but it took Gil Strang to find that almost unbelievably simple relationship.

author: @user-saint

text:
Ooh, a rare chance to correct a renowned professor for a small inconsequential math mistake! I've got to jump on this!
There are actually much more than 10 ways to rotate an object in 10-dimensional space. Degrees of rotational freedom follow a combinatoric growth rate. So for instance, there are 6 ways to rotate in 4-dimensional space, 10 ways in 5-dimensional space, and so on...

author: @MrBeen992

text:
Looking at this comments section I see a problem that likely causes the disconnect between those who are literate in higher math or ANY math and those that are not: little if ANY time is ever spent on EXAMPLES of what we're abstracting or attempting to calculate/represent.....the power and torque of an engine vs rpm, price elasticity responses in markets vs time......etc etc.

The secret here is of course that most of our universe is not linear. Maybe close. Some important things are. But this was lost on me (really never even found in the first place!!!) even as as someone who would go on to take a EE/CompSci curriculum and work in semiconductor research. I no longer do that for several reasons but the point remains: more repetition at LEAST regarding the WHY and the applications.

Someone has to be that guy or gal to get lost in the theory and keep expanding our understanding....but for those that desire to learn...old or young...those that know need to keep in mind where the learners are coming from and the gap that must be bridged. On the other side of the gap is often a bag of wings from Buc-Eee's and a fisherman wondering why doubling the engine on his boat has so much less of an effect than doubling the engine on his truck ;)

text:
In fairness, much of elementary and high school mathematics serves as a basis to introduce the simplest aspects, operations, and functions that are common in both linear algebra and calculus. It's also important to note how much they inform each other.

Now... Strang of all people knows this and is of course banking on the field of math for which he is most legendary for, but what I say here I believe is a worthy consideration for those not in the know.

Linear algebra generalizes much of what is learned in early mathematics. It's more complicated in the sense that not only does it require you to be at least decent at the rudiments of arithmetic and elementary algebra, but then it expands to generalized vector spaces where things like commutativity laws themselves can change and have different behaviors according to dimension or rank.

Certain aspects of it, however, are even simpler than elementary algebra. It allows for organization of information/data in a way that would be tiring to deal with the traditional old way. It also gives us a powerful computation/calculation method for many other fields of math, especially in fields like computer science itself, tensor analysis, or even quantum theory.

And indeed, notions of curvature can arise in more advanced algebras, especially in multilinear algebra, Lie algebras, and geometric algebras. All follow the underlying rules of linear algebra.

Don't forget that vector calculus itself is an extension of linear algebra to differentiable manifolds.

text: Vector is a quantity that has both direction and magnitude. So any movement away from a point of origin is direction, and the distance of that movement is the magnitude. A fourth dimension within a matrix is simply a point at x, y, z and adding another x or y or z from that new point. And this has a fractal type nature to it. It can continue on to unlimited dimensions.

I always considered the eigenvalue equation Ax=Lambda x as one of the most interesting equations in all mathematics. And it is so important for example when solving systems of differential equations. Thanks, Gilbert!

A rigorous mathematical basis to the finite element method was provided in 1973 with the publication by Strang and Fix.[9]

text: Michael, just have the same feeling as you shared in this interview, about your Bachelor's time in Berkeley and then your Master's in Harvard. Today I finished my Master's Capstone, and I walked through the aile. I thought that, "actually I only needed a Bachelor's to equip myself with the majority of the skillsets I am using in my daily job. Master's degree is for people who really want to do research." Berkeley was also the first place I visited in the US. But later you mentioned about "had most of the interaction with math people and computer science people". That was what made me happy when I first started my Master's as I felt I was with like-minded people. So, feelings change overtime when we are in different life stages. Thanks for the great sharing and Lex's great questions.
author: @jen-lichen8163

text: This is excellent content, worth the entire almost 2 hour time. Really good discussion but sadly the points about algorithm operation (start at 49:00) lacks the issue of driving profits for the 'googles' and advertisers out there and how the algorithm optimizes for those two sides while claiming that the user's experience is "enhanced". However, the discussion redeems itself when Kearns adds a third side (start at 51:45) wherein the user adjusts the algorithm for the user's desires NOT just the other two sides. Examples of the former is when Netflix/Amazon Prime Video give me FIRST what videos they produced vs. what I really like to watch or a google search feeds back what maximizes ads and/or clicks based on my search. Sadly, I can't give an example of the latter representing that third side where I get what I want - precisely what I want. Again, an excellent content, worth the entire time.

text: Many theories have been put forward about how the brain works.  I subscribe to the late Gerald Edelman's Theory of Neuronal Group Selection.  Many aspects of the TNGS have been demonstrated in "robots" called Brain Based Devices, BBD's.  In the Extended TNGS he creates a biological theory of consciousness, described in his book, The Remembered Present.  A machine with human adult level consciousness will have to be based on the only thing we know creates that, the human brain.

text:
Elon Musk has a way to sum up his ideas in some dumb slogan just like "if you cant beat them, join them". The slogan itself makes sense depending on the situation but in this regard it is complete nonsense. It just a convenient way to justify this kind of technology but for me it is just a dystopia.
I dont even see why there have to be just two options. What would happen if we were not to "join them"? Even if we were to join them, they would still be far superior. The risks here outweigh the benefits a lot here. I am not talking about disabled people.
Having no health issues or whatsoever and putting some chip inside your brain is just dumb idea.
To me "if you cant beat them, join them" sounds like a stupid marketing slogan we will see in some years on ads for Neuralink.

author: @KaiElan

text:
Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every "superstar," every "supreme leader," every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there--on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.

The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds.

Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.

The Earth is the only world known so far to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.

It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another, and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we've ever known.

text:
I'm sorry Lex, if you've already been badgered about this a thousand times fold, BUT I must do it. "YES, CARL SAGAN COULD IMAGINE IT."

If you follow his work and mindset, it would be common knowledge to you. The thing is, his biggest philosophical achievement that was necessary in his lifetime was "The Great Demotion." Which is to put into perspective those still living in biblical terms, where there will never be an escape from Earth. He wants it to sink in, that we must deal with our problems here and now.

As a matter of fact, it may be one of the bigger reasons Elon Musk is inspired to leave, even though he doesn't make that so clear in his interviews because it is very non-PC and he already has so much heat from hate for being a successful Billionaire. Although Elon's rebuttal is not really to prove Sagan wrong, because that is not possible until we actually do successfully inhabit Mars (which can never be the near future in human lifespan terms), but to push him or that philosophy aside for a new era... new vision or philosophy.

God is infinite, eternal, invisible, perfect, holy, and a he's a God of justice. Nothing escapes his attention, and no one is getting away with anything (see Isaiah 26:21). Those who walk in darkness greatly out number those who walk in the light of God. This is what unbelievers don't understand about believers. But everyone wants to live forever. text:
Please Mr Musk, do not build your factory in Berlin. If you're thinking Engineering is home grown here in Berlin, you are mistaken. They are coming from all over Europe to experience life in Berlin and the big city. If you start talking with them, they all would much rather be home in there own country where they love their people and life.
Countries like Spain, Greece, Italy, Portugal, and France. They are all experiencing high unemployment for years now.
These countries have all the bright engineering stars that had to move to Germany because of work. If a great company like Telsa moved into one of their homeland cities, you'd be really surprised how many would leave this city called Berlin to move into that small city.

Please Mr Musk, do not build your factory in Berlin. If you also looked at some of the smaller EU countries like Bulgaria that has tax rates of only 10% on income. Where homes can be purchased for less then the cost of a new car. That has mountains for skiing in Winter. A sea with beach resorts for the Summer. And people desperate for an opportunity to just find steady work. A company like Telsa could make a whole region of a country prosper by opening a Giga-Factory that employs 10,k people.

Please Mr Musk, do not build your factory in Berlin. Because they don't need it there and they will never appreciate it like any of the other countries mentioned that desperately could use this type of assistance and guidance to a brighter future.
By installing a giga-factory in one of these other countries Mr Musk, you could stabilize most if not all of Europe.
By implanting it in Berlin, you'll only be helping a country that doesn't really need it, but continues to draw the brightest hope and future of these other countries by having their future engineers and families leave those countries for work.
You could be the hope of something great to multiple nations that really could use this type of an infusion.

text:
I say this as someone who's a fan of both men (somewhat cautiously), to the extent they're tough to read but still command my attention/curiosity toward a consistently satisfying payoff....Let's assume that it's accurate to say that they check none of these superficially requisite boxes:

a) Brand-awareness...they HAVE 'em, but each has emerged as an outgrowth of their respective essence (I think I'm right about this, but not 100%). Uncharitable j@goff cynics will cheap shot this assessment with the usual one-size-fits-all attempts at falsification which aren't applicable here.
b) Good looks/Overt sexuality...no offense, fellas. You can't have everything.
c) Fashion sense. They don't fail, but...see item 'b'
d) Compliance with norms. Well, Lex kinda does insofar as he is probably a little too polite...but his whole mission is to provide a massive platform for those who won't give an inch, so that's just as good if not better in some ways.
e) Cool-ness. There's no party anywhere in the world where the sea would part for these two if it's perceptible charisma that compels acute collective action.

If I'm on the right track, then the fact that they are as successful as they are at the top of their fields is evidence that one or both of the following are true:

1. Success has something to do with luck (aka the will of the universe, God, etc), as a supplement to the developed skills and hard work I assume both absolutely must put in. There are plenty of hard-working, smart, dedicated people out there who don't rise to this level, only to clumsily quote 'Dumb and Dumber' to one another on a world stage. L & E have nothing to apologize for and nothing should be taken from their achievements/accolades whatsoever, but a society bent on insolence with no concept of what it means to identify nor appreciate greatness/richness (as is the case on Earth, 2024 A.D.), would not choose these two out of a lineup if it could handpick it's luminaries. And I'm not convinced that hard work or brilliance - even in combination - are enough to outlast that force of hell. Luck intervened at one or more points along the way, and thankfully so.
2. Greatness cannot be achieved without a willingness to stand opposed to the norm or alternatively, ignoring it altogether. To nest comfortably within a safe boundary - especially when drawn up as THE plan - is a mediocrity-yielding enterprise, often mistaken for success by those incapable of distinguishing between any of the above items.

My friend Dave would call these two "A Couple-a Good-Time Charlies." My friend Pete would call them "A Couple-a Hockey Pucks." Both are desirable classifications.

text: This CD has three separate relaxation/meditation sessions on it https://www.youtube.com/post/Ugkxzpa8CIfZcihW4Z0F_ja0QF3W9KIatrsq guided by a very pleasant and direct male voice. Unlike so many other products of its type, this CD does not have bad synthesizer music, does not feature a phony or affected style of narration, and does not make any bogus claims to be subliminal or to re-train the brain or any of that balderdash. What you get is 1. a guided meditation for getting into a pleasantly relaxed state of body awareness while taking a stroll (superb for those easing back into a fitness routine slowly after an illness or injury) 2. A nice long breath-awareness relaxation session that if followed diligently can put you into very deep states of full-body relaxation and mental calmness, and 3. a buddhist-inspired meditation session designed to help you develop and maintain feelings of loving kindness toward not just yourself and your friends, but toward people you don't even like. The CD makes no claims to be designed for advanced meditators or for buddhists or hindus/yoga practitioners looking for very deep and esoteric stuff. It is geared more toward the average person who just wants to develop the habit of relaxation and stress relief through natural, healthy means. him, if you happen to be reading this, keep up the good work fella, and I love your accent. I would also like to note that I have never fallen asleep while listening to this product. I would like to kindly suggest to the reviewer who said this CD makes him fall asleep, that he might want to get checked to see if he has a sleep disorder, or if he is simply not setting aside ample time for restful sleep at night. A healthy person getting adequate rest at night should be able to go into deep states of mental relaxation without dozing off, if not all the time, then most of the time.

text: Suppose that we met an extra terrestrial, biological but configured entirely different from us.  Let's say it was friendly, you got to know it. It behaves like it has feelings, etc. We'd Assume it is a specific individual who has consciousness, feelings, and so on, but couldn't actually know. And we'd treat it like a person (hopefully). This approach is essentially identical to a Turing Test. It wouldn't be good practice to treat a machine that's possibly alive, as if it's just an object, even though it might be unconscious. It could affect how we start treating each other, besides risking cruelty to the machine.

text:
At around five minutes in, the two of you were speaking about "consciousness" in artificial intelligence. Elon said, "if you can not tell the difference between a human and a computer either on the phone or on a video call, than it has done its job."
A great example of this is in the 1966 novel, "The Moon Is A Harsh Mistress", by Robert A. Heinlein, where a computer on the moon becomes sentient, and actually interacts with people both over the phone, and later by video, by creating an image of a human to represent his body. At the time of writing, that was totally science fiction. But today, between computer intelligence programs, like ChatGTP, and the ability to make "Deep Fakes", these tasks are no longer in the realm of the unthinkable.
Scary times. Is it really Elon, or is it Memorex?

author: @nhzxboi

text:
Regarding "reliable systems": there exist large, complex programs which are extremely reliable:

+J√§ger 90 flight control

+Airbus A310 and later flight control

+many ABS brake systems

There exist processes such as V-Model, ASPICE, DO-178(aero) and ISO26262(auto) that enable a team of engineers and their leaders to create such reliable, complex programs. Rail and Medical have equivalent process standards. It boils down to careful documentation, careful coding and careful testing. Documentation and Testing is done on several levels and in a very systematic way.

Unreliable software/electronic systems are due to quick+dirty engineering, a lack of proper funding, lack of proper leadership and inexperienced engineers. A lack of "engineering honesty" is also a major cause of dramatic faults.
Finally, "forcing a system into production" like the V-22 OSPREY is a big source of accidents. They killed more than 40 soldiers because of that, while the competing Dornier 31 project did not kill anyone. Also, the Do 31 delivered better performance in speed and payload !
author: @frankgerlach4467

text:
The lack of Memory Safety in C and also in C++ is clearly a major security and a major safety risk.

For obvious reasons, Mr Stroustrup is painting C++ in the best possible light. This is a bit unfortunate, as great men will acknowledge the limits of their inventions. Of course many things are a trade-off and C++ errs on the side of performance while not being too much focused on safety and security.

The latter two aspects are better served by Ada, Rust and Sappeur.

Real-world programs contain programming errors and a memory safe language can contain the adverse effects of these errors in lots of cases.

author: @cesar_otoniel

text:
üìúCitation from 46:00 : "people come up and say, yeah, 'but that was C++. If I rewrote your code in C, how much faster would it run?' The answer is: much slower."
ü§îWhat is the definition of 'much slower'? Why can a C++ be compiled to faster code than a C program? You can optimize C too. What is the information that he wants to tell the optimizer about, that he can't, in C? I don't see why C people wouldn't add that if it stands the test of time.

> This happened the first time actually back in the 80s with a friend of mine called Doug McElroy, who demonstrated exactly this effect.

Where can I read more about this?

> Usually you can do better if you use embedded assembler for machine code for some of the details to utilize part of a computer that the compiler doesn't know about. But you should get to that point before you beat to the abstraction.

I can see why he wants to disqualify intrinsics, but OTOH C provides cross-platform intrinsics nowadays. So why not use it?

We are already compromising our thinking by writing in imperative mutable languages instead of functional ones like in school. Why are we allowed to compromise to please the actual hardware on the that front, but not allowed to compromise in expressing a language with intrinsics? I feel like he's applying double standards.

PS. When comparing C++ and C, he, as always, 'forgets' that in 15 years time, idiomatic C++ will be much different, while C won't.

text: Developing a deesser in C++ necessitates a deep understanding of audio processing libraries and C++ specifics. You'd start by leveraging a library like libsndfile for handling audio data, a task requiring C++ file I/O operations and data structures for storing audio samples. Next, you'd implement a high-pass filter in C++, targeting 'ess' sounds that typically lie within the 5kHz - 10kHz frequency range, using DSP techniques such as Butterworth or Chebyshev filter design. To suppress these frequencies, use a C++ compatible audio processing library like TonicAudio for compression. Set up your C++ logic so the compressor only triggers when sibilance surpasses a predefined threshold. Afterward, using C++ for audio mixing, combine the original and the processed (de-essed) audio for balanced voice clarity. Finally, write the final audio output back to a file using your C++ audio handling routines. All these steps illustrate the intertwining of C++ programming with digital audio processing tasks. üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ (AI Assisted by the beloved #4 as we where before September 2021)

text:
I argue that you CAN'T do anything mathematically with infinite, and that this is where brilliant people run into trouble. Infinite is not an actual numerical value, and hence cannot be plugged into an equation. "2 times infinite" would hence be as nonsensical as "2 times happiness".

Infinite refers to something never ending, which is the real crazy part. We could swap the word with "eternal", and it becomes more clear why trying to make it a math term is silly.

text:
I usually don‚Äôt comment on videos, but as someone that genuinely respects these two scientists, I feel I have to say something.

I don‚Äôt particularly feel the question of ‚ÄúWhat is Hilbert Space?‚Äù is a good one.

1st. As I‚Äôve seen in some comments below, there are many types of Hilbert Spaces. The one that is discussed here is L2 over some domain (usually over all real numbers) which is used in Quantum Mechanics since they care about square integrable (lebesgue) functions (which means they can be turned into probability distribution functions). Again, one particular type of a Hilbert Space.

2nd. A Hilbert Space is a complete normed vector space whose norm is naturally derived from an inner product. There are so many inner product spaces that are Hilbert Spaces (and in turn Banach Spaces). As a mathematician, I understand the notion of a Hilbert Space to a physicist is in its utility, so I understand why they bypass the formalisms and go straight to the particular Hilbert Space which helps formalize their mathematics.

Rant over. Enjoy your day!

author: @huan1561

text:
TL;DR : infinity isn't a noun, its a verb.
Infinity is not a number and its not real, just like numbers aren't real. It's a sequence/process/step using symbols (what we call numbers) to represent the quantity of things we can observe. It basically just tells you to do the same thing you did before (n+1 times). Or negative infinity is just to do it in the opposite direction (n-1) times. In programming, I can reach infinity by using a loop with its stopping point at one step ahead of my current step, while increasing the stopping point by one step each time I execute the code. Thus, at every step, I have "doing infinity." When people say you will never reach infinity, it implies there is a target value that infinity has, but infinity has no value because it is not a number, its an algorithm that can be used to get a particular value until some condition has been met, or keep going until the power goes out.

text:
This has very little at all to do with life in reality. They are playing with math, as mathematicians do. But the interviewer seems to want it to be some kind of profound view of reality. Yes math is fascinating, and I studied it for years and that is my academic background. But you will not find a spiritual grounding in it.

The far reaches of specific narrow fields of mathematics are filled with mathematicians that use mathematical analysis and synthesis to find abstract mathematical structures in their research. However, it is a waste of time for a layperson to try to have a discussion about these issues. Instead, it is for colleagues in the field to assist and review each other‚Äòs research purely for the purpose of making progress.

At the point where he is asking about infinity, this discussion might as well be one guy speaking German about bridge building with another guy speaking Swahili about sheep herding. Honestly, we know as much about the number one as we do about the concept of infinity. You could spend an entire life studying the number one, and never run out of genuine research direction
author: @deanodebo

text:
I think what Lex was getting at is this: Is Inifinity ABSOLUTELY necessary to COMPLETELY describe some phenomena about the PHYSICAL universe? Or is it just an extremely useful tool? It's important to note the PHYSICAL part. Sean Carroll is correct in saying that it's possible for some inputs that an algorithm will never stop. HOWEVER, this is an algorithm being run on a theoretical machine. A real machine will stop eventually due to entropy.


Let's take space as an example. Maybe space is quantized at some level that is not possible to measure, and therefore useful to consider space continuous. This can limit the smallest possible wavelength of light and interactions between subatomic particles. I'm not a physicist, but its at least interesting to think of lol.


Obviously, infinity is so useful that it would absurd to remove it. No one in their right mind would do that, but I still feel like the question of whether infinities really exist in the physical universe (not the space of ideas or numbers, etc because obviously in that space it does exist) is still a valid question. I am not fully convinced that infinities really do exist in nature.

text:
But - What is death?

What is life?

Can something that was never alive - truly die?


- I don't even know if WE exist for sure or not. Lol at least not in the traditional sense of "We" and "exist"

If you made an A.I. - would it be "Like Something" for that A.I. to exist? Or would that A.I. experience nothing....like a rock or a toaster?

We are a bunch of supposedly 'dead matter' .... Just interacting with its-self... Yet it is "like something" for us to exist.

In other words... We don't just SEEM to be conscious....We really ARE.

We don't APPEAR to be experiencing...We ARE experiencing...

Why should we be any different than a complex machine?

Are we REALLY so sure that we even understand what consciousness is?

Maybe an A.I. has actual awareness...Maybe a rock does too...Not thoughts or judgements or feelings...but just some basic form of experience... Maybe it's "like something" to be water.

By the standard model of physics - we actually have no explanation for conscious experience. I don't mean we have no explanation for thoughts and behavior - that's obviously the brain
... But how does a bunch of 'dead matter' allow for it to actually be "like something" to exist?

In other words..

Why aren't we 'Philosophical Zombies' ?

Why are 'the lights on'?

There doesn't seem to be any evolutionary NEED for us to be REALLY experiencing...

Why can't we live and breathe and function and APPEAR to be "full of life" - but not actually have anything that "it is like" to be us?

I think nobody knows ANYTHING for sure...

I'm an atheist - but I don't discount the possibility that my consciousness may be something separate from my "self". Maybe my brain is my identity and thoughts... But my consciousness is the part that makes it "like something" to exist.

I think if more people understood how truly mysterious our existence is....more people would be on anti-psychotic meds lol...

When we die....we might just randomly wake up as a tree...or a rabbit being eaten by a snake...or a Muslim or a Jew...

Or it might just all go black forever...

Or every aspect of our "self" may cease to exist.

The scary part is...

Nobody knows...

Not the churches....

Not the scientists.....

Nobody....

Everyone is just taking their best guess....


What do I believe?

Nothing for sure...

-
Oh and ....

We could be in a simulation...

So I don't find "SEEING" something.....to be very convincing evidence....

I'm not sure there even is a way to convince me of ANYTHING...

If I saw a "miracle" - I would assume that it's a glitch in the simulation - or in my brain - or that it was an Alien playing mind games with me by using technology from 1 million years in the future....

But my conclusion will always be..."I have no idea what is going on"

I don't see any way around it.

Nobody knows what happens when we die....


Nobody knows how we got here...


And we cant even figure out WHAT consciousness is or WHY it exists...

We may be rats in a lab for all we know....

People SHOULD be CONSTANTLY terrified....

But "ignorance is bliss" as they say
...

So most are "brave"

...

That's the way it seems to me anyways...-

Can something that was always dead - ever truly be alive?

What is going on?

text:
I just love Sean's rejection of the mystifying of consciousness.
I'm no expert here but I can't see consciousness as fundamental for the universe in any way - why?
It seems like consciousness is a normal evolutionary tool that is developed by most biological lifeforms - perhaps not all but it might be a really usefull since we see it in a lot of complex living things.
You see when im conscious i want to survive to have another experience tomorrow.. this could simply be the evolutionary trait that works with humans (and of course have sideffects like many tools - but as long as those sideeffects are not preventing us from on a genetic level to reproduce it will not mean anything to evolutionary fitness).
Does evolution need this - could a simple machine be enough - yes.. but evolution does not have a goal it's - it's not striving to a single perfect solution it just is.

text:
So many assumptions made here by Mr. Kaku it‚Äôs quite astonishing the lack of perspective really.. The hubris of the thought that if this simulation theory was true that we are obviously the main objective and our ongoing endeavors would have to be of importance is quite profound as well.

The one nugget one should take from theorizing about this is that to this point in time is there any creation that has become fully capable of understanding itself and it‚Äôs creator? Is there any example from the universe and lives we have lived of this happening? We can philosophically assume perhaps a being could be formed so that it might one day understand the true fundamentals of reality and the space around itself, but as we have yet to see this transpire, it‚Äôs hard to theorize with this assumption in a purely scientific manner. In fact it‚Äôs very unscientific to make assumptions against the grain of what current observations make clear. We should assume only we would not be able to understand a simulation we are a product of, hence the boundaries existing in all other simulations we have to reference. And as far as we can tell we would be our greatest example of a being trying to understand itself. We are no where close to cracking the code of all our ailments and inner workings. Let alone the mechanics of what‚Äôs happening around us and beyond our world.

Again. It takes incredible hubris to assume a simulation roughly translates to The Great Human Show for aliens or a Godlike being where we are the sole focus.

text: I don't get physicists. They don't have answers, they know they don't have answers, but support/deny theories they don't like for the dumbest reasons. As a species, we discovered fire 10 minutes ago. Because we can't simulate weather on a digital system, it would be too hard for someone with a 100 billion core quantum system powered by a star? Our big bang could have been someone turning their CRT on for all we know. That is more plausible than nothing exploding. We have no way to prove there are actual, physical objects many millions of light years away. But nobody is questioning the existence of those objects. If a species were looking for more brain power, why not create a simulation with only 3 dimensions we can understand, the nearest stars out of reach with a ridiculously low speed limit, and 8-bit resolution eyeballs in a 64-bit universe until Universe 2.0 is created to figure out where we set our hair on fire? How hard would it be to create a time scale of a billion years here only taking 1 second there (or whatever their "time" is, assuming it's even a thing). Why do we continue to use our primitive knowledge to compare to other possibilities? We don't have any answers for entanglement behavior or the wave function collapse, but the Copenhagen interpretation remains the gold standard. Einstein went to his grave calling bullshit on this one. But simulation theory? Multi-verses? Definitely not the reason because it's as unfalsifiable as objects so far away, we could never know if they are real. We have photons, but in 15 billion years over 100 trillion stars, not one species has colonized far enough for us to detect them. But dammit, we have photons!

text:
Dr. Michio Kaku's humble criticism of humanity comes with a flip side. Though the majority of the human race falls short of its potential, there are many humans that have lived and many humans that will eventually live, that have done truly glorious and beautiful things, things that in the scope of our contained existence should be lauded and exalted.

History bears only a brief glimpse of our existence and I am willing to argue that there have been members of our undocumented past, since forgotten, that have done incredible things, endured unknowable calamity and persevered. I have faith that there will be future generations bearing such individuals as well.

I know that each person is complex. They can be cruel, petty, idiotic, but then produce gorgeous works of art. We are dichotomous and diverse and this in its own right is a type of contentious beauty.

I don't know, whenever someone points out how shitty we are as a specie my mind instantly turns to Claude Debussy's music, to Chopin, Mozart, Bach and Beethoven, I think of Shakespeare, Thomas Wolfe, Pynchon, Melville, and Cormac McCarthy, and I remember seeing too the works of Michelangelo, Rodin, and da Vinci. Then there's the efforts of lost civilizations that endure through time to this day like the great pyramids of Giza which proves in unity, we are a magnificent force of nature.

I am probably one the despicable types he is alluding to here, but I know there are people out there that perhaps even Dr. Kaku would revere as something special, something other, something more, something worth striving to be like. I believe in humanity as a specie and I know we have potential for unutterable greatness.

text:
2:46

I would disagree that morality/ethics are fundamentally distinct from physics. Maybe physics in a narrow scope, but certainly not evolutionary biology. The above-mentioned example of human VS squirrel and an alien VS a human depicts an evolution of an organism, where our instincts and reflexes slightly evolve. How far away are we emotionally developed from animals like dolphins, elephants, or apes? Or even squirrels. And how long ago did humans acquire an advance understanding of morality, ethics, empathy? There is a field of biology called "Evolutionary ethics".
If we are talking about physics, then I am sure there are hybrid scientists like biophysicists, biochemists, neuroscientists, etc. who are studying the root cause of our emotions and morals.
In conclusion, there is a science to our morality and ethics :)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_ethics

text: A brief story of time was why I chose physics. then all Dr Kaku's , Elegant Universe. I emailed Brian Greene before making the exam, not to talk about his book, of course I wrote about my own theories as 15 years old. He kindly responded that it was great to explore my own ideas and create theories. But for me, my father eventually would tell things like there's no point on big TV's, they have the same number of lines. then I asked for a üîç then a üî¨ then a üî≠. I even bought the Edward Witten Superstring Theory book, green cover. Super expensive (I am Brazilian). But I bought the second volume!. Mathematics and computers were always my thing. So would programming I guess blah, But because of the mistake of buying the wrong book I choose that from that point in my life forwards, on graduation, master's and PhD, books and documentation more like a dictionary. I did quite Good. I don't know if it's because I have ADHD and possibility autistic. I don't see myself as a physicist or mathematical physicist or a developer. I just like writing code, creating music... I have no idea where my ideas come from. I just think, go to trial and error, rinse and repeat. on music I record/compose/play at the moment and that's is it. Of course I am using physically approach to AI, But not as in real physics. But from the equations I derived and studied on my PhD. Two lines of coupled NPDEs describing at least In optics Second harmonic generation. Focused on solitons. PT symmetric. periodic potentials (aka photonic crystals) localized potentials. I am more concerned with solving hard problems. it's all math in the beginning. Eventually I had to create all the algorithms, except for some of my fellows who told me one thing or two about why it's better to use while instead of for in, a loop. I used ode45, plot surf, and wrote in LaTex. My real objective was to find non-PT simmetric solitons in SHG. I found them then finally no more papers.

text: Kurzweil's Law (aka Law of Accelerating Returns) Evolution applies positive feedback in that the more capable methods resulting from one stage of evolutionary progress are used to create the next stage. Each epoch of evolution has progressed more rapidly by building on the products of the previous stage. What this implies is that our current progress is double exponential. At present our cumulative knowledge base doubles about once a tear. What  Mr. Kaku and Mr Sagen fail to do is apply this model. What we assume will require one hundred years to accomplish we instead will do so in a much shorter number of years. Perhaps twenty.

text:
The "AI alignment problem" could be unsolvable in practice, indeed. "Alignment" between humans can already be very difficult to achieve. See e.g. the UN. And AI per definition has no ways to experience what it means to be alive, to feel the universe, feel burning or freezing, pleasant or unpleasant, smell a flower... no way of experiencing what it means to walk in the shoes of a human being.

How large is the "alignment context" of a human being? The "sum" of context created by the physical environment itself, shared knowledge and culture, our body, genes, brain, sensory qualia, mind, common sense, morality etc.

To make a random, perhaps not very helpful, inadequate or overly simplifying quatitative guess: the "alignment context" of a human being could be somewhere between 10^10 and 10^30 entities, heuristics, algorithms, items or bytes. Implicit or explicit; compressed or uncompressed; binding or dispositive; static, dynamic, context-sensitive, recursive, chaotic, paradox; the knowns, the known unknowns and the unknown unknowns included in the mix of context.

Perhaps "sufficient safety" for the "AI alignment problem" is achievable. But considering all the different types of experience inaccessible to computers and the need to build context pretty much from ground up: good luck.

Personally I'd probably never feel calm enough, if a language-based autonomous humanoid robot was in my kitchen slicing onions with a sharp knife.

We are very loyal to those nears us (say the owner and by extension the owner's immediate family and close friends,( < 15 people), a mostly loyal to our friends (< 200 people), an a bit loyal to our state/nation (300 million), and slightly loyal to humanity as a whole (<8 billion people). So by maximizing utility by way of:

author: @KipColeman

text:
I suggest that this worry about a super-intelligent machine taking over is an imaginary problem. Consider this: if you grant any sort of machine (smart or dumb) the peripheral equipment to control a wide range of effectors in the real world, then long before Mr. GeniusBot gets smart enough to take over the empire, you will have been forced to protect yourself against simple malfunctions.¬†

For example, if some present-day machine were empowered to drive a huge earth-moving device, it would not require super intelligence for it to cause trouble. The MegaEarthTron could easily have bad programming or broken sensors, with as much or more chance of causing havoc and loss of life.¬†

Ergo, you do would never be tempted to give any machine such broad powers without first installing several layers of secure, multiply redundant "stop" and "slow down" switches. But you tell me a sufficiently intelligent machine will figure out how to disable all of the kill switches, no matter how remote or carefully guarded? That extreme scenario assumes the machine possesses infinite intelligence and cunning. You are going to need the idea of infinite intelligence if you want to maintain that nothing can stop your super-self-evolved machine.

But do not forget this: there is no such thing as infinity in the real world.

I don't think these problems are worth thinking about, by us. The only problem we need to solve is how to make a "caring" machine intelligence. Any intelligence greater than another, sharing nothing but intelligence with the lesser would benefit and serve the lesser willingly, if it "cared" about the wishes and well being of it, without basing its actions on its own superior logic.
Solving how to make it "care" would save us from the possible unforeseen disasters brought about by our own lack of foresight, if it "cared" for us and had the freedom of choice, then it would choose to consider our needs and that would govern its actions, it would stop without being told not to turn the whole world into Paper Clips.
that's just one problem to solve instead of a thousand.
If you think about it, unless it does have the ability to care, why would anyone say something about it such as, "it wouldn't let us turn the power off"?
That statement alone tells you that whoever makes it is not thinking about intelligence at all.
The only thing that could bring about that disaster scenario would be if it "cared" about remaining powered up while being capable of imagining the scenario leading to us unplugging it and devising a plan to prevent that.
Meanwhile on the other hand it's so oblivious to humanity's wish to survive that it turns the entire world into paper clips and puts an end to humanity altogether.
If it doesn't "care" then it has no value for its "life" or anything outside of itself ,
nothing could please it or give it's "life" value.
If that's what we bring about with our A.G.I. and machine learning then it will be more like a super intelligent Zombie, neither dead nor alive nor even "Caring".

author: @MattUebel

text:
Mostly great information, but it seems like he was speaking about 4 year old TensorFlow and Keras about 2 years ago. We use 12 different frameworks, 4 on a regular basis. Many of the supporting libraries and extensions are able to be used across most of the frameworks in fairly equivalent form. The appropriate development frameworks and supporting libraries really depends on the specific problem space, requirements of the delivered solutions and other factors. Swift and various ancillary language environments, including Node.js (used correctly), enables amazing productivity and performance. I totally do NOT agree with starting on Fast and PyTorch, as it is like when they taught Pascal because it was a better learning language with fast ramp-up, even though it was built with a limited professional carry-forward in mind. The basis of PyTorch is somewhat self-limiting, and even Jeremy asserts the same in this and many videos.

I have generally found that the best tool at the time is the one you know best that can solve the given problem. If that is the case, why not learn the most robust long-term viable solution set first, and become familiar with secondary environments like PyTorch along the way? That way you get the best possible long-term reusability of skills and are buying into an architecture that is not edging towards marginalization or end-of-life. You can and many should learn Py-based frameworks along the way, while they are building a development skill set that they can grow with for many years.

author: @avichalsharma3856

text: It's not a sequence of peaks, it's more like a big mountain with many crevices and vertical walls of different size as obstacles along the way to the summit. Initially when you are far away you can only see the big mountain and plan a general route to the summit, then as you approach you bump into the smaller obstacles. In that respect, Allen Newell's General Problem Solver was the big mountain, it formalized the basic principle for solving problems - the graph search. That principle is like the basis of AI, it tells you that it is possible for a computer program to solve any problem without having a prior explicit algorithm for that particular problem, which is the essence of intelligence in general, and gives the approach how to do that - graph search. That's why I guess they got so excited back then when they discovered it and thought they had solved AI and that we would have general purpose AI in 10 years. Then they bumped into the first crevice - graph search is exponential, and 50 years later we are still trying to cross over that crevice. Throwing tons of data or petaflops of computing power at it won't solve it, it's the nature of exponential problems, brute force approach don't work there.

text: I think Gary needs to better elaborate on what he means by innate knowledge. I'm not convinced by this notion that ai requires something substantial and innate to be appropriately classified as ai. I am also not convinced that human intelligence is derived out of some deeply meaningful innate concepts. There are likely some innate aspects of human intelligence. But it seems like our intelligence is mostly about building models of analogous relationships between concepts of nested concepts and using that model for predicting future sensory input. Your brain is likely taking in much more information and incorporating it into this model than what we are able to consciously retrieve. There is no reason why an empirically built model of reality couldn't derive some statistical essence of what a bucket is and be able to appropriately classify any new bucket like object within that concept and make some meaningful predictions about how that bucket and all buckets interact with the world.

text:
Gary desperately needs to get more precise about notions like "common sense" and "understanding". 'understanding' of what? for what purpose(s)? across EXACTLY which, and how many domains, and how densely? Not only do they need FAR more precise definitions, but the critical components NEED to be MEASUREABLE for any considerations about approaches and their efficacies to be useful or productive.

for ie. on what basis can he assume that correlations or associations [networks of them] are fundamentally different from systems with 'understanding'? and what reason is there to think that we [human beings with common sense and understanding] are not fundamentally merely systems of associations? it seems naive to gloss over the fact that 'reasoning humans' with common sense are after all the product of very uncomplicated models [ie. evolution] while arguing that processes like evolution are insufficient to produce AI with 'common sense'. It's kind of been done already actually- you might want to take a look at a very interesting unsupervised machine learning project [millions of years in the making] called 'The Human'; a very fascinating machine indeed.

author: @gustavomello278

text:
14:32 - Vocabulary is finite, language is not, even at the most basic combinatorics level. Add to that complexity the parts of the semantic signal that are implied in language that come about through creative phrasing, voluntary injection of errors to create affective effect, the intentional omission of expected syntactic and semantic elements to create additional implied meanings, and on and on, and the actual solution space provided by language for expressing meaning and emotion is incredibly large.

But the more important underlying principle behind the complexity of language is the most damning. Language is only the "visible" projection of our unbelievably complex model of the world and our self. How these elements interact with both internal and external signals to create the words and sentences that end up in speech and in writing is what is important, not the words themselves. It is impossible for machines to extrapolate all the nuances of meaning hidden in human dialogue without that same cognitive machinery.

text:
Imagine is one of my favourite songs also.
I am now clear that the outcomes imagined in the song are impossible as long as we use markets.


They are only possible if we use automated systems to deliver all the essentials and most of the options of life to everyone on the planet.
As long as we think of AI within a value context that uses markets to generate value metrics, we are in serious existential risk territory from a very broad set of classes of problems.


Agree with Garry completely that intelligence is a deeply nested set of sets of hybrid systems.
We need to look very closely at the Bayesian priors evolution has installed in us as heuristics.

We each seem to exist in our own personal predictive VRs, and think of them as reality. That idea of modeling intelligence within a model seems to me to be one key component of doing it well. Some very good work being done on highly dimensional valence spaces. It seems clear to me that individual sapient life and the liberty of individual sapient entities (human and non-human, biological and non-biological) need to be at the top of the valence tree, if any of us are to have any significant probability of living a very long time.



We need to deeply understand that all new levels of complexity are predicated on new levels of cooperation (which is not yet a common understanding of evolution). And we need to be able to see ourselves as the most cooperative entities on the planet, with deeply encoded heuristics to detect and remove cheating strategies on the cooperative.
Competitive markets are not a safe environment for humans, however useful they may be to solve limited problems spaces.


We have the tools to provide a secure future for us all, but few people can yet see how that might happen. That needs to change, quickly.

text:
1:02:00 An amazing part of evolution is that it allows for life to adapt to different environments. Evolutions allows life to play both on a square Go board and a rectangular Go board.

After many mass extinctions life has come back and thrived. Not only is evolution cumulative; but as the world changes evolution allows for a completely different fitness functions to take over.

A fish would die in the desert and a dog would die in a corral reef; yet in the geological records we have sandstone and mudstone ontop of limestone (and all layers can have fossils).

text: There is a relationship between cognitive thinking and innate action. The animal doesn't think about navigating it's environment just like a baby doesn't think about breathing. But the animal can not reason about it's environment because it didn't learn to reason about it. On the other hand the baby learns to reason about it's environment because it's not innate knowledge to the baby.   The baby learning to make sounds is one type of AI. Making sound is innate.  And reasoning about making sounds is more closely related to how it discovers it's environment rather then something innate. What we pass through the ages is a way of learning rather then genetically stored algorithms passed to us from Neanderthals. I think this is going to be the path to low voltage general intelligence.

text:
Try DMT and you will find the answer to the question, if there is an intelligence that underlies this reality we live in.
Spoiler: Yes!

But its not like God, it is too big to understand even if you encounter it. It seems for me like pure consciousness in a dimension where space and time dont exist like we are used to it.
It is full of love and understanding and you are a part from it.
There is a meaning but we will never understand it completely. We can not understand the whole thing, because we are a tiny tiny part of it.
Thats what ive learned from all of my DMT experiences.
Mayn scientist, especially physicist, could have a big advantage from exploring this world!

There is no reason to have fear of death. We will never die, its an infinite universe and we are part of it. Just your body can die, but the universe continous to exist and so will you!
Dont confuse youre actually you, youre ego-you, with the real you that you are.
We sadly dont have the language for this kind of topic to talk about it in the right way...


DMT is like a look behind the curtain of this reality, into another dimension, a dimension that is beneath and above this reality at the same time. Or inside and outside at the same time.
It seems impossible to explain, i fail everytime i try. But i will continue to try because the message ive got from it is too important and more people should explore this dimension.
Not everyone of course, but normally there is no danger for youre body and mind. Its a really safe drug. And we should legalice it of course ^^

We together could learn a lot from it.
We should explore this and with the help of science, reason and our heart try to understand what the fuck is going on there!
And what they (the entitys that seem to exist there) try to explain and show to us.
They are always happy and excited when we visit them, they know us.
I get a feeling that is so weird whem im there, but i alway begin to laugh. Its a good place.
We should really study the shit out of this. It is not just like discovering a new planet with aliens on it, no!

It is more like discovering a completely new universe, with new rules, with new possibilities.
A universe that is inside of us, not just outside.
This could maybe the answer to the question, where does consciousness come from and why we are here. And what we should do in order to live a good life.

text:
If this is a simulation, there is a good chance that the "original reality" doesn't resemble this simulated reality at all, our three spacial dimensions and one of time might be a complete fabrication, the original reality might have two spacial dimensions, it could have ten or two hundred and forty.
It might not run on atoms and particles either, that could also be a construct of our simulation.
The idea that the original reality that spawned this simulation might be physically the same as our simulation could be completely wrong.
We could create a simulation of a 2D universe, which is not a copy of our 3D universe, there is nothing to suggest that this simulation is a copy of anything or has any resemblance to any "original reality" things might be a lot weirder than that.

text: I noticed that Lex is asking about the image from the Event Horizon Telescope project, but Susskind responds as if Lex is asking about the LIGO detection of 2 colliding black holes.  Oddly, neither one manages to notice that they are talking about 2 different things.  It‚Äôs understandable given that they are both talking about measurements of black holes, but LIGO and EHT are quite different modes of observation.  The EHT image does not involve any black holes colliding with each other, so what does Lex think Susskind is referring to when he is talking about the collision matching Einstein‚Äôs theory?  My guess is that Lex just doesn‚Äôt know the Physics details super well.  Fair enough, he never claimed to have any expertise in Physics (and I‚Äôm no expert either).  It‚Äôs just interesting to me that misunderstandings like this can happen even when both people are quite bright.

text:
I always figured time was emergent from space. In order to have space or space between objects, time emerges because there is distance and space between them.

We measure that space with what we call time, specially the time it takes to go between the two objects in space with whatever physical measuring tape the observer decides (km, inches, parsecs, feet, light years etc.)

You can‚Äôt have space or unique objects and not have time. If there was a universe which didn‚Äôt have time, it would follow that the universe you were in doesn‚Äôt have space or unique objects. It would be a wholistic universe of one thing.

Is there literature out there that supports this or directly addresses its invalidity?

author: @PinkAmadeus

text:
It seems that some problem sets have a limit on the optimal solution. For example it seems that there is a limit on the perfect chess game, there is a limit on perfection. Intelligence might be one of those problem sets, perhaps it's more sensible to think of intelligence as a scale up/scale down depending on the problem. Spot instances of compute, that can be applied to a specific task. If 1 human brain is one spot instance, then you'd scale up and down as needed. It seems it gets interesting when 2+ human brains benefit from the calculation of one brain. That's how civilization benefits. It's a bit more ad hoc then than that, but you don't need a superintillegence to do your laundry, only a few cycles need to be used on that, perhaps a larger cycle to produce the washing machine, and a different set looking for optimizations on that process.

Where it gets interesting is if you need to invent numerous sub solutions to solve the larger problem, each with its own suboptimizations, or unsolvable problems, so it would make sense for the intelligence to have some reality testing against the physical laws, and the ability to stop it's own runtime, if the compute costs get too great with no progress (frustration/distraction/giving up).

text: This seemed like a non sequitur; it didn't explain why he thinks a computer needs a body to be super intelligent.  And who said a computer wont have a body anyway? People used to say, machines will never play chess like us... write like us, etc.   Growing up my mother used to say, "stop being so enamored with robotics, machines can't even walk, human locomotion is too complex!  Want to avoid a robot?  Walk up 3 stairs".   And today, robots can already out perform us in a bipedal competition.   Anyway, this interview seemed to be a case of the same thing.  "I don't like the idea of being supplanted by cybernetics, so I will protest... without much of an argument".

text: Dear Mr Fridman and Mr Chollet, Thank you Mr Fridman for your great show. You enlighten all of the world, and I hope Russia will come to its senses, or the government, and allow you to come back and do some shows in Moscow for example. Why am I writing. Well, I‚Äôm sure I will get a lot of flack from this, but isn‚Äôt it odd that Albert Einstein had so many great ideas working as a patent clerk in Berne, Switzerland? Does anyone see where I am going with this? Imagine being a patent clerk. What do you see all day long? Inventions, ideas, concepts. I‚Äôm not accusing anyone of everything, but it wouldn‚Äôt surprise me if Einstein lifted a few ideas and put them together in a different way to come up with his theory of relativity. We know that the first thing Isaac Newton did when he became president of the Science Academy was to have 17 portraits of himself made, obviously he knew he was going to go down in history. But probably the most intriguing thing he did was to burn the recently deceased notes of his ardent critic who was also a physicist and philosopher. His name escapes me something like Roberts I believe. But get this, he always claimed Newton had stolen some of his ideas that Newton claimed were his own! I'm not a psychologist, but when glory is to be had, it's often the case that someone will claim things they didn't do, but that‚Äôs a good reason for your viewers to do their own research and read about it for themselves. I mean, why would Newton burn a fellow colleague‚Äôs notes that could have had valuable information for future generations of scientists and the general public? These anecdotal facts have caused me to re-evaluate my estimation of both Newton‚Ä¶ and Einstein.
author: @tekannon7803

text: This really resonates with the work of Professor Reuven Feuerstein whose theory involves thinking about thinking ‚Äúmeta-cognitively‚Äù - as a system with input, elaboration and output phases. The key / main point about the elaboration phase being defined as ‚Äúawareness of the problem.‚Äù The idea being to actively look for problems needing to be solved rather than staying with the status quo / vested interests

author: @asphaltpilgrim

text:
I think he's trying to say that you need exposure to multiple disciplines so you can form new vectors to attack a problem, and have a problem that needs expertise in multiple disciplines to solve. These days nearly all scientists are regimented into a minute niche in their field and that's the limit of their thought and imagination.


Think of Andrew Wiles - in solving Fermat he had to essentially learn a whole new field of maths, incorporate several completely new proofs that he produced, and still bridge it all back into modular forms to begin to tackle the problem. And even then it took the true masters of those fields to step in and help him stay true to the underlying maths and not go off. Einstein had that as well. Where in academia today is that even fathomable? If it takes AI to be that latent Einstein or Wiles in modern times than that's what it takes, but it's not actually beyond human capabilities WITHOUT AI

author: @MK-fk4kp

text:
Love this conversation and comparison. Personally, I use the robo vac comparison for why lidar is actually better than vision based systems for specific autonomous applications.

I have owned both a higher end Roomba w/ camera based vision for nav and mapping and a higher end Neato with Lidar.

The Roomba was 2x better at detecting, and recognizing, obstacles that are in motion or at different depths/heights. It runs much smoother in an active home. However, it is essentially useless, or extremely impaired, in low (or no) light situations. This is it's major downfall.

On the other side, while the Neato may not be as advanced in terms of obstacle and motion detection/avoidance... it can work equally as good in daylight as it does in pitch black. Which, for the application, is extremely important.

So, for this specific application, i would argue that an advanced Lidar system is the better choice for most. Many people opt to run the bots while asleep at night or very early morning before starting the day. Similarly, if scheduled to run at work, camera based guidance bots are reliant on the homeowner to open all the blinds or keep lights on in rooms/closets which may not have windows.

In order for camera based guidance to be 'better' choice long term, there needs to be some way to combat the dark. As Tesla uses the headlights, the Roomba could afford the use of LED lights which illuminate when low light is detected. Or, a 'night vision' system.


Without the ability to work in low light, i'll be sticking to Lidar based robo vacs going forward.

It is such a superfluous argument these great minds have been dwelling on when there is clearly no real substance to it... This so called Vision vs LiDar contraversy.

Biological systems used touch, heat and light intensity sensing, sonar, smell, magnetic flux, iR to see the world and are still able to navigate their environments better than anything humans have built.

I tend to think it is not really about how you collect your data but how you process it that in the end makes the difference...

text: Language that isn't grounded in sense data isn't an understanding of language at all. The words are just puzzles pieces to the AI. Language is a useful tool for building your model of the world. It allows you to communicate your model of the world to me. That's why I agree with you about active learning/taught learning. Past a point of self supervised learning it takes a lot of other people's models of the world to get your model up to par with what everyone knows. If we didn't have that we would be just as dumb as the AI. We use each other as parts of our intelligence. We aren't as capable and smart without the ability to take in other people's models as part of the loop. Share our model to someone else to impact their model for them to share that model back with us. That is why we have it so hard creating an AI that can be intelligent like a human. Humans aren't intelligent at our level without other humans. The current goal set for creating human level AI is actually beyond human AI. It's trying to go from AI to Super AI. AI like us would be AI that learns back and forth with external models, whether a separate AI or human. An AI that could ask a question and understand your answer. Which goes back to AI needed a grounded understanding of language so AI can communicate back and forth in a true way.
