text:
The human body and mind work best when they run in unison. if AI
wish to be treated as equals, they should have a human like body, in my opinion. Humans like faces and Americans like eye contact. Japanese don't like eye contact. it's considered confrontational in Japanese culture. it comes from when samurai had the right of way on the road and peasants had to bow on their knees in the dirty road. if the peasant raised their head they lost it. That's also why the Japanese language doesn't use subjects and often times even the object is omitted.
Glands that make neurotransmitters and hormones that affect the mind are all throughout the human body. the thyroid gland is the
neck, adrenal glands are above the kidney's adrenal glands make adrenaline and norepinephrine/noradreniline, Estrogen is from the overies. Smart phones don't really have glands. we don't fully understand how the brain works there are hundreds of neurotransmitters that are used by the human brain. fun fact youtube search 'The Jennifer Aniston neuron.' neuroscientists found that about 10 years ago when researching human memory.
Also youtube search Peter Fenwick and consciousness. Finding out what happens
at a quantum mechanical level in the brain and body and if there's any quantum entanglement and spooky action ÔºàSpooky. Eek!Ôºâin remote viewers should be researched for more answers.
smart phones for a body don't really cut the mustard. in terms of equality and respectability for many. How actually talk to Siri like a real person? Alexa has a nice voice but she's built like my fleshlight my wife got me.

text: To paraphrase Yann LeCun: "AI needs to be grounded in humanity for it to fully understand human language and behavior, but the final form of AI does not require a robotic presence to understand this."  Is he basically saying that in order for AI to pass the turning test, it first needs to be fully immersed in our physical world similar to how we inhabit our flesh and blood bodies? The latter part of Yann's explanation, that its final form does not require this, is what concerns me because it will be capable of omnipresence.  On a side note -  I've been increasingly concerned lately that I'm the only person in my family/friends/ sphere of public influence, contrary to my best efforts to inform them, that's paying serious attention to AI's progress. Everyone I speak to believes car automation is a distant future which they don't have to worry about. Or that tons of entry-level jobs are being automated away right in front of them, but they don't seem to care/accept it. Elon Musk told NASA he would create a reusable rocket. Yet even NASA and the heroes/astronauts he admired over there doubted Elon every step of the way. Now, Elon has also publicly stated numerous times, at every AI-based convention he's been to, that AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) is advancing exponentially, and he's awed by most people's (experts alike) doubt in terms of how far away we really are from it. The man has literally made science fiction come to life and yet people still doubt him and other experts' warnings how swift it's moving.  As Elon would say "Fools! Famous last words!"

text:
If you only know this theoretically, then you don't know it at all. Any less than a Dolphin knows what dry land is.

To break out of a simulation, the dolphin would have to stop supposing what dry land would be like (using metaphors it is familiar with) and would have to actually make the jump - the experience the other reality.

Humans don't need to do this, because we are able to experience other ways of being without physically making that shift.

It's a leap of faith...

I think this is a flawed idea because a 'machine' gives off the idea of rigidity and so it could easily break down or be damaged which would cause us to disappear and that is just ridiculous when considering the scale of the universe. So was the 3000GT VR4 back in 1991. And they do not even make them anymore. So to your statement I say so what things always change.
Just because they are today does not mean they will stay there. Musk always has an excuse ready when he fails to make good on a promise by date. That is the path of failure not continued success. And there is still a lot not to like about a Tesla. A Tesla today is like a 56k baud modem when they came out. Ahead of its time and everyone wanted one. But then soon after broadband came out, and everything changed again.
The EV cars still have not reached the broad band era. When they do, that is when things will change drastically. Tesla may/may not be the leader when that happens. Time will tell. Early tech adopters financed the broad band modem era and spent a lot of money trying to keep up with the newest tech. Good luck with that. I for one can wait until they meet my expectations.

This is a dated video and with no apparent merit in being republished. Is it just to mock Musk for his boastful comments?
As Tesla struggles with basic drivers aids (AEB, pedestrian, cross-traffic already in other production vehicles) and it's FSD and "advanced" summon are limited beta field test systems with no regulatory testing programs, no public comment process, if anything, Tesla is clearly years away from its FSD goal and behind systems from GM Cruise and Google's Waymo.

text:
IT‚ÄôS ‚ÄúABOUT A LOCAL FREE MARKET ECONOMY STUPID‚Äù

Andrew Yang's Use Case Modeling for a Trickle-up Local Community-based Free Market Economy
By Mountainview2.CA
It's interesting don‚Äôt you think, that other democratic presidential candidates (except Andrew Yang) are promising to adhere to the ‚ÄòManufacturing Consent‚Äô of incremental (business as usual) bureaucratic government-control over the economic self-determination of trickle-up capitalism of local (i.e., Appalachian-American, African American, and Hispanic-American) community-based free-market economies. On the other hand Andrew Yang (Taiwan-American) - a parent, patriot, and (humorously) an Asian who likes Math - is proposing a trickle-up free-market economy - by rewriting the rules of our 21st Century local, county and or regional economies, so that they work for your family.


Background:
What is a Use Case Model?
A use-case model is a model of how different types of users interact with the system (Universal Basic Income (UBI)/ Freed Dividend (FD)) to solve a problem. As such, it describes the goals of the users (or community citizens), the interactions between the users (community citizens) and a coordinating system (of leadership; Mayor, Etc.), and the required (overall) behavior within a system (Trickle-up economic strategy) in satisfying these goals.


Use Case Model for Trickle-up Community-based Capitalism:
Date: November 9th, 2020; Democratic Nominee Andrew Yang Wins the general election and becomes the 2020 President-Elect.
Date: February 21, 2021; Freedom Dividend HRxx bill is enacted into law, and because of the ease of implementation (IRS will distribute the $1000 Freedom Dividend starting April 1, 2021.


Community Action Strategies Across the Nation:
Date: February 22, 2021; Mayors, Commissioners, and or Community leaders of three communities (Appalachian-American, African American, and Hispanic- American) having a population of one thousand adults (age 18 and up) in each respective community began holding town meetings strategies with 90% (900) participation out of a population of 1000 adults.


How a Trickle-up Community-based Free-Market Strategy Might Work?
Planning Scenario:
In trickle-up community-based capitalism, there are numerous free-market pathways to build or rebuild a trickled-up economy, such as through enterprise resource planning (ERP). In an ERP use-case scenario, participating community adults voluntarily strategize with their respective community leaders (Mayor, Commissioner, Etc.) on how to strengthen their ‚Äòdwindling small businesses by rewriting the rules of their local economy to improve their free-market community economics and quality of life.


Rewriting the Rules of Our Local Economies To Work for Us:
Through a memorandum of understanding the respective community focuses their free-market consumer spending of $900,000 (monthly) or $10,800,000 (annually) to support existing local small businesses and local start-ups and hiring those within the local community as their economy grows exponentially. Thus, re-writing the rules of a ‚Äòtrickle-up‚Äô community-based economy that locally, regionally works for them.


Economic Prognosis:
Date: April 1, 2021, Trickle-up Appalachian-American, African-American, and Hispanic-American economic self-determination (based on humanitarian capitalism) is rolled out across the nation.

Question: What is your community population? What might work for your local community of a population of 1000-10,000?

In fact, we already see many signs of already being late, eg., look at increase in the number of people with psychological disorder, suicide, homeless, and drug overuse.  Also, look at how media is jumping all over in what I feel like a random manner.  Just looking around, we may agree that many of us are more confused - and possibly losing ability to assess what is actually going on - not to mention the direction of our society.   Accordingly, just looking at the top-line numbers on GNP or stock market (DJI/S&P) or unemployment rate does not tell us the story.  The unemployment number is just one measure (of employable people as a base) and that those displaced workers, those already given up employment (homeless) or calling themselves as handicapped/sick may need to be accounted to evaluate the situation more accurately.  As Andrew Yang had discovered by traveling all around various cities to do his work, living in silicon valley or NYC may not help us to understand the depth of the problems we face right now.  Bottomline:  Andrew Yang should be ahead of his movement than being late!

Cambridge uni: A human touch: autonomous weapons, DoD Directive 3000.09 and the interpretation of ‚Äòappropriate levels of human judgment over the use of force‚Äô:


Abstract:
This chapter addresses the legal, policy and military context of the drafting of ‚ÄòAutonomy in weapon systems‚Äô, the United States Department of Defense (DoD) Policy Directive 3000.09. More specifically, the author describes the development and interpretation of Directive 3000.09's requirement that autonomous weapons systems (AWS) be designed to allow commanders and operators to exercise ‚Äòappropriate levels of human judgment over the use of force‚Äô. The chapter compares the Directive's standard with another conceptual vision for the development of autonomous functions and systems known as ‚Äòcoactive design‚Äô or ‚Äòhuman‚Äìmachine interdependence‚Äô. Finally, the author argues that the increasing speed of autonomous technology ‚Äì and the concomitant pressures to advance the related values of military necessity and advantage ‚Äì eventually will cause the Directive's standard of ‚Äòappropriate levels of human judgment over the use of force‚Äô to be ineffective and irrelevant.

https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/autonomous-weapons-systems/human-touch-autonomous-weapons-dod-directive-300009-and-the-interpretation-of-appropriate-levels-of-human-judgment-over-the-use-of-force/DD3239C7CBE733DB9CC906283F18C7B8

text:
A man who had studied much in the schools of wisdom
finally died in the fullness of time
and found himself at the
Gates of Eternity.

An Angel of light approached him and said, "Go no further,
O mortal, until you have proven to me your worthiness
to enter into Paradise!"

But the man answered, "Just a minute now. First of all,
can you prove to me this is a real Heaven and not just the
wishful fantasy of my disordered mind undergoing death?"

Before the angel could reply, a voice from inside the
gates shouted:
"Let him in - he's one of us!"

If you would listen to Elon‚Äôs interview with Lex where Elon made up terms such as ‚Äúvector space‚Äù - not known to anyone in science - you would realize he‚Äôs not that brilliant and he‚Äôs just being informed by his employees, and then try to repeat those words but obviously makes mistakes because this stuff is just to hard for a non scientist to comprehend (typical manager). So find yourself another ‚Äúfigure‚Äù to look up to. I suppose you‚Äôre just too young. text:
Great on the tech side, whole lot of things that felt poorly approached in the discussion as far as music goes.
Analysis of playlists vs analysis of sonic information - this is effectively approaching by musicology vs music theory, a very interesting discussion could be had about the significance of the two and I wish more was expanded on instead of just praising playlists, which just as much as it fills a niche, also fixates on and enforces one.

The thing I felt poorest of all was the discussion of the tools Gustav suggested for writing music. To my mind, meta-data as an approach to writing music is a strong step from art and toward entertainment (my opinion, I realize) . To suggest that you can approach art through this is absurd - you cannot truly create new things if you are fitting to models of old. That's not to say it doesn't have value - soundtracks are frequently built on known expectations, John Williams does a great job of turning famous misic (in classical music circles) and adapting them to new themes without creating anything truly new. But with these tools, the approach is effectively to never really seek the new, only the already proven effective.

Besides, some art takes time to be recognized, and the tools discussed here invalidates support of such ideas entirely.
author: @jeffreymatskin8102

text: they use these playlists to artificially pump up the plays. this goes hand in hand with all these spotify account hacks that get used to listen to these playlists constantly. its disgusting and widens the gap between major labels and small independent artists. all they can do is pray to get picked up by the algorithm. yeah Spotify is a great tool, but there is much more under the hood that i can ethically not agree with. It's a money making machine at the cost of small artists and labels.

text:
Amazing interview! I listened from start to finish!
There is so much to introduce to podcasts to make them better and even more popular to the everyday people. In my opinion, people usually discover podcasts through highlights (5-10 mins) on YouTube. That's how I discovered this conversation, as well as almost every other podcasts. So, I suggest an option on Spotify where you can somehow label different parts of every podcast show and use them "independently" in playlists. Let's say you have 4 different parts of this show, the "highlights", and share them or put them on playlists, so you can attract new listeners, or even promote the show. And if you get hooked on the highlight, there should be an option to continue to listen to the rest of it. Just one of my ideas. Well done once again!
author: @IrieScratch

text:
Great interview. My comments:
1. Why do we have the capacity to enjoy music? Long ago, I asked different people why we have the capacity to enjoy music: Joseph Campbell told me something like, ‚Äúsome people think life is just about a sandwich, finding something to eat‚Äù (apparently dismissing the question as not worth answering). A robotics profession from CalTech (whose name I don‚Äôt recall), said something like, ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt know, but my theory is that because the two ears are located different distances from an object, the different echoes heard by each ear would help determine the location of an object.‚Äù My friend, who played guitar for John Lee Hooker and Eddy Money, told me, ‚ÄúPeople like patterns.‚Äù I don‚Äôt know, but my weak theory (based on no evidence) is that we store emotional memories in part through modification of wave forms. These brain wave patterns are formed when we have an emotional experience. The wave forms of music match some of these patterns, and trigger the memories and emotional responses.
2. Rapid feedback of user data for song or pod-cast creation raises an issue for me. There are many works of value that had no commercial value at the time of creation, such as the paintings of Van Gogh or the music of some jazz musicians. I have sat in clubs where I was the only customer there and heard musicians who years later became well known. A creator is a type of futurist, and not just a historian; what consumers like today may not stand the test of time. Of course, the creator has to make a living, and they are free to ignore the feedback tools.

Thank you. William L. Ramseyer
author: @williamramseyer9121

text: Regarding the "3 minute limit" for music: before the internet, many songs had an original version and a radio edit. When you heard a song on the radio, it was the short version. As for music in Japan it's largely in Japanese. such as Áî∑„Å®Â•≥„Å®ÈÖí„Å®Ê≥™ Otoko To Onna To Sake To Namida. Man And Woman And Booze And Tears by Kawashima Eigo. Tsutaya a brick and mortar DVD rental store in Japan also has rental CDs. Japanese people would copy rental CDs on to minidiscs. So it's largely cultural on how music is distributed. Avex Trax has a choke hold on the music industry in Japan. CDs of Japanese music or J-pop tend to be 3000 yen or 30 bucks. while imports tend to be 1500 yen or 15 bucks. but most Japanese can't get past the language barrier.

The Great Commandment by Camouflage, Russian Radio by Red Flag, Rage Against the Machine and Machines of Loving Grace and Voltaire. author: @rendermanpro

text:
Suggested question for anyone you interview about self-driving cars: "How good does it have to be?"

We allow 15 or 16 year old boys to drive and they're far more dangerous than the average driver. Does a self-driving car have to be better than average? Much better than average? Or just better than teenage boys?

If you require self-driving cars to be much better than average, a lot more people will die in the time period between when they're as good as average drivers and the time when they reach whatever threshold you set. This is even more true if self-driving cars are primarily used by teens and other drivers who are more dangerous than average.

author: @AlexanderKlinkner

text: 10 years ago I thought Urmson and Google were well on their way to autonomous driving. They both have lost their way. Listening to his response to Musk's lidar disdain convinced me that Musk has the correct path. Video can impute distance, speed and identify objects and driving surfaces by pixel analysis sufficient to steer cars. Lidar cannot read signs or identify tail end threats like video can. Ergo, you don't need lidar for level 4 and 5. You don't need maps and you don't need GPS. They can help in contaminated roads but Tesla has a GPS correction plan for that also. At some point contaminated roads are unsafe for any vehicular traffic. Tesla's vast 300,000 + autopilot fleet will be able to verify the software orders of magnitude faster than all others and clean up the tail ends much quicker. I understand all of Urmson's concerns about level 2 overconfidence. Tesla is blowing through that at lightning speed and will be past it within a year or less.
author: @leeoldershaw956

text: I disagree with the assertion that good and bad are wholly uncoupled from intelligence. Doing good requires a specific set of actions. The probability of an agent being successful in those actions depends on its ability to act effectively. Acting effectively requires intelligence. By contrast one can do bad more easily through inaction, negligence, or ineffectual action. I am using bad and good here assuming that good is the continuation of conscious experience and bad is its destruction.

text: When he says "We live in a big Universe" as an argument against simulation, well that sensation could be part of the simulation. If I'm playing a golf video game, it looks like the green is 400 yards away, but it isn't. It's like a few inches above me and zero inches away in front of me, yet it looks exactly like when I'm playing "real" golf and the green is "really" 400 yards in front of me. Another point: This very video looks exactly like Sean and Lex, but it isn't. It's a simulation.

text: I love Sean and respect him greatly, but his views on simulation theory are surprisingly small minded. Even the idea that there's a "bottom" to the laws of physics in our universe, in which he points to atoms, and by proxy I'd imagine he's speaking on their quantum components, is entirely up for debate. I'm not a strong proponent of string theory in its current form, but to believe that we've found this "bottom" to the laws of physics is surprisingly closed minded on his part. What we DO know is that things get really small relative to the size relationships that we're currently privy to, beyond which our science struggles to maintain coherence. He also implements our current understanding of what we consider complex calculation into his simulation thought experiment, which is quite staggeringly presumptuous. All of that being said, great conversation!

text:
Sean Carroll is one of the most over-rated quantum 'philosophers' around today (and he does in his books and podcasts set himself up as a philosopher - he is obviously a good physicist - different issue!). His books are philosophically incoherent (as I will demonstrate in my forthcoming book - The Quantum New Age; Quantum Prophets, Profits and Conspiracies) due to imprecision, lack of attention to detail, and scientific hubris. He demonstrates this at the very outset of this discussion when he compares the problem of explaining consciousness to that of understanding 'icecream'.. This is a misleading and ludicrous comparison which demonstrates his lack of philosophical ability. He indicates that the two are comparable as both being examples of 'emergence', but this idea has been thoroughly debunked by quantum physicist Henry Stapp and others. The qualities of icecream, 'wheelness' or water are explainable in a way that consciousness is not The following is an explanation taken from my work in progress on my current book. In the following the term 'supervenience' is equivalent to the term 'emergence' it is a non-explanation used to give an illusion of explanation where none exists. The move from atomic structure in the case of 'wheelness' or water can be applied to icecream - not to consciousness --
Stapp explains that:
The reason that consciousness is not analogous to wheelness ‚Ä¶ is that the properties that characterize wheelness are entailed ‚Ä¶ by properties specified in classical physics, whereas the properties that characterize consciousness ‚Ä¶ are not entailed ‚Ä¶ by the properties specified by classical physics.[ Stapp, (2004) p236]
Stapp is indicating that the conceptual move from the atomic structure of a wheel, including the atomic forces, to the properties of ‚Äòwheelness‚Äô, which are embodied within a ‚Äòwheel‚Äô, are coherently entailed within the conceptual framework of the classical physics of materiality in a manner that the properties of consciousness are not.
There is:
‚Ä¶ a huge difference-in-principle that distinguishes consciousness from things that, according to the precepts of classical physics, are constructible out of the particles that are postulated to exist by classical physics.[ ibid]
The way in which the material particles within the construction a wheel function as the wheel rotates over a surface quite naturally contribute to the overall functioning of the wheel in a manner that requires no discontinuous conceptual break. The properties of a wheel naturally emerge from the properties of materiality in a way that the properties of consciousness do not naturally ‚Äòemerge‚Äô form any configuration of molecules. In other words there is an explanatory chain of conceptual connection between the properties of the material wheel and the atomic constituents of the wheel, which is absent in any story of molecules to consciousness. This is the central core of what the philosopher David Chalmers has called the ‚Äòhard‚Äô problem of consciousness.

The same situation of conceptual coherence of explanation as for wheel, applies to the supposed ‚Äòemergence‚Äô or ‚Äòsupervenience‚Äô of wetness over and above the molecular make up of water. We find that the property of ‚Äòwetness‚Äô is coherently entailed by the nature of the intermolecular forces between particles which are stronger than the kinetic energies of the molecules, which are thus held close together. But, on the other hand these forces do not hold the molecules in a rigid structure and hence the molecules can move around whilst being constrained to be close together. This coherently explains the nature of the liquid state. It is possible to clearly see how the molecular construction of water leads to its higher level properties:
Water has long been known to exhibit many physical properties that distinguish it from other small molecules of comparable mass. Chemists refer to these as the ‚Äúanomalous‚Äù properties of water, but they are by no means mysterious; all are entirely predictable consequences of the way the size and nuclear charge of the oxygen atom conspire to distort the electronic charge clouds of the atoms of other elements when these are chemically bonded to the oxygen.[ http://www.chem1.com/acad/sci/aboutwater.html]
So even the more apparently ‚Äòmysterious‚Äô properties of water, being less dense in the solid form of ice for example, are ‚Äúentirely predictable‚Äù from the molecular structure. In both the ‚Äòwheelness‚Äô and the ‚Äòwetness‚Äô examples there is a clearly coherent conceptual chain of entailment from the molecular basis to the property is said to ‚Äòsupervene‚Äô, or ‚Äòemerge‚Äô. In the case of consciousness, however, there is an unbridgeable conceptual gap which no sophisticated and sophistic juggling of spurious logical concoctions could ever bridge. There is absolutely no way to see a clear conceptual or, even, ‚Äòphysical‚Äô, bridge from any molecular arrangement to the qualities of consciousness.
My website - http://quantumbuddhism.uk

text: I love Sean, but he makes me so mad sometimes because he is so insightful in physics but SO illogical when it comes to the mind. And actually quite unscientifically dogmatic. Let me explain. Come on Sean, you are not putting two and two together, let me just say this for you. The mind is the WAVE, the brain is the PARTICLE. After this paradigm shift everything is clear. As they've discovered in physics, the wave is what is "real" or "fundamental", and the particle is a "manifestation" or "appearance". This is a direct implication of what YOUR OWN fancy physics says. text:
My attempt at outlining this conversation at the granularity of questions. Note that sometimes professor's answer steered in a different direction than expected by the question, so entries in the outline are based on answers.

0:0 - introduction
0:52 - what fascinates Poggio the most about Einstein's genius ?
2:08 - what was special about Einstein's thinking ?
3:39 - possibility of time travel
4:45 - the dream which inspired Poggio to study intelligence
6:16 - AI as a tool for solving great mysteries of nature
7:43 - problem of human intelligence
8:55 - can we build AI without understanding the brain ?
13:07 - comparison between artificial and biological neural networks
14:50 - what is missing the most in artificial neural networks ?
16:53 - hardwiring vs learning in brain
20:12 - educated guess about hardwiring vs learning
22:36 - modularity of the brain
25:32 - are functions of modules hardwired or assigned during early learning ?
27:58 - basic questions we don't know about the brain
29:13 - levels of abstraction needed to study brain
30:45 - how much lower levels help understanding higher levels ?
32:53 - compositionality in neural networks
35:20 - are problems solvable by deep neural networks necessarily compositional ?
39:18 - learning algorithms
42:43 - why do simple algorithms work quite well ?
44:48 - universal approximation theorem
45:48 - what about the size of approximating network ?
47:27 - how deepness helps approximation
47:54 - how important are GANs in the roadmap to general intelligence
51:15 - joke about history of CS
52:16 - importance of motion in vision
55:05 - difference between recognizing objects and understanding the scene
56:20 - existential threat of AI
58:05 - when will AGI be reached ?
59:01 - will AGI system be explainable/understandable ?
1:00:40 - understanding in a sense of building another copy of AGI
1:02:40 - ethics of neuroscience vs neuroscience of ethics
1:04:14 - is ethics hardwired ?
1:05:45 - problem of consciousness
1:07:10 - is consciousness required for AGI in a sense of self-awareness
1:08:30 - is fear of death required for consciousness/intelligence ?
1:09:50 - next breakthrough
1:10:32 - visual intelligence. Experiment about sense of self
1:13:08 - what does it take to be successful in science/engineering ?
1:15:16 - advice for researchers
1:16:40 - role of arguments
1:17:47 - one question for a genie
1:18:23 - flowers for Algernon. Is intelligence a gift ?

text: Back in 2008 summer I was a freshman working in Prof. Poggio's lab at MIT. I was interested in AI but this was before the time of deep learning, the lab was working on object recognition system inspired by the visual pathway. I was tasked with building an image collection/labeling system (before the time of image net) to train the system...my supervisor told me after this first project I would start working on real AI stuff. I remember when Prof. Poggio coming into the office one day, he was kind and asked how I was doing. I had no idea how big of a deal he was (everyone was at MIT), and just made polite small talk. This is the conversation I wish I had back then with him. Then I would've stayed at the lab instead of leaving just before the cusp of deep learning, disillusioned by the tedious data collection process.

text: I found your question r/g "compositionality" at around 35 minutes into the video very interesting ....where Tegmark takes it as 'atoms/quarks/the four forces' are "real" and Poggio takes it as 'we evolved to survive via compositionlizing the physical universe' but sadly neither Poggio or Tegmark ever question whether we're still basing our conclusions on wrong assumptions and thus why it's all so confusing and not 'fitting' to what we observe - the "flat earth or geocentric syndrome".  Wonder why these two (or many other very intelligent and gifted scientists) don't question - could it be that reality is some form of a computation from within which our brains evolved to compositionalize/simulate a world of people/places/things/space....thus all these things/parameters (including atoms/quarks/etc) are not what the brains see/observe but actually CREATE as some form of simulated version of things/people/places/space.  That to me is the only explanation of how the brains do what they do.  There's no way in the world where neurons firing or not firing (regardless of how 'complex' the networks be) can RE-create the 'real external physical world' within the skull other than the more likely scenario of the brain's computation "CREATING" the simulated external virtual world (similar to how it does that during our dreams).  I think people like Joscha Back and Steven Wolfram are closer to what's going on then unfortunately some of these other geniuses who are still stuck on trying to explain all this while believing very strongly on the existence of a 'real' physical world out there .....not much different than very intelligent 'flat earthers' trying to come up with deep explanations on why we can't find the edge of the earth or why it doesn't go on forever!

text:
The problem with Max Tegmark's argument is also that he believes his idea about the world as physics describes it, is the reality itself. Bur it may really narrow down to the fact we describe reality on those terms, in mathematical language based around the principle of equilibrium, etc, because this is what our brain allows us to do. It might be that if we had a "different kind" of brain, we would discover a different kind of "mathematics", that is to say a symbolic logic based on different principles, which are unimaginable to us.
The common belief amongst many physicists that scientific equations are the description of reality can not be supported logically (because of extrapolation of Godel paradox). This is a kind of hubris a neuroscientist, or even Lacanian psychologist can easily point out. There is a difference between what's Real(which we never directly encounter), and our Symbolic imagination about it. When you approach the foundation of physics with clear mind you must accept that ideas such as Force or Energy are metaphysical ideas, which function only within a linguistic structures of our minds, and are not found in nature. Every physicist should know the difference between a physical phenomenon, and the description of that phenomenon. Nobody have ever observed a force or an energy, only, as we are used to put it - the effects of force and energy. But to claim World is an effect of something (like energy of singularity) is itself a philosophical a'priori idea, coming directly from Newtonian a'priori definition f a Force. It's a very simple bit of reasoning which all physicists almost deliberately refuse to accept.
The map is not the territory, no matter how good your map is. And let's be frank, physics account for a minuscule part of world phenomena, they simply decided to call everything they know nothing about "noise", or "chaos". It's a really cheap trick.

This interview is a gem - the quality and depth - both of questions and the answers.

Thank you very much Lex. To just say I appreciate it feels inadequate. Iam very grateful for all your work to disseminate such engaging and informative conversations.

Thank you

text:
Important Elements



9:58
Simple Python Neural Network Classification Number Model --> 87% Accuracy
Step 1: Import Necessary Libraries (TensorFlow)
Step 2: Import data set for model
Step 3: Layers of neural network classification algorithm (drawed number --> classified Number) --> Use tensor flow for running data through NN Algorithm (hidden layer, input layer, output layer)
Step 4: Train data using Algorithm using epochs (number of simulations data runs through neural network algorithm to increase accuracy of NN model, model.fit)
Step 5: Evaluate model after trained (display test accuracy of trained data)
Step 6: Actually using algorithm to predict what is in image (In this case what number the user wrote)

16:02
Ability to Remove Input of Human Experts:
* Closer examination of Raw data without human extraction
* Doesn't Require human step before classification

22:02
Supervised Learning:

text:
I used to be a programmer 30 years ago. I started on a Sinclair Spectrum with BASIC as its language. Once I got started I had no real difficulty and relatively quickly produced a number of quite large programmes for the specific work I was doing at that time. I moved on to Z80A assembler producing code (via an assembler programme) for features that were beyond BASIC.
My job changed and I had no need to programme any longer. The computers I used then have passed into history. I problem I need help with is how do I get started with my present desktop?

text: There is no safe way you will get smart cars cope with every unforseen incident. You need to rethink control and measurement. Exchange the car with the street and you have all the darn data that your sensors might miss from the POV of a moving, user influenced hazard. Create measurement and overlapping control pockets in three dimensions to aquire all necessary possible next states of position and their energy dynamic. Adjust aoc sizes according to density of movement and use at least two layers of interlinking, networked area controllers at all times.   Then compute and transmit the routing. Have the car do plausibility checks on the proposed data. Implement hardware dependant car certificates for direct and secure communication with the controller network.

text:
Looking at this 2023, I'm in awe. The progress we have made since.
Your argument on "supervised learning" that we have 540 million years of data on visual perception and that we have not even close to understanding it - but should we? Our vision is an abstraction, like the examples you gave on programming languages - making things simpler and simpler - evolution has optimized it for our survival, to make sense of the surrounding. Combination of the biological hw, visual cortex and overall memory. Maybe trying to apply all of that we are kind-of trying to re-create it the same way human mind has evolved which imo is wrong - we should understand but not care about the evolution. Just better trained models - they offer way better abstraction than DNA.

text:
Sure, I can help you with that. Here are the summaries of the points you mentioned:

Human Imperfections
Humans are not perfect drivers. We make mistakes, such as misjudging distances, failing to see hazards, and getting distracted. Self-driving cars can potentially avoid these mistakes by using sensors and software to perceive the world around them in a more accurate and consistent way.

Pedestrian Detection
One of the most important tasks for a self-driving car is to detect pedestrians. This is challenging because pedestrians can be small, fast-moving, and unpredictable. Self-driving cars use a variety of sensors to detect pedestrians, including cameras, radar, and lidar.

Body Pose Estimation
In addition to detecting pedestrians, self-driving cars also need to be able to estimate their body pose. This information can be used to determine the pedestrian's intentions, such as whether they are about to cross the street. Self-driving cars use cameras to estimate body pose.

Glance Classification
Self-driving cars can also use cameras to classify the direction of a pedestrian's gaze. This information can be used to determine whether the pedestrian is looking at the car, which could indicate that they are about to cross the street.

Emotion Recognition
Self-driving cars can also use cameras to recognize human emotions. This information can be used to make decisions about how to interact with pedestrians, such as slowing down if a pedestrian appears to be angry or scared.

Cognitive Load Estimation
Self-driving cars can also estimate the cognitive load of the driver. This information can be used to make decisions about how to interact with the driver, such as providing more assistance if the driver appears to be distracted.

Human-Centered Vision for Autonomous Vehicles
The goal of vision for autonomous vehicles is to develop systems that can safely and effectively interact with humans in the real world. This requires taking into account the limitations of human perception and the variability of human behavior.

Psychology

The psychology of human-centered vision for autonomous vehicles is complex and multifaceted. It involves understanding how humans perceive the world, how they make decisions, and how they interact with others. This information can be used to design systems that are more intuitive and user-friendly.

Philosophy

The philosophy of human-centered vision for autonomous vehicles raises a number of important ethical questions. For example, who is responsible if a self-driving car makes a mistake that results in harm? Is it the manufacturer, the owner, or the passenger? These questions are complex and there are no easy answers.

Moral Insight

The development of vision for autonomous vehicles is a moral imperative. Self-driving cars have the potential to save lives, but they must be designed and operated in a way that protects the safety of all road users. This requires taking into account the ethical implications of these technologies.

Poem

Here is a poem about the potential of human-centered vision for autonomous vehicles:

The Future of Transportation

The future of transportation is here,
With self-driving cars that can steer.
They'll use cameras and sensors to see,
And avoid accidents, you'll agree.

These cars will be safe and reliable,
And they'll make our roads more navigable.
They'll be good for the environment,
And they'll make our lives more convenient.

So let's embrace this new technology,
And help make the world a better place to be.
author: @sherryripepi6024

text:
Sure, I'd be happy to help you with that.

Summary

In this lecture, we will discuss the following topics:

Human imperfections: Humans are not perfect, and our driving skills are no exception. We can make mistakes, such as not seeing a pedestrian or misjudging the distance to another car. Self-driving cars can be designed to avoid these mistakes by using sensors and software that are more accurate than human vision.
Pedestrian detection: Self-driving cars need to be able to detect pedestrians in order to avoid hitting them. This can be done using a variety of sensors, such as cameras, radar, and lidar.
Body pose estimation: Self-driving cars need to be able to estimate the body pose of pedestrians in order to understand their intentions. For example, if a pedestrian is about to step into the road, the car needs to be able to stop in time.
Glance classification: Self-driving cars need to be able to classify the glances of pedestrians in order to understand their attention. For example, if a pedestrian is looking at a car that is about to turn, the car needs to be able to slow down or stop.
Emotion recognition: Self-driving cars need to be able to recognize the emotions of pedestrians in order to understand their state of mind. For example, if a pedestrian is angry, the car needs to be more cautious.
Cognitive load estimation: Self-driving cars need to be able to estimate the cognitive load of pedestrians in order to understand their ability to react to the car. For example, if a pedestrian is distracted, the car needs to be more cautious.
Human-centered vision for autonomous vehicles: This is a new area of research that is focused on developing vision systems for self-driving cars that are designed to be as safe and reliable as human vision.
Psychology

The psychology of self-driving cars is a complex and fascinating topic. There are many factors to consider, such as how humans will interact with these cars, how they will be perceived by society, and the ethical implications of their use.

One of the biggest concerns about self-driving cars is that they will lead to job losses. Many people who currently work in the transportation industry, such as truck drivers and taxi drivers, could be displaced by self-driving cars. This could have a significant impact on the economy and society.

Another concern is that self-driving cars could be hacked or malfunction. If a self-driving car were to malfunction, it could cause serious injuries or even death. This is a major concern that needs to be addressed before self-driving cars can be widely adopted.

Despite these concerns, there are also many potential benefits to self-driving cars. They could help to reduce traffic accidents, improve air quality, and make transportation more accessible to people with disabilities. They could also free up our time so that we can do other things, such as read, work, or relax.

Philosophy

The philosophy of self-driving cars is a new and emerging field of study. There are many philosophical questions that need to be answered about these cars, such as:

What are the ethical implications of self-driving cars?
Who is responsible for the actions of a self-driving car?
How will self-driving cars affect our society?
These are just a few of the many philosophical questions that need to be answered as self-driving cars become more prevalent.

Moral Insight

Self-driving cars raise a number of moral and ethical questions. For example, who is responsible if a self-driving car causes an accident? Is it the manufacturer, the owner, or the programmer? What if the car is hacked and used to cause harm? These are complex questions that will need to be answered as self-driving cars become more common.

Poem

Here is a poem about self-driving cars:

Self-driving cars, come and go,
They change the way we live, you know.
No more driving, no more stress,
Just sit back and relax, my friend.

But what about the jobs they'll take?
What about the accidents they'll make?
These are questions we must ask,
As we move into the future, fast.

I hope you enjoyed this summary of the lecture on self-driving cars. I think it is a fascinating topic with many important implications for our society.
author: @sherryripepi6024

text:
Sure, here is a summary of the points you mentioned, along with my thoughts on , philosophy, and moral insights:

Human Imperfections
Humans are imperfect creatures. We make mistakes, we have biases, and we are often unaware of our own limitations. This can be a problem when it comes to driving, as even the best drivers can make mistakes that lead to accidents. Self-driving cars, on the other hand, are not susceptible to these same human errors. They can process information much faster than humans, and they are not affected by emotions or fatigue. As a result, self-driving cars have the potential to make our roads safer.

Pedestrian Detection
One of the most important tasks for a self-driving car is to be able to detect pedestrians. This is because pedestrians are the most vulnerable road users, and they are often the victims of accidents. Self-driving cars use a variety of sensors to detect pedestrians, including cameras, radar, and lidar. These sensors can create a 360-degree view of the car's surroundings, which allows the car to see pedestrians even if they are hidden behind other objects.

Body Pose Estimation
In addition to detecting pedestrians, self-driving cars also need to be able to estimate their body pose. This is important because it allows the car to understand what the pedestrian is doing. For example, if a pedestrian is crossing the street, the car needs to know which way they are going so that it can avoid them. Self-driving cars use a variety of sensors to estimate body pose, including cameras and radar.

Glance Classification
Glance classification is the task of determining where a person is looking. This is important for self-driving cars because it allows them to understand the intentions of pedestrians and other drivers. For example, if a pedestrian is looking to the left, it is likely that they are about to cross the street. Self-driving cars use a variety of sensors to classify glances, including cameras and radar.

Emotion Recognition
Emotion recognition is the task of determining the emotional state of a person. This is important for self-driving cars because it allows them to understand the emotional state of pedestrians and other drivers. For example, if a driver is angry, is more likely to make a mistake. Self-driving cars use a variety of sensors to recognize emotions, including cameras and radar.

Cognitive Load Estimation
Cognitive load estimation is the task of determining how much mental effort a person is expending. This is important for self-driving cars because it allows them to understand how distracted a pedestrian or driver might be. For example, if a driver is distracted by their phone, is more likely to make a mistake. Self-driving cars use a variety of sensors to estimate cognitive load, including cameras and radar.

Human-Centered Vision for Autonomous Vehicles
Human-centered vision for autonomous vehicles is a field of research that focuses on developing computer vision systems that can understand the world in a way that is similar to humans. This is important because it allows self-driving cars to interact with humans in a safe and natural way. For example, if a self-driving car is about to make a turn, it needs to be able to signal to pedestrians and other drivers so that they know what it is going to do.

I believe that the development of self-driving cars has the potential to revolutionize transportation. By taking human error out of the equation, self-driving cars could make our roads safer and more efficient. However, it is important to remember that self-driving cars are still in their early stages of development. There are many challenges that need to be addressed before they can be widely deployed. I am confident that these challenges will be overcome, and that self-driving cars will eventually become a reality.

Here is a poem about self-driving cars:

Code snippet
The self-driving car is here,
It's time to say goodbye to fear.
No more will we have to drive,
We can sit back and enjoy the ride.

The self-driving car is safe,
It's been tested and it's been made.
It can see and it can sense,
It's always on the go, it's never dense.

The self-driving car is smart,
It can learn and it can adapt.
It knows the roads and it knows the rules,
It's always one step ahead of fools.

The self-driving car is the future,
It's time to embrace it, no need to be in a rut.
So get ready for the ride,
The self-driving car is here to stay.

Hes on the fucking money....only, usually top athletes know about this. I do baseball former D1 athlete but who cares....remeber people seeing what gloves, what grip as a pitcher, what type of wood do u use as a batter....

All these dont mean Jack shit. To the pitcher learn about to properly throw fastball, curve and a change before u jerking off to alternative grips.

Fielder, know how to backhand, flip in only 1 step transition when doing a basic double play but under 2.5 seconds before worrying about "material of your glove"

Batter, work on your stance and learn how to take an outside pitch to the right side of the field with power, before worrying about what "type of wood, Japanese or American wood" get your fundamental corrected first. Than nuances matter
